PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of former Senator George McGovern from the United States of America. I extend to him, on behalf of all honourable senators present, a very cordial welcome to this country and in particular to this chamber. We trust that he will have a most enjoyable stay in Australia.

—I direct my question to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is an Australian consulate to be established at Houston, Texas, next month? Do we already have consuls in San Francisco, Los Angeles, Chicago and Honolulu? Why is a new consulate needed and why, if there are trade opportunities in Texas, would the office not be headed by a trade commissioner instead of a Department of Foreign Affairs officer? Is the office to be given to yet another Liberal or National Country Party member of parliament, 13 of whom already have been appointed by this Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not know whether any announcement has been made with regard to the opening of an office in Houston. I did read a Press report along the lines of the question asked. I do know that there is a need for further representation in the United States. I will seek information with regard to whether an announcement is to be made about Houston and ascertain whether there is any other information which I can make available as soon as possible.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Support say whether the industry rationalisation policy of 1976 remains in force with the Department of Defence Support? If it is still the policy of the Department, how can such a system be modified to permit competitive tendering to contain costs? Since there have been significant exceptions to this doctrine why is the policy being selectively applied?

—The 1976 rationalisation agreement to which Senator MacGibbon referred was subject to some review early in 1980. The review was to have regard to the suitability and flexibility of the rationalisation plans to meet changing defence requirements. I understand that some changes have been made as a result of that. I will have to refer the specific questions asked by Senator MacGibbon to the Minister for Defence Support and get a detailed answer from him.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. I ask the Minister this question because of her responsibility for the proper spending of public money. Noting that the $121,700 appropriated in the Additional Estimates for the Department of Administrative Services for a mailing service for the Government Information Unit represents $2,300 a week, if it is for a whole year , I ask whether it is in fact for a whole year or only for part of a year. If it is not over a year, what is to be the weekly cost over a full year? I further ask whether her Department or any other department will conduct any kind of effectiveness audit of this service.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not have available information with regard to the matter raised by Senator McLaren. I assume that he had the opportunity at the time of the Additional Estimates to pursue the matter. I will seek information from the Department of Administrative Services. As far as the monitoring of effectiveness is concerned, the Department itself examines any of the expenditure that is used by it. In particular, I think that for the Government Information Unit and the dissemination of information about Government policies there would be mailing lists of different kinds for different departmental information. All of these things are subject to the same sort of inquiry as Senator McLaren or any other honourable senator may wish to pursue. I have no particular information with regard to the matter raised today . Senator McLaren seeks information about a particular figure. I will see what information can be obtained from the Department of Administrative Services.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources: In view of the continuing weakness in the world tin market and the importance of tin to a number of Australian communities, particularly in Tasmania, what is the Government doing to improve the situation at present?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did have some information on this matter at hand recently but I would like to get it updated. Therefore, I will refer the question to my colleague in another place to seek full information.

—Is the Minister for Finance aware of a recent report in the Australian Financial Review that the Government is delaying its substantive response to the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System until August this year? Does the Minister agree that home buyers are desperate not because there are no funds available but rather because they cannot keep pace with rising interest rates, now at an all time high, and because they would certainly not be able to cope with further increases which would inevitably follow a Government decision to deregulate interest rates as recommended in the Campbell report? Will the Minister give an assurance that the Government will not implement this recommendation but will instead maintain controls on housing interest rates, thereby enabling prospective home owners to make their commitment to buy a home without undue anxiety?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has announced on a number of occasions that many aspects of the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System are under study. He indicated that not one announcement but a series of announcements will be made as decisions are taken on the various aspects of the report. As far as home buyers are concerned, I think it ought to be remembered that at the time the report was tabled the Treasurer said that we would be looking particularly at the social consequences of any of the decisions that the Government might take on the recommendations of the Campbell report. In his statements at that time the matter of housing was raised.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the social consequences of housing interest rates are concerned, I remind the Senate that the Government's housing policy package which was announced some weeks ago contained measures of assistance to home buyers in the near future and recent home buyers. This package has shown the attitude of the Government in its effort to assist home buyers to deal with high interest rates. It has also given great assistance through the tax system and the Homes Savings Grant Scheme. Of course, it must be remembered that the banks have been helpful and co-operative in arranging for quite substantial increases in the housing funds available for those who seek them. The realities with regard to interest rates and the availability of funds cannot be ignored at any time we have this sort of discussion. However, as I said, the Treasurer, when introducing the Campbell inquiry report, spoke of the social consequences of decisions that are taken, and these are very much in the minds of members of the Government as they deal with the various recommendations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce had an opportunity to look at a letter which I supplied to him, sent from Ampol Petroleum (Victoria) Pty Ltd to a person whose name I blanked out, which sets out the terms of agreement which this franchise holder of Ampol is obliged to enter into in order to get supplies of fuel from that company? Has the Minister noticed paragraph 6 (a) which states that the selection of the price is at the discretion of the franchise holder but if he does not charge the price that Ampol requires him to charge, that company will not give an allowance to him?

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Minister understand that, in fact, Ampol supplies petrol to this franchise holder at 39.45c a litre and requires him to sell it at 0.65c lower than the price at which it supplies the petrol to him? He thus makes a loss of 0 .65c for every litre of petrol he sells and some two or three weeks later Ampol refunds him the amount lost on the petrol he has sold, plus a profit of about 2. 4c. Does this constitute a mark-up of 5.5 per cent? Is this agreement in accordance with the spirit of legislation recently passed through this chamber? Is Ampol putting itself in a situation where its franchise holders are, in fact, financing Ampol Petroleum (Victoria) Pty Ltd? Is Ampol perhaps in some collusion with the banks and requiring these franchise holders to borrow money from the banks in order to--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, please ask your question quickly. It contains numerous parts. It is nearly a statement.

—Yes, I understand, Mr President. In fact, I think I have asked three questions of the Minister. Finally, does the Government intend to take any action about these fuel companies which throughout Australia are endeavouring to bankrupt the franchise holders and retailers who are not part of their organisations?

—Order! Following my comments yesterday-I say this to the whole of the chamber-I hope that honourable senators will respond to requests I have made on numerous occasions to limit their questions, thereby at the same time giving Ministers an opportunity to give shorter answers. In this way more questions can be asked in this place. I call the Minister.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a long and complex question to which I have a long and complex answer. It is not, however, an answer with which I will enlighten the Senate at this stage. Of course, there has been a great deal of government intervention in this area, for the simple reason there have been very real difficulties for franchisers and retailers. The relationship between those individuals and the oil companies are now covered by a series of Acts which have been passed by this Parliament and which are in a sense unusual in the general commercial arrangements which apply within Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: My advice is that this letter is in accordance with the legislation, provided no bad faith or anything other than what appears on the face of the letter is involved. Whether the letter gives rise to a need for further government intervention is a matter on which I would not give an opinion. In any event, I think it is probably a matter of policy, which I cannot respond to at Question Time. But I take the question to be an indication that Senator Lewis is concerned at the competitive position of this particular retailer, at the question of whether this agreement is within the law and, if it is, whether the law is therefore adequate to protect his interests. I will therefore seek a consideration of those various points and a more detailed reply, which may well be in the form of a letter from the appropriate Minister. The matter is an extremely complex one. Senator Lewis has reminded me that he has asked whether it is within the spirit of the legislation. I can only say that the legislation is intended to provide protection to this particular group but, at the same time , not to prevent real competition in the market place for the benefit of consumers. That is a very delicate balance. I prefer not to hazard a guess at this stage as to whether it is within the spirit of the legislation. I will undertake to give it further and careful examination.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Attorney-General aware of the decision of the High Court handed down on Tuesday in the case of R. v. Darby where the majority held that a finding by a jury of not guilty no longer means that the accused person is said to be innocent of a charge? I ask by way of example whether the High Court decision means that we will no longer be entitled to say that the acquittal of the Minister for Defence, Mr Ian Sinclair, by the jury means that he is innocent . Will the Government consider the introduction of legislation in relation to this decision by the High Court?

—I have not had an opportunity to study the decision in the case referred to by Senator Button, apart from the general information relating to it which I have read in newspapers. I will take note of the matter raised by the honourable senator and give consideration to his suggestion.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TAR AND NICOTINE CONTENT IN CIGARETTES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and relates to an alleged breach, or an attempted evasion, of an agreement reached by Health Ministers at a meeting in Adelaide last year that negotiations would take place with tobacco companies about a voluntary advertising code, which negotiations have not yet proceeded because of lack of agreement among the State Ministers. I ask, firstly: Is it correct that representatives of a tobacco company met officers of the Department of Health on Wednesday, 21 April and that they showed the Department a series of filters which are capable of disguising the amount of tar and nicotine delivered by the cigarettes? Secondly, is the Minister aware that a brand known as Barclay has recently been launched on the Australian market, which is claimed to have a low tar delivery-that claim may be made because it has one of these filters attached -but which delivers a high quantity of tar? What action will be taken by the Government to prevent the tobacco industry from engaging in blatantly misleading practices of this kind? Will legislation be implemented to ensure that the actual tar delivered is accurately displayed on each packet of cigarettes and the advertisements for them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Health Ministers Conference brings together Federal and State Ministers. This conference set up a tobacco products sub- committee to examine matters of the kind raised by Senator Missen. The working party which was set up by that body had its first meeting this year and started discussions with industry. I understand there was a meeting on 21 April between officers of the Department of Health and the appropriate government analytical laboratory. Representatives of the tobacco company advised the committee that the tar levels which can be attained under machine smoking conditions are in fact lower than those which occur if people smoke the cigarettes. This is due to the fact that the smoking machine which tests the cigarettes does not occlude some of the little side vents and does not draw all the material in whereas, when people smoke cigarettes, those vents are occluded and a higher amount of tar is drawn.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Missen is correct in saying that the testing procedure does not give an accurate record with this particular by-pass filter of the amount of matter which is delivered. The machine which is used conforms to international standards. It is the usual machine but it will not pick up the load to the smoker when this particular kind of filter is used. Whether this represents some attempt to mislead the public or to by-pass the proper procedures is another question. I think that what has emerged is that this filter now does present a problem to the Department of Health and to the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories. They are going to put the technical aspects of this matter under review. They will have to come back to the Ministers in due course when this review is complete. If that then involves some alteration to the procedures for advising the public I think that is a matter which will be taken under consideration. The date 21 April is fairly recent and the matters have only just come to attention. It will take some time for analysis to be carried out and for a determination to be made as to whether procedures have to be changed, either in the method of analysis or in the method of notifying the public.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to a report delivered at the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science conference by Dr Sandra Egger and Jane Crancher on home violence. The report stated that most battered women seek help from the police and doctors but find them largely powerless to intervene. The report found that:

QUESTION.PARA: The most successful aid in cases of domestic violence was the women's refuge, yet this was used by only an average of 22 per cent of victims.

Would the Minister agree that it is clear from this report and others presented and debated in this place that more people are turned away from refuges than are accepted, because of accommodation and financial restraints? Would the Minister agree that women's refuges obviously require greater funding? Will the Minister consider some means of applying direct pressure on State governments at the next Premiers Conference to direct greater amounts of Federal grants to women's refuges?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure why this question is addressed to me because women's refuges have never been a responsibility of my Department but rather of the Department of Health. This matter is now, properly, I think, the responsibility of the State welfare departments or health departments, since the community health program was returned to sole State administration last year. I think that I saw a report of the paper mentioned by the honourable senator and some reference to it in a newspaper report concerning the incidence of violence. I did not see a report which was in such detail as to identify the cause or the proposed cure which was referred to by Senator Coleman in her question. It is a matter which basically is within State responsibility. I would not expect to be a participant at the Premiers Conference. In any event I would doubt that the Premiers would go into items of detailed policy of the sort that the honourable senator has raised. I think that if she wishes to see the matter pursued she should raise it with her colleagues in the various State parliaments.

—Is the Attorney-General aware of an incident which occurred at the Canning Vale Remand Centre in Western Australia on 28 March 1982 when an Aboriginal youth aged 19 years, Ricci John Vicenti, was shot while attempting to escape and subsequently died? Will the Minister make a thorough investigation into this matter and seek answers to the following questions: Firstly, is there a need for armed prison officers in the Canning Vale Remand Centre which was built in such a way-for example, it is surrounded with ribbon wire-as to obviate the need for firearms? Secondly, why are all prisoners, from first offenders to hardened criminals, held together in this remand centre? Thirdly, were warning shots fired? Fourthly, how competent in the use of firearms are the prison officers? Fifthly, why was Ricci Vicenti taken to Fremantle Hospital and then transferred to intensive care at Royal Perth Hospital when he had a bullet in his head? Sixthly, why did the two uniformed police officers not inform Mrs Vicenti, Ricci's mother, that he had been shot when they called on her on Sunday evening, 28 March 1982? Finally, why, in the first instance, was it necessary for Ricci to steal food in order to feed his family? It is my understanding that this was the offence with which he was originally charged.

—Senator Bonner has asked a series of detailed questions about an incident which occurred in the Canning Vale Remand Centre in Western Australia, an institution which is administered by the Western Australian Government. All the questions that he asked seemed to be within the responsibility of the Western Australian Government. I will look at the detailed questions to see whether there is any matter for which the Commonwealth has responsibility.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Considering that at a referendum in 1967 the people of Australia gave to the Federal Government the power for Aboriginal affairs, is it not the responsibility of the Federal Attorney to make these inquiries concerning an Aborigine who was shot and killed at a prison?
—I said I would look at the matter to see whether it involves anything that is a Federal responsibility.

—I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether he is aware that Mr David Saggers, the Western Australian delegate to the recent National Liberal Party Conference, has claimed, as reported in the Daily News of Monday, 17 May, that the changes to the Liberal Party's Aboriginal policy advocated by the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party but rejected by the Liberal Party Conference as bigoted and offensive, are, to quote Mr Saggers, 'already a part of Western Australian Liberal policy'. Mr Saggers is reported also to have said that granting equal rights to Aborigines was as irresponsible as granting such rights to children. Will the Minister guarantee that the Commonwealth will assert its constitutional rights and duty in the field of Aboriginal affairs to ensure that bigoted and offensive policies are not allowed to prevail in Western Australia, regardless of the reactionary nature of some of the Western Australian Liberal Party members?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the article which, I think, Senator Giles said was in the Daily News. Therefore, I do not know the truth or otherwise of the report and I cannot comment on that report. The Commonwealth Government's policies towards Aborigines are very well known. They are extremely enlightened. They are pace-setters. It was, in fact, the Fraser Liberal Government which acted to give land rights while others talked. Indeed, the pursuit of our policies in all directions towards Aborigines is enlightened and wholesome and is expressed in those policies which have been made here. I will look at the references and see whether there is any information which should be added.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Education, relates to community education centres. I have been informed that two of the four centres in Western Australia will no longer attract Commonwealth funds. I understand this follows a review that was held by the Schools Commission. I have serious reservations about the need for the Commonwealth to be involved in this area at all, but the two remaining centres at Geraldton and Fremantle are well run and perform useful functions. If other Western Australian centres are not established, will the Government consider allocating the $70,000 which will be saved by the withdrawal of funds from Derby and Albany to the two remaining centres?

—The Schools Commission sets guidelines which are used to determine whether particular institutions qualify for funding under different programs. I am not certain as to what is the status of the two community education centres which Senator Thomas says have had their funding continued or of the two which have had their funding removed. I am not at all certain that it is possible to promise the honourable senator that any saving from one centre which has had funding removed can be applied to another. I undertake to look at the matter, to examine why funding has been transferred or is being continued, as the case may be, and to advise him whether it is possible to accede in any way to the proposition he advances.

—My question, which is directed to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs, concerns passport control. Can the Minister confirm that Mr Peter Clyne, the prince of taxation evaders, is able to gorge himself on black forest cake in Vienna simply because he possesses an Australian passport? Are we going to withdraw that passport or is he travelling on a forged travel document?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I saw a reference to this gentleman in the Press this morning but I have not any information with regard to his passport. I will seek that information from the Department of Foreign Affairs.

—Is the Minister for Education aware that an agreement has been reached at the University of Tasmania in line with the Federal Government policy of voluntary unionism? Is he aware that the agreement enables students to pay a student service and activities fee, with no compulsion to join the students union? Can the Minister say how many other universities give this freedom to their students?

—I was interested to hear Senator Walters mention the agreement that has been reached. The honourable senator will be aware of the view that has been taken by my predecessors in the post of Minister for Education and in this place over a number of years. We have set out to establish a reasonable set of parameters within which membership of student unions by students can occur. The honourable senator will be aware of the efforts we have made to ensure that in the Australian Capital Territory, an area under this Government's control, there will be appropriate arrangements for membership of student unions. I would be grateful if the honourable senator could show me the agreement that has been reached in the University of Tasmania. It may be a very useful addition to what is emerging as an appropriate and sensitive national policy. I hope that most institutions in Australia will come to realise the advantages of having students belonging on a voluntary and ready basis to the unions on their campus.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It is related to a question asked yesterday by Senator Button. Will the Minister table papers presented to a meeting of Ministers before the 1977 Budget which was called to consider estimates of revenue for 1977-78? Were the papers in question prepared by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and by the Treasury? Do they show that the Treasury estimate, supported by the Commissioner of Taxation, was $1,000m less than that of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet? Was the Treasury estimate proved accurate? Why did the Cabinet accept the estimates of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet if it was not to deceive the electorate with income tax cuts which were withdrawn five months later?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The whole Parliament knows, if Senator Walsh does not, that all documents that come before the Cabinet and all records of discussions at Cabinet meetings, whether they be Budget Cabinet meetings or otherwise, are confidential documents and are not matters for tabling. So the answer to the question about tabling is: No, I will not do so. Secondly, I repeat what I said yesterday; that is, that in all Budget discussions a great deal of information comes from a wide number of sources and it is for the Cabinet to make its own decisions on that information. That has been the practice throughout all Cabinet meetings of all governments. I again recommend to Senator Walsh a re-reading of Mr Hayden's Budget Speech of 1975 in terms of promise and performance. The statements in that Budget Speech and the actual results are totally in conflict with each other.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations been drawn to the fact that Australia's wheat shipment program was 700,000 tonnes to one million tonnes behind schedule as a result of industrial disputes and problems in April, including the recently resolved tug dispute which set the shipping program back by 200,000 tonnes for the month? Does the Minister not agree that such a situation is damaging not only to Australia's economy but also to our reputation as a reliable trading partner? Can the Minister advise what action the Government is taking to ensure that such situations are not permitted to occur in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not have figures to confirm those put forward by Senator Bjelke-Petersen in her question as to the precise amount of delayed wheat tonnage which resulted from the disputation on the waterfront mentioned by her in the question. I shall seek those figures from the Minister. Concerning the second part of the question, I agree with her that this sort of delay to exports is damaging to Australia's economy and to our reputation as a reliable trading partner. It also needs to be said that it is damaging to every Australian, and that the standard of living of every Australian is ultimately affected by this sort of activity.

ANSWER.PARA: As to what action has been taken by the Government, the Government has shared the concern of the Australian community about the record of disputation on the waterfront over the last year or more. There has been an extended period in which a succession of disputes has occurred in different ports. One is treated to the spectacle of what is now known in New South Wales as Wran's Navy waiting outside Wollongong and Newcastle, and there have been problems in other States as well. It was because of those concerns that the previous Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Viner, raised that matter with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Stevedoring Industry Consultative Council and the National Labour Consultative Council, and there was a review and examination by the Government of the issues relating to improving industrial relations on the waterfront. The matter was raised at the Premiers Conference in February and there was an agreement at the Premiers level that this was a problem. The Premiers accepted an invitation to join the Commonwealth in discussing with employers and unions the means of improving industrial relations situations in these industries.

Comparatively recently there was a very large meeting in, I think, Senator Bjelke-Petersen's capital city, Brisbane, involving unions, States, employers and the Commonwealth. As a result of that meeting further work is being done. It was agreed that the ACTU and the Confederation of Australian Industry would review with their affiliates the effectiveness of existing consultative mechanisms, including dispute settling procedures in both industries, and report back prior to the next Premiers Conference in June. So the matter is getting active attention at government level and at the trade union and employer level. I think it is widely recognised that the sort of damaging effects that Senator Bjelke-Petersen mentioned are occurring, and if they continue to occur we shall wind up a much poorer country. Concerning the maritime industry, I simply remind the Senate that we have had the Crawford report and that there are negotiations with the maritime unions about the revitalisation of Australian shipping, which is an an ancillary area in which we must obviously improve our performance.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I refer the Minister to the large and growing degree of community support in Adelaide for the extension of ethnic television into South Australia. In particular, I refer the Minister to the support given to recent initiatives in this area by the Leader of the Australian Labor Party in South Australia, Mr John Bannon, and the belated support more recently given by the South Australian Premier to the proposal. Will the Minister comment on reports that the Australian Government has decided to defer the extension of ethnic television to South Australia? Is it a fact that the cost of the extension would be about $750,000, with a further annual expenditure of just over $200,000 being required to maintain the service? Finally, will the Government review its decision in the light of the community demand and the comparatively minimal costs involved?

—There is no doubt the the programs that have appeared already on this service in the cities in which they are screened have been very successful and that they are preferred viewing for many people in my own city.
—How many?

—They are regarded as very high quality programs, certainly within the Baume household. I often find that it has tuned into these programs because of their good quality. It is true that proposals have been put to the Minister which would allow for an extension of the service to other cities. There has been a proposal for extension to the Australian Capital Territory. The Minister has before him a number of options for extending the service. They are being examined by him. Any decisions that will be taken by the Government would have to be considered in the Budget context and the results of any decisions taken would be announced with the Budget on Budget night, in a month or two.

—My question of the Attorney-General concerns the Film Censorship Board. I refer to the newly released Australian film The Man from Snowy River-a marvellously Australian presentation of the lively and colourful themes of Banjo Paterson's original poem. I ask why this film has been classified 'Not Recommended for Children' when it can be and has been already of great enjoyment to children of all ages, including my own sons aged seven and four. I ask this question notwithstanding, indeed reinforcing, my continuing support for the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts on 'Children and Television'. Will the Minister urge the appropriate authorities to review the 'Not Recommended for Children' classification so that any unnecessary discouragement can be removed, to the benefit of the children of Australia and children in all the countries where the film will be shown?

—The classification 'Not Recommended for Children' is of course an advisory classification for parents. The classification indicates that the film may not be suitable for children under the age of 12. The basis of that decision of the Censorship Board, I am advised, was that there is occasional use of coarse language, a portrayal of a father's traumatic death, a graphic fight with the threat of a broken bottle, and some subtle sexual innuendos.
—Mainly involving horses.

—I find remarkable the sorts of responses one gets to serious matters from people here who are not called upon to make these judgments. There is a system of classification which is administered by a board of people who, as I have said on other occasions, have a very difficult job to do in making judgments. I believe the role of the Board is widely supported by the Australian community. If anybody is not satisfied with a decision of the Board there is a Films Board of Review. If the distributors were not satisfied with that classification they had the right to appeal to the Films Board of Review. I do not propose to interfere in these matters.

—I ask the Attorney-General a supplementary question. Will the Minister himself give consideration to urging a reclassification of the film? In asking that let me say that I do not think I am known as a violent revolutionary in these matters, but I do happen to feel that it is a very appropriate film for families in Australia, and not least the children of the age of my own sons.
—I will draw Senator Teague's comments to the attention of the Board, but I do not, as I have said, propose to interfere in these sorts of decisions.

—My question is directed to Senator Sir John Carrick in his capacity as Minister for National Development and Energy and as Minister representing the Prime Minister. Has the Government given consideration to the financing and construction of a new hydro-electric dam in Tasmania? If so, when did the Government reach a decision on this matter? Will the Minister give an assurance that finance for such a dam will be provided once the legislation has been passed through the Tasmanian Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that there has been no formal application by Tasmania to the Loan Council for funding-for either normal loan raisings or infrastructure financing. Therefore, the matter of power generation, whether by water power or by other means, has not come before the Government and the Government has not given consideration to it. I understand that in correspondence to certain senators, including Senator Chipp, the Prime Minister has made it clear that the Commonwealth has given no commitment as to its support. Whether the Tasmanian Government shall proceed with the proposed hydro- electric development in South-West Tasmania is a matter for decision by the Tasmanian Government. As stated previously by the Prime Minister in answers to questions on this subject, all States would object vigorously if the Commonwealth were to impose its decision-making on the normal programs of the States. These are matters for which the States must carry responsibility. The generation of electric power is a State matter entirely. The method of its generation is a State matter. There has been no approach to the Loan Council and , therefore, no Commonwealth consideration.

—I ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's answer , does the Commonwealth acknowledge no responsibilities in the light of the classification by the National Heritage Commission of South West Tasmania? Does the Commonwealth acknowledge no responsibilities in terms of the proper uses of resources throughout Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator asked two separate questions. The Commonwealth has certain environmental responsibilities. The Commonwealth had taken steps to declare the classification of the wilderness area. If there are environmental considerations the Commonwealth would have its appropriate responsibilities under review. The question of sovereignty of the States arises in relation to resources. The development of resources within the sovereignty of the States is entirely a matter for the States.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Health advise the Senate of figures on the incidence of endemic malaria in each of the States and Territories over the last recorded 12-month period, and if numbers have increased, to what extent? Can the Minister also advise whether the Government has statistics on how and from where the disease is being introduced and whether the Government carries any responsibility for assisting in the cost of treatment ?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The incidence of malaria in Australia is of some importance. Senator Kilgariff was kind enough to give me some advice. TALK.START.PARA: —There is a quite significant incidence of malaria in Australia. The table shows that approximately 500 cases a year are reported. One would wonder how we could have so many cases in this country. Malaria is not indigenous in Australia. The figures for 1981 show that all 500 cases were contracted overseas. The latest year for which we have complete figures-that is, 1981-shows a slight drop in the incidence. I think we have to be a bit cautious in order to be certain that this represents a trend and is not just a chance variation. It is not yet possible to present a complete analysis of the origin of each malaria case in 1981, but it seems that most cases originated in the Solomon Islands. Fewer cases were reported from South East Asia compared with the year before. There were very few cases from the other endemic area of Africa and Central America.

ANSWER.PARA: I think there are public health implications for these figures, particularly concerning the large number of cases that come to Australia from the Pacific Basin. I think State and Territory health services would want to look at the policies they apply as the responsibility for the provision of health services for the treatment of malaria is a matter for State and Territory services. They would want to know the source of the infection in order to choose the correct drugs and to take the appropriate public health response.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, follows on from the question asked by Senator Button regarding the possibility of funds being provided for the damming of the Franklin River in South West Tasmania. Does the Minister see any conflict with his answer to Senator Button and the repeated statement of Mr Gray, the Leader of the Liberal Party in Tasmania, that the Prime Minister had assured him that there would be no problem raising loan funds or getting infrastructure funds from the Commonwealth for such a project?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no knowledge of any such statement by Mr Gray; therefore, I cannot comment on it. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: BEEF INDUSTRY: BRUCELLOSIS AND TUBERCULOSIS ERADICATION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. I ask: Is the Minister aware of concern among beef producers, and in particular their charge concerning the potential loss of export markets, about the projected failure of the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign, due to increasing costs? Does the Government recognise the seriousness of these allegations? If so, how is it prepared to help?
—I will refer the honourable senator's question to the Minister for Primary Industry for consideration and reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask: Has the Minister seen the latest survey of manufacturing trends by the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Bank of New South Wales for the three months to March, which showed that 54 per cent of respondents expected the general business situation to decline, compared with 29 per cent in December and just 3 per cent in March 1981? Does this not indicate a massive collapse of confidence in the Fraser Government's economic policies and that any recovery in the economy is further away than ever?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have not seen the particular survey by the Bank of New South Wales but I believe that such an assumption, drawn from any statements which have arisen as a result of surveys, is not accurate. There are concerns, not only in Australia but also at a world level, about the likely growth of trade. Varying decisions need to be taken by those who are planning for the future. Investment confidence is still strong but undoubtedly many manufacturers will need to make certain decisions. Perhaps the most recent wage decision will have removed some of the doubts that many of them may have had with regard to planning for the future. What we want to see is a continuance of development, of job opportunities and, above all, of confidence in the strength of the Australian economy. To say that is not to ignore that difficulties exist for some-with regard to the financing of capital requirements and so on-but I believe that to draw the inference, as the honourable senator has done, that a massive lack of confidence exists does not represent accurately what is in the minds of those who are looking to develop and to continue manufacturing planning .

—I preface my question, which is directed to the Minister for Social Security, by noting that it was reported in the Mercury of 17 May that the Liberal Federal Council passed a motion by a Tasmanian delegate calling on the Government to re-examine the criteria for entitlement to the supporting parent's benefit on the ground that 15-year-old girls are getting pregnant as the best way of supporting themselves. I ask: How many 15-year-old girls in each State are in receipt of a supporting parent benefit?

—I believe that girls in that situation who were receiving a benefit would be receiving a special benefit. I will make inquiries and, if the figures requested by the honourable senator are currently available, will obtain them for her as soon as possible.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, relates to the position of ex-servicemen who received injuries from participation in mustard gas trials held in North Queensland during World War II . Those servicemen who were injured or suffered illness as a result of those trials may receive a disability pension but not a service pension, because they did not serve overseas in a theatre of war. I ask: Does the Minister consider that servicemen who were disabled in these hazardous trials are being financially disadvantaged, since all of their disability pension is deemed to be income for age pension eligibility, whereas only 40 per cent of a disability pension is so regarded in qualifying for a service pension? Will the Minister consider the possibility of granting a service pension to those ex-servicemen who were disabled due to the mustard gas trials? If not, does the Government have any other plans to overcome the financial disadvantages suffered by these ex-servicemen?

—It is important to recognise that the service pension was designed in the first place-it has been so for 50 years-to take account of the unrecognised effects of war. The disability pension was designed to compensate directly a serviceman for injuries he suffered as a result of war service. So it is well established that the disability pension payable to people in these circumstances is designed to compensate them for injuries having occurred as a result of exposure to mustard gas experiments. From that point of view, therefore, the question of a service pension does not necessarily arise. The question of eligibility, generally speaking, is a matter which is constantly being reviewed by the Government and will, of course, be taken into account in Budget discussions. On the specific point about the amount of disability pension being taken into account in assessing eligibility for the age pension, that, of course, is again related to Budget consideration and is something that the Government will no doubt consider later this year.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation to the announcement by Trans Australia Airlines that the Hobart-Christchurch service will now be only once a week except during summer. In view of this, and despite a spokesman for the Minister being quoted as saying that the project will not be reviewed, will the Government think again about proceeding with the construction of a separate international terminal at Hobart? Will it do the sensible thing and use the same funds to expand the existing domestic terminal in such a way that it can cater for the Hobart-Christchurch flights on those days on which they operate and allow for the extra space needed for domestic flights to cope with normal busy times such as Easter and other holiday periods when the airport is uncomfortably packed with people? Would the Government not prefer that the new space be wasted as little as possible?

—I am aware that there has been a withdrawal of service by TAA in respect of the Hobart-Christchurch route. Whether that changes the situation with regard to the airport, loads and volume of traffic is something about which I have no information. I think that all I can do in the circumstances is to refer Senator Coates's concerns to the Minister for Aviation and seek an early reply for him.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Did the Government Information Unit issue a promotional leaflet about the purchase of HMS Invincible on the day that the destroyer HMS Sheffield was reduced to a hulk by an Argentine missile? What was the cost of the promotional effort of the Unit in trying to make the purchase of the Invincible more palatable? What other publications are planned by the Government Information Unit to promote Liberal Party policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen printed information regarding HMS Invincible. I do not know whether it coincided with the time of the sinking of HMS Sheffield. I think one should read the information leaflet very carefully. The fact is that Invincible is a vessel designed to provide the most effective means of anti-submarine warfare detection that modern navies have in mind. The Invincible took part in North Atlantic tests some months ago and was commended by all navies concerned. The fact is that Invincible contains the type of helicopters that can operate what are called dunking or dipping sonars which can take soundings wide of all convoys and detect the presence of enemy submarines well ahead of any kind of threat to the convoys by submarines. Therefore, I think the Senate would regard it as important that there should be in Australia for the future, a great impetus to our detection ability in anti-submarine warfare. The fact is that the alternative is shore-based aircraft of the Orion type which do not have active sonobuoys; such aircraft use passive sonobuoys with a limited zone. The Invincible is not, in itself, a total capacity. Of course there must be support and protective systems. Of course the very nature of war is such that all vessels are vulnerable. It would help all honourable senators if they applied their minds to the general purpose of an anti-submarine war vessel, and particularly to the general purpose of dunking or active sonars which provide greater protection for convoys, particularly as Australia at any time of conflict would need massive convoy movements across the world and therefore protection.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: REVIEW OF COMMONWEALTH FUNCTIONS: DEPARTMENT OF ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES

Therefore, all I can do in those circumstances is to raise the matter with the Minister and ensure that I get an early answer for Senator Gietzelt.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. I preface my question with the information that Mr W. W. Sweetland has recently headed an inquiry into the long term future of Christmas Island. I am informed that a report has now been completed. Given the possible effects of the Government's fertiliser subsidy amendment legislation on the sale of Christmas Island rock, which is before the Senate at the moment, will the Minister give an undertaking that the report will be released immediately?

—The undertaking sought by the honourable senator is really one that can be given only by the Minister himself. It is proper that I refer the matter to the Minister whom I represent and seek an answer for Senator Macklin.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today Senator Robert Ray asked me a question about the Australian Consulate-General in Houston. The formal opening of the Consulate-General is to take place on 14 June. It is correct to say that Australia has Consulates-General in San Francisco, Los Angeles, Chicago and Honolulu. The decision to establish a Consulate-General in Houston took account of the growing importance of the southern area of the United States for Australia as a market and the potential it offered for further Australian exports. Other considerations include the requirement for consular assistance to Australians in this area of the United States and the growing demand for the provision of information about Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The decision to establish the Consulate-General in Houston was announced on 11 February. I had some concern about the announcement of the person who was to be appointed and I understand that announcement was to be made today. So I now advise that the new Consul-General in Houston is to be a Mr E. J. L. Ride, a senior career officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs. It is normal practice for Australian diplomatic and consular missions overseas to be under the charge of officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs. The functions of the office extend well beyond trade activities and the responsibilities of the Consul-General will be much wider than those of a trade commissioner.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — On 18 May Senator Sibraa asked me a question concerning the death of the Algerian Foreign Minister in a plane crash in northern Iran. I am advised by the Department of Foreign Affairs that the Algerian Government has instituted an inquiry into the crash but that no results of the inquiry are yet available. I should add that the Minister for Foreign Affairs sent a message to the new Algerian Foreign Minister, Mr Ibrahimi, expressing condolences on the death of Mr Benyahia and noting his contributions towards resolving international conflicts.

—Senator Teague asked me a question yesterday concerning a policy change which has allowed theological students access to the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme. I promised to get some particular information for him. Courses at five institutions have been approved for TEAS following the policy change. An estimated 50 theological students studying on a full time basis will qualify immediately for assistance under TEAS. Assistance will be back-dated to 1 January this year provided that the students make application as soon as possible. This is something we will try to take up. An estimated 380 students are enrolled in the five courses on a part time basis. It is possible that if those students transfer to full time study they would be eligible to apply for TEAS as from the date their application to transfer was received. I have the names of the five institutions which have been approved which I can make available to the honourable senator.

— Senator Keeffe asked me a question concerning a report on radio for Aboriginals in Central Australia. I note there has been some Press comment on this matter. The Minister for Communications and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs have recently received a report from the working party on Aboriginal broadcasting. That report has made recommendations on a number of options for extending Aboriginal broadcasting. These will be considered along with any additional proposals put forward by the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association for settlements in the vicinity of Alice Springs. The Government is aware that fears have been expressed about the possible effects on traditional Aboriginal culture and lifestyle of television and radio services made available through the domestic satellite after 1985. The Government agrees that radio services to Aboriginal communities in local language could provide an important avenue for preparing people for the arrival of the new services.

—Senator Macklin asked me a question concerning the cost savings which were anticipated following the Review of Commonwealth Functions decision on the Curriculum Development Centre. The decision was to seek joint funding from the States. Initially it was not a cost saving decision. At that stage it was not possible to forecast whether there would be savings or what those savings could be. It may have been possible, for example on the same output of Federal money, to double the program, if the States had contributed. It was not undertaken in the sense of just a cost cutting exercise and I cannot give the honourable senator the information which he sought.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Bradshaw, will be accompanying me to a conference in Sydney next week, I take this opportunity of informing honourable senators that he will be retiring as Clerk of the Senate during the winter recess. Today is the last day on which he will be serving in this chamber in his capacity as Clerk of the Senate. Mr Bradshaw served in the Royal Australian Air Force in England during the war. After study in the post-war period, he joined the Senate in July 1950 as Clerk of Papers and Accountant. He served as Private Secretary to the President of the Senate during 1953 and 1954, as Clerk of Records in 1954 and 1955 and as Ministerial Liaison Officer during 1955 and 1956. He then became Usher of the Black Rod and served in that capacity from 1956 to 1964-a quite extensive period. In 1964 he was promoted to Principal Parliamentary Officer and in 1965 to Clerk-Assistant. In 1973 he became First Clerk-Assistant. In 1979 he became Deputy Clerk of the Senate and since October 1980 he has served as Clerk.

INTERJECT.PARA: During his service he has been involved in many other aspects of the working of the Senate. He was Secretary to the Joint Committee on Constitutional Review from 1956 to 1959 and Secretary to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence from 1959 to 1965. He was also Secretary to one of the very early Senate select committees-the Senate Select Committee on the Encouragement of Australian Productions for Television-during 1962 and 1963. The Deputy President, the Honourable Douglas McClelland, served on that Committee with Mr Bradshaw. Mr Bradshaw also served as Secretary to the Senate Select Committee on Off-Shore Petroleum Resources. Three Presidents served on that Committee with Mr Bradshaw- the Honourable Justin O'Byrne, Sir Condor Laucke and, of course, myself. I do not know whether there is any significance in that or whether Mr Bradshaw should be commended or otherwise. I will leave that to the judgment of honourable senators. Mr Bradshaw was also Secretary to the Australian Inter-Parliamentary Union delegations to meetings in Canberra, Tehran, Bucharest and Tokyo. He also accompanied the previous President of the Senate to the 250th anniversary of the Parliament in the Bahamas, as well as on official visits to Japan and China.

Altogether Mr Bradshaw has served for some 32 years in this chamber. During that time he has seen many changes take place and has made a great contribution not only to the Senate but also to the Australian parliamentary institution itself. On a personal note, I thank him very much for the kindness he has extended to me since I became President of this chamber. I have leant heavily on him and other advisers in this place. There is no doubt that during his period of service he has made many friends, both senators and staff. Some of them have left this place but many of them still serve here. He has a very gentle and friendly manner and one which attracts people to him. The Deputy President, Senator Douglas McClelland, is not present today, but he has asked to join me in extending to Mr Bradshaw and his wife all the very best for the future and in thanking him very much for what he has done for this chamber. We wish Mr Bradshaw and Mrs Bradshaw well in his retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, on the occasion of the retirement of Keith Oscar Bradshaw from the position of Clerk of the Senate, the Senate places on record its appreciation of the long and valuable service rendered by him to the Commonwealth Parliament, and conveys to him good wishes for many happy years of retirement.

Those officers who, like Keith Bradshaw, serve this Senate, and serve it very well, have a unique place in this Parliament of the Commonwealth and in this unique chamber, the Senate. By their devotion, by their skills and by their association with honourable senators they shape the evolution of this institution. They ensure that it conforms with its administrative goals and its Standing Orders and they help with the evolution of the institution as a human institution and they help to develop its character and, above all, its integrity . It is no mean thing for a person to proceed through the various offices of the Senate and come to the very high office of Clerk of the Senate. It is a distinguished office and an office of very great significance and importance. Keith Bradshaw has had some very distinguished predecessors and he walks amongst them as a peer. He walks as one who has in his journey given to this Senate not only his qualities of experience and knowledge but also the qualities of a very warm and human personality, a kind and gentle person, exercising his authority with the gentleness of strength and therefore adding much to the ease of our journeys.

I regret that he has found it necessary to make this decision to retire. On behalf of us all, I thank him very much indeed for the great contribution he has made here, for the warmth of his friendship with us all, for his objectivity in discharging his duties, for his tolerance-sometimes we are truant children-and for the contribution he has made to the evolution of the system. We wish him full strength of health, happiness and enjoyment of life for many long years to come. We express our thanks to his wife, Sylvia, and his family for supporting him in his journey. We understand the sacrifices that she must make as the wife of a Clerk because of the long hours he spends here. We extend our warm wishes to her. We are very proud to have had Keith Bradshaw as our associate. We are the better for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion which has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick). I associate myself with all the remarks which he made about Mr Bradshaw. But when he describes senators as truant children I would like to feel that he speaks for himself rather than me. This is the first occasion on which, in a long period of association with Mr Bradshaw, it has come to my attention that he was a wireless operator during the war. Had I known that earlier I would have sought his advice about a variety of communications matters in addition to the other advice which I have sought from him over the time that I have been in the Senate. I do not think I can really add anything more except to say that this is a somewhat hectic place; perhaps that is another way of putting what Senator Sir John Carrick was trying to put with the figure of speech he used. It is important, in a parliament like this, that the work of the place is facilitated as much as possible by those who are here permanently and not subject to the fortunes applicable to politicians, who Arthur Calwell described as roosters today and feather dusters tomorrow. It is very important that the continuity of the Parliament be kept going by people of the calibre of Keith Bradshaw. I put on record our party's appreciation of his work in that role and our party's best wishes to him and Mrs Bradshaw for a long and happy retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —On my own behalf and on behalf of my party I support the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick), which was seconded by Senator Button. It expresses appreciation for the 32 years of service by Keith Bradshaw to this chamber and, indeed, to this Parliament. It is a happy occasion when one can express appreciation to someone such as Keith Bradshaw and wish him well, knowing that he is so obviously fit and will be around for many years to come. One would always prefer that sort of circumstance , but does not often find it.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had some experience as Deputy President and for a short period as an Acting President. In those positions I became aware of the great contribution that Keith Bradshaw made in his quiet and efficient way. I express my personal thanks to him for the help he has given to me, and I am sure to all honourable senators, over the long period of his association with the Senate. Keith Bradshaw has always been very accurate in his advice and very courteous in his manner of delivering it. On my own behalf and on behalf of my party, I wish him good health and good luck and say: Thank you for that long period of service you have given to us in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the Australian Democrats in the tribute to Keith Bradshaw. It is interesting to reflect that more than 30 years of service is a long time. As I recall, Keith Bradshaw was Usher of the Black Rod when I joined the Parliament in about 1961. He was a young, callow youth then, as I was.
—As all Black Rods are.

—Yes. I notice with interest that Mr Bradshaw was in air crew about the same time I was. No doubt he strutted down the streets of Broken Hill with that little white peak in his cap, cutting a handsome, striking figure in 1942 when he went on leave. No doubt his hair was a little thicker then and not quite as grey as it is now, but still he cuts a handsome, striking figure as he parades in this place in his gown and wig.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats have had nothing but friendship, co-operation and non- partisanship from Mr Bradshaw and his assistants. My contribution to the tributes made by the other three speakers perhaps follows a different turn but is just as sincere. One of the matters that goes to Keith Bradshaw's credit is revealed in an examination of the calibre of the people who surround him, whom he has appointed, whom he has nurtured and who have stuck to their jobs in the Department of the Senate. Although we will miss him on his departure we know that his place will be filled by a person of great competence. As each person moves up the rung we are happy in the knowledge that each of those persons is a competent, trustworthy and non-partisan officer of the Senate who has been encouraged and nurtured by people such as Keith Bradshaw. That compliment refers to not only the people in direct line of succession to Keith Bradshaw but also all of the staff of the Senate, both male and female. They reflect credit to Keith Bradshaw. We wish him and his wife well in his well-deserved retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I associate myself with the sentiments expressed and thank Keith Bradshaw for the very wise advice that he has offered me since my election to the Senate in 1975. I also thank him for the assistance that he has offered me. I note, as did Senator Button, for the first time that Keith was a wireless operator in an air crew. I imagine that he was adept at morse code. I know he would need in this chamber the anticipation that that job sometimes requires, for example, especially with the tic-tacking that used to go on between himself and Acting Presidents from time to time. I believe he holds the record of being the last clerk of a Senate committee to have travelled by ship to Western Australia. That may have given him an introduction to the laws of the sea which he would have found handy in his position as secretary to the Senate Select Committee on Off-Shore Petroleum Resources, to which Mr President referred.

SPEECH.PARA: Incidentally, Mr President, I notice that you referred to three Presidents having served on that Committee. There is only one honourable senator remaining to become President who served on that Committee. I hesitate to mention his name , but it is Senator Keeffe. I believe it cannot be stressed enough how much people in the community regard the work done on that Committee. Indeed before election to the Senate I had cause to come across a number of people who had been very interested in the work of that Committee. That Committee took a number of years on its inquiry and occupied, I think, five years of Keith's career. The Committee's report is a living testimony to the industriousness and effort which Keith Bradshaw puts into the tasks which he has been given. Mr President, you, as Chairman of that Committee, would be well aware of the efforts of Keith Bradshaw. You have referred to them in your address to the Parliament today. The Committee undertook its task without the benefit of large resources and its achievement contrasts more than favourably with the royal commission into the same subject area. Indeed, the report of the Committee, for which much credit must be given to its Secretary, Keith Bradshaw, is even today regarded as a textbook on the legislation within the industry.

Mr President, I know that you and other honourable senators know that Keith is held in high regard amongst the staff and other people who work in this building . It came as a great shock to me to learn only last week that Keith was going to retire and I think it is a great pity. I am sorry that he is unable to continue as Clerk of the Senate. He is a man of great courtesy, even-handedness and propriety in his dealings with senators from both sides of the Parliament. He has been an integral part of this Parliament and he will certainly be missed. I join my colleagues in wishing him and his wife a very happy and long retirement.
Honourable senators-Hear, hear!
