DEBATE.TITLE: THIRD UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE LAW OF THE SEA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report is largely now, it must be conceded, of historical interest as it relates to the tenth session of the Law of the Sea Conference which ended over a year ago on 24 April 1981. The Convention on the Law of the Sea was, of course, adopted in New York on 30 April 1982 at the end of the eleventh session of the Conference just a few weeks ago. We look forward to seeing the report of the Australian delegation to that final and all-important session and hope that we will not have to wait a year to receive it.

The particular interest in this tenth report lies in the account it gives of the devastating impact of the Reagan Government's sudden announcement at the opening of this tenth session that a fundamental review of United States policy in relation to the proposed convention had been ordered. It is now a matter of record that, when the convention was finally adopted, the United States was one of four countries, in company with Turkey, Venezuela and Israel, which voted against the convention in April this year. One hundred and thirty countries, Australia included, voted in favour of it. Seventeen countries, including, amongst others, Brisbane-I mean Britain; but it would be absolutely typical of the dog in the manger attitude adopted by that particular administration in this country, although it has not yet assumed international status-Britain, Germany and the Soviet Union, abstained from the convention. It is, accordingly, I think interesting given that final outcome, to note the report of the Australian delegation, politely expressed but certainly devastating in its effect, which appears on page 8 of the report. It is in the following terms:

The announcement of the United States review of its policy caused considerable consternation and disenchantment among delegations, most of whom had believed that they were assembling for a final negotiating session. For many delegations the decision was a baffling and disquieting one, since many of the provisions in the Draft Convention reflected the results of protracted negotiations involving concessions on points to meet particular concerns of the United States Delegation. In these circumstances many delegations were prompted to speculate whether the reasons for the United States decision were more fundamental than the original public announcement might have led them to believe.
In any event, the United States Government's announcement was nothing short of ruinous to the session to which this report relates. At page 9 the report states :

. . . the efforts of the Conference to continue working more or less as normal were doomed to frustration. It proved impossible to have serious discussions on all but a relatively small range of issues.

The serious roadblock, as it is referred to in the report, feared by delegates of course became an ever greater reality as the following year developed. Ultimately years of work towards consensus-we should note that the formal sessions in relation to this go all the way back to 1974-were destroyed by the self-interest of the United States which ultimately undermines the capacity of the United Nations to perform the role that so many of us are anxious for it to be able to do. The objections of the United States related to some extent to the procedural amending provisions of the proposed Law of the Sea Treaty but more essentially, and centrally, to the compulsory transfer of deep sea bed mining technology from private corporations to the proposed new United Nations Deep Sea Bed Mining Authority. For obvious reasons of commercial self-interest in relation to the corporations involved and the private sector interests involved, the United States, under the new Reagan Government, went to bat right to the last hurdle for the protection, as it perceived it, of those interests and in the process destroyed a consensus which had been evolving for eight years. There were undoubtedly important Third World implications for the United States in the course of the action that thus occurred. There is no doubt that the existing Law of the Sea, which it has been the purpose of this whole process to revise and make the subject of an international convention, has been operating in such a way as to disadvantage spectacularly the developing countries. The report notes on page 1:

The Conference came about because of the conviction of many States that the traditional Law of the Sea was inequitable in that it advantaged the developed countries and disadvantaged the developing countries and was outmoded because it had permitted the exhaustion of fishing grounds throughout the world and did not satisfactorily equip coastal States to protect the marine environment off the shores.

It is clear that the failure of the United States to come into this proposed treaty will have profound practical implications, at least in the short run, for the effectiveness of the new international order created by it. Undoubtedly there will be a delay in the establishment of the international sea bed authority which is to supervise deep sea bed mining. The United States and the Soviet Union were both to contribute a very large section of that body's budget and if the two nations are not party to the treaty-the Soviet Union is clearly maintaining its abstention role until such time as the United States comes in- the budgetary strains on the other countries will of course be very much greater and there may as a result be a decision to adopt a much slower course in setting up the authority than might otherwise have been the case.

There are nonetheless some grounds for supposing that the resistance of the United States to endorsing and participating in this treaty may not be permanent . It is not because of any likely change of heart or any prospect of greater sensitivity emerging in the breast of the Reagan Administration. That would be far too much to hope for. Rather, it is a question of being likely that the United States will realise that it is in its own ultimate interest to join in this international treaty arrangement. It has become clear that Japan, which has been a very active supporter of the treaty-a signatory of it or, at least, a voter for it-along with several other nations working on the development of the expensive sea bed technology, can be expected to take advantage of the United States absence and will put considerable pressure on the United States eventually to come in and participate in the treaty. It is clear that the operation of sea bed mining under the treaty regime will ultimately be perceived by the United States and the commercial authorities and interests to which it has so far bowed as being in the interests of the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would not the advent of the Democrats coming back to power at the White House bring about what you are stating?

—There is no question but that the resumption of a Democrat regime in the United States, which would also be a more democratic regime, would accelerate that process. But I think Senator Mulvihill would be the first to appreciate that the forces of capitalist private enterprise in the United States are exceedingly strong and it is not to be assumed that any administration would be capable of resistance. But the whole course of events until the Reagan Administration came to office is such as to suggest that a Democrat administration would support this.
—The vision of Roosevelt is needed.

—Indeed-the vision of a Roosevelt and the courage of a Mulvihill. My final point is simply that there are inequities and disadvantages for other countries until such time as we can develop this regime. There is a need for a sharing, co-operative internationalist approach to these issues, not the parochialism nor, indeed, the very old fashioned economic imperialism which has been associated with the United States attitude. This is one area, at least, in which there is a substantial degree of bipartisan solidarity between the parties . We agree very strongly with the points made by the Foreign Minister, Mr Street , when he spoke on this issue in the House of Representatives on 4 May. We are disappointed, to put it at its mildest, with the United States reaction to these events so far and we look forward to the United States reconsidering its position. Certainly it will not be appreciated around the world, and its position will not be appreciated in Australia, so long as its intransigence is maintained.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report on the Housing Assistance Act is one of the obligations to the Parliament and arises from the legislation which deals with the Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement. The objectives of the 1976 agreement were to facilitate home ownership for those able to afford it but not able to gain it through the private market and to provide adequate rental housing for those in the community who are deemed to be in need of governmental assistance at a price that is within their capacity to pay. The agreement, therefore, provides for two programs. Firstly, it provides for a home purchase assistance program, which assists those persons wishing to buy a home who are unable to obtain mortgage finance through the private market or any other sources. It must be admitted that that is a growing number of people in today's very tight economic conditions. Secondly, it provides for a rental housing assistance program which provides rental accommodation for those most in need of rental housing assistance. With the increasing mobility of our work force today, we need more and more rental housing, particularly public rental housing, to provide for those persons.

The Commonwealth provides advances to the States to meet those purposes. Of course, the funding in 1980-81 shows that the Commonwealth Government is failing very dismally in its obligations and responsibilities. The table on page 5 shows that Commonwealth advances to the States for the past two years have fallen alarmingly. It is particularly important for the Senate to note that no rental housing assistance at all is given to Queensland. One would expect the Government members to be interested in that fact, but they remain silent. There has been an increase in dollar terms in total advances to New South Wales, my State, of only $2,138,000, which is a drop in real terms of 8.3 per cent. There has been a drop in total advances to all the States of some 7.7 per cent in real terms.

The effect of the Government's policies has been particularly bad for public housing in the States and of course that is why all State housing commissions and housing Ministers have been critical of the Commonwealth Government's abdication of its responsibilities in this matter. For example, the New South Wales Housing Commission is reported to be running out of money in the present quarter. It cannot keep up with the increasing demand for public housing. An article in the Australian Financial Review of 27 March stated:
In 1976-77 Commonwealth loans and grants for public housing in New South Wales totalled $103 million. By 1980-81 this figure had fallen to $69 million.
That was in a period when the consumer price increase had gone up by more than 50 per cent. The article, reporting the Chairman of the Housing Commission, stated:

It was clear that high costs of land and housing, high rentals and very difficult conditions in the finance sector generally were continuing to confront homeseekers with a difficult situation, a scenario which suggested a continuation of the trend for levels of public housing demand to increase.

And of course that is exactly what has happened. Total funds for home purchase assistance under the Agreement have been reduced by $11,321,000 in the year under review and this neglect has had a bad effect upon the construction industry generally. For example, home building approvals have slumped to a seven -year low, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for January 1980. This means that since this Government came to office it has brought about a serious decline in the home building industry. The Commonwealth should be using the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement to stimulate the housing industry and therefore stimulate the Australian economy but of course it pursues its own ideological and philosophical position in the belief that the buck spent in the government sector is somehow different from the buck that is spent in the private sector.

Government finance for rental assistance has been increased only marginally in the same period. I raised this matter in the Senate on 11 March this year. Time will not permit me to deal with all the details except to say that a 72 per cent cutback in Commonwealth funds since 1975 will have the inevitable result-it is very clear, particularly in New South Wales-of forcing up rents. The Government' s current housing policies do nothing to redress the problems in housing and certainly do nothing other than give emphasis to increased rents.

Interest rate increases have recently been announced and we are led to believe that another increase in interest rates will soon take place. The new housing assistance scheme which this Government announced recently will do very little to alleviate the problem. As my colleague, the Opposition spokesman on housing, Tom Uren, said, the housing scheme announced in March is nothing more than a gimmick and a sop to the wealthy and it will do very little to assist the very sections of the Australian community that need assistance. The home buyers who need assistance will not be guaranteed any assistance under the Government's latest policy. So that housing scheme will really be giving $74m to assist the very wealthy, the only group of people who can get into the housing scene in today's environment.

If we compare the home purchase assistance figures for 1979-80 and 1980-81 we can see that there has been an increase of only $0.3m for New South Wales. This represents a drop of 6 per cent in real terms for last year. Victoria and Queensland both experienced a drop in dollar terms, which means massive cuts in real terms so far as their capacity to provide public housing is concerned. Overall one has to say that statistically the report provides us with basic information which shows that the Commonwealth is abdicating its responsibilities in this area. No matter which State we look at we will find a situation in which the responsible Minister, regardless of his political complexion, is critical of the severe cutbacks that have occurred in the provision of Commonwealth funds to the States for housing. A very interesting article which appeared in the Bulletin of 30 March this year states:

Next year's housing issue will be ''the rental crisis''. The government knows this and as part of its package last week provided $20 million for housing crisis assistance. The Commonwealth expects the States to match this on a dollar -for-dollar basis.

Considering that the ''rental lobby'' has been barely heard in Canberra, this looks at first glance to be an act of rare compassion on the part of the government. Rather it should be seen as recognition of a very difficult problem.

The article went on to show that in 1975-76 132,000 houses were built in Australia. Five years later, in 1980-81, that figure had increased by only 2,000 to 134,000. This has occurred at a time when our population is growing and we are stimulating our immigration policies and bringing more than 100,000 people into Australia each year. All of this compounds the problem and adds to the demand situation in our housing industry. If we do not meet the supply side, prices in the private and public sectors are inevitably forced up and the States are forced to increase the rents which they charge for their housing commission homes. Of course, in the private rental market we have seen rentals increase by at least 50 per cent over the last couple of years. The Commonwealth Government, as this report indicates, is failing to recognise its responsibilities in this area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The 1980-81 annual report of the Australian Federal Police is a most welcome document for those of us who are concerned about the state of policing in the Australian Capital Territory and areas under Commonwealth jurisdiction. The report is welcome, firstly, because it is a far more expansive review than last year's report of the activities of the Australian Federal Police and it affords us an opportunity to look at the amalgamation of the Commonwealth Police and the Australian Capital Territory Police which was agreed to on 19 October 1979 and which is in its third year of operation. Secondly, the report is welcome because it is much more candid than the previous report.

The Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, Sir Colin Woods, made some remarks in the report, particularly in the introduction, which give us some-I must emphasise 'some'-insight into the vast problems faced by the Australian Federal Police. Sir Colin's comments give us some idea of the problems, but this is not really sufficient. As I have said on several occasions, I believe there is a need for a substantial review of the activities and functions of the Australian Federal Police. There is a need for soul-searching and a shake-up. One can only say that the current Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) has failed miserably, as did his predecessors, to put into effect the essential leadership needed to bring about an effective amalgamation and an effective police organisation to carry out the functions as determined by the Commonwealth Parliament.

Let me be a little more specific about those matters. The Minister for Administrative Services informed the Commissioner of the new charter for the Federal Police in November of last year. That charter is shown in appendix A to the report. The Opposition has no quibble with that, because it believes that there is an increasing need and role for the Australian Federal Police. The major priorities are identified as the investigation of crimes under Commonwealth law, the policing of the Australian Capital Territory, an emphasis on combating drug-related and organised crime and, of course, fraud. It must be said that such are the lack of resources and the discontent within the Australian Federal Police that in respect of Medibank frauds, for example, resources are so stretched that the organisation is able to look at manipulation and misappropriation State by State only; it cannot conduct a total review of the wholesale, improper practices by the medical profession that from time to time have been brought to light in respect of Medibank. One is aware that drug trafficking constitutes a major and growing problem for the Australian community , also that organised crime is growing in importance and significance. The Australian Federal Police is not able effectively to play its part in combating these problems.

The Opposition supports the emphasis that Sir Colin Woods places on these matters. Honourable senators will be aware that in both the House of Representatives and in this place the current royal commissions and the problems of the State police forces have been discussed. So often what is wrong in New South Wales is highlighted, but similar problems exist in other States. There is conflict and competition between the State police forces and our new Australian Federal Police.

We believe that the problem with the charter lies in its unrealistic expectations. The Commonwealth Police Officers Association has called these guidelines 'fine but misleading'. The Secretary of that Association has said:

What is the use of extending tasks and responsibilities without an increase in staff? The resources of the A.F.P. are already stretched to such an extent that the force won't be able to carry out some of the functions outlined by the Minister.
The journal of the Association recently editorialised in regard to this matter in these terms:
One often wonders how our organisation--
That is, the Australian Federal Police-

and as a consequence our Commissioner manages to function with the manipulation of funding that appears to occur each and every year. We regularly seem to run out of money for one thing or another part way through the financial year. On the one hand we have the acceptance of particular functions by the Government and on the other a cut-back in the finance that would enable us to carry out such activities. (A true catch 22 situation).

I have already referred to the complaints about the staffing levels of the organisation. For example, I am led to believe that in Canberra the effective establishment for detectives, as indeed for the men on the beat, has declined by about one-third. On the other hand, I am led to believe that at the Governor- General's residence there are five protective guards. I wonder what sort of police organisation we have when that sort of emphasis occurs at the Governor- General's residence and fewer police are on the beat in the streets of Canberra itself. According to figures given at a Senate Estimates Committee C hearing last year, there has been an actual reduction in staffing, particularly in the junior ranks, in both the general policing and protective services components of the force. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the figures shown in the report.
