TALK.START.PARA: —According to the 1981 report of the Australia Federal Police, a major review of the functional divisions, staffing and rank numbers requirements was conducted. This review confirmed what the men and women in the force have been saying for some time-that the general policing duties component is insufficiently staffed. Therefore the general duties component has been increased by 748 ranks as from 31 December 1981. The report does not make clear, however, that those extra positions will be taken from the other component of the force, the protective services component. Of course, that is a major bone of contention. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The corresponding Protective Service officer ranks were not abolished at the time the general duties ranks were created as it was necessary to develop a program for that progressive transfer of officers of that component, after appropriate training, to the General Police Component.

Therefore, the total numbers of staff in the Australian Federal Police will be increased only marginally. That, of course, will have a disastrous effect upon the morale, activities and efficiency of the force.

In the few moments that are left to me I raise a matter which Sir Colin Woods has described as a minor indiscretion, that is, the giving of a security clearance, a character reference, to a Greek restaurant owner in Canberra which was subsequently found to be so deficient that the Commissioner as well as the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs saw fit to make changes to the recommendations. I am not concerned about the disciplinary action that was taken or the suggestions that there had been an indiscretion. Sir Colin Woods said that the officer concerned, then acting Assistant Commissioner Antill, was transferred to Queensland not because of the indiscretion. Mr Kennedy, the officer above him, was primarily responsible. Mr Kennedy has now been transferred to a different department. I raise this matter not to seek some sort of a witch hunt or persecution of the officers but to indicate the unsatisfactory way in which the Australian Federal Police force is operating. The evidence is abundantly clear that there is an unsatisfactory staff situation .

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

A discussion took place at the meeting which was held in Adelaide on 8 February about the inquiry of the Industries Assistance Commission into the canned fruit industry about which I am very interested. It is of vital importance to the Riverland area of South Australia. The cannery is in the hands of the receivers. This is causing a lot of worry to not only the growers and the people who derive their livelihood from working in the cannery but also the small business people who derive their livelihood in a round about way from the incomes of fruit growers and from the wages from the people who work in the cannery.

I am disturbed to find that the annual report of the Australian Canned Fruits Sale Promotion Committee will not be available to the Senate today. It is very important that we can speak on that paper. The interim report by the IAC on the canning fruit industry is referred to in the document about which I am speaking. Although it has been published and will be tabled here today we will not be able to speak to it today because we are not aware of the recommendations in respect of the canning fruit industry in Australia. That places undue restrictions on senators who may wish to make some remarks about what the IAC has recommended in respect of that industry. Whilst I can talk about that report here because it is mentioned in the report of the Australian Agricultural Council, we are prevented from having any discussions on the recommendations of the IAC report. This should not be so. We have spoken about this matter before when papers have been tabled in this Parliament without senators having a prior opportunity to see their contents. All that an honourable senator can do is move that the Senate take note of the report and then seek leave to continue his or her remarks so that it will be on the Notice Paper and be debated at some future date. As I pointed out here a couple of weeks ago, some reports had been tabled in the Parliament 12 or 18 months prior to them coming on for debate. They are well out of date when we get the opportunity to debate them.

There are many other matters about which I would like to talk. One concerns live sheep exports and a study mission which went to the Middle East, but I will not talk about that because my colleague Senator Childs will deal with that matter in some detail. It is the next matter on my list for consideration. Another matter is the commercialisation of rabbits. We well remember the long discussions that have taken place in Australia. I think at one time a senator tried to establish a rabbit farm in New South Wales. He was not able to do that and he had to go to South Africa, I think, or America, to establish his rabbit farm.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oregon, in the United States.

—Senator Peter Baume tells me that it was in Oregon. Being a strong supporter of rural industries, I would not support in any way the commercialisation of rabbit production in Australia. That industry could become a competitor with many of our established industries, particularly the poultry industry which endeavours to sell white meats. I refer to cull hens, for which there is a very limited market. There is a big market for broilers. Not only would the commercialisation of the production of rabbits threaten the limited markets now available but also there would be the danger that these very large rabbits would escape and not succumb to myxomatosis. They might be immune to it. We would then have another rabbit plague which in turn would create havoc in pastoral industries.
—Some have got out already.

—We know there are a few rabbits about; as Senator Sibraa says, some have already got out. However, they are not mentioned in this report. Many other matters need some looking at in detail but I do not intend to do that today. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN SHEEP MEAT STUDY MISSION TO THE MIDDLE EAST

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
This mission was sponsored by the Government to overcome the disputes that have occurred and which are still occurring over this issue. The objectives of the mission are significant. They are:

To report to the Australian Government on the Middle East market for sheep, sheep meat and alternate meats. To identify opportunities for expanding demand in the area for Australian mutton. To make recommendations on any special market development or promotional assistance measures which could help to exploit the market opportunities which are identified.

Those objectives are very important. It is important then to examine the major importers of live sheep in 1981. We find that Saudi Arabia imported 2,008,000 live sheep, Kuwait 1,540,000 live sheep and Libya 794,000 live sheep. Australia dominates the world trade. For example, Kuwait imports 96 per cent of its live sheep from Australia.

It is worth while examining this matter because the major shipper to Kuwait is the Kuwait Livestock Transport and Trading Co. It is run by two of the ruling families of Kuwait, so the company is subsidised by interest free loans and cheap fuel oil which is readily available in Kuwait. We assist this trade by supplying cheap water and feed from Australia. The Kuwaiti Government gives a subsidy for live sheep and then another subsidy goes to butchers in Kuwait. That is the position. They are the advantages enjoyed by the live sheep trade.

Against that we have the claim by the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union that there should be an increase in frozen or chilled meat going to these countries. The Kuwait Livestock Transport and Trading Co., which dominates the market there, claims that the Moslem Hal-al method of slaughter cannot be complied with in Australia. Of course that is not true. It also claims that the consumer preference is for live sheep. It does this to scare people away from meat slaughtered in Australia. The reason for the subsidy is understandable, but it is to the disadvantage of employment in Australia.

I contrast that situation with the position in Iran. A change has taken place because of the war waged there. Iran used to be the largest importer of live sheep and all the arguments about preference for meat not to be processed here used to be trotted out. Last year Iran imported 715,000 sheep compared with 2.5 million sheep in 1977-78. Last year, 24,000 tonnes of frozen mutton went to Iran from Australia, and 92,000 tonnes of fresh lamb went from New Zealand. This substitution of carcass meat for live sheep in Iran, due to port congestion and cash problems, gives the lie to the claim that people in these countries cannot make a change. It gives the lie to the suggestion that consumer preference is such that these people will not take carcasses instead of live sheep.

It is also alleged that these people might go elsewhere. This is a fallacious argument. Australian meats take 16 days to get to the Middle East. North Africa can get it there within 10 hours; and sheep from Turkey takes only two or three days. South America could only supply the market for half a year; they are and will always be minor suppliers of the market. The European countries do not have flocks sufficient to supply the market. On the other hand, New Zealand has taken a principled stand and refuses to export live sheep. It has not suffered because of that decision.

The consequences of this development for employment in Australia are very serious. Over the past five years the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union has lost approximately 10,000 members. Its membership has reduced from 55,000 to 45,000 workers. It is a very serious situation for rural Australia when we consider the accumulator effect on employment which country abattoirs have in the areas in which they are situated. When we consider that only half of the sheep goes in meat and the other half goes into products such as hides, bone meal, sausage cases and fertiliser, we can appreciate that the meat processing industry is being lost to our country and half the industry is being ignored by Government policies. New Zealand was told seven years ago that it had to sell live sheep. It has resisted doing so and it has been successful in improving its exports despite the threats which it did not cave in to.

I want to refer briefly to a particular section of the report. When the members of the mission concluded their work in the Middle East they stopped over in Singapore. The purpose of that stopover was to review the mission and to prepare recommendations. These recommendations, along with others received, gained unanimous support. Following the mission's arrival back in Australia arrangements were made in Canberra for discussions with the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon). The purpose of the meeting was to acquaint the Minister with the recommendations. After reading the recommendations the Minister advised the mission that he could accept all the recommendations except the second one. That second recommendation is significant. The second recommendation, in a draft dated April this year, was as follows:
That the Australian Government in consultation with interested industry bodies investigate the feasibility of a scheme having the following features

a tax on the export of live sheep for slaughter to be levied on the exporter, the amount of tax being determined periodically by reference to the difference between the prices of sheep for export and for slaughter in Australia--
It continued-
the proceeds of the export tax to be used to facilitate the export of mutton and hoggett to the markets which import live sheep for slaughter

The Minister claimed that this recommendation would conflict with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. He said that the mission should re-write this recommendation. The following day members of the mission, after lengthy deliberations, decided that the recommendation should remain except for the deletion of the reference to a guaranteed price for sheep. The mission decided that the recommendation should be referred to the bureaucracy so that the reservations expressed by the Minister could be checked. However, it was to be returned to the Minister as an addendum to the formal list of recommendations. The suggestion that the second recommendation to which I have referred is in conflict with GATT must be considered doubtful. The countries concerned are not signatories to GATT and even if they were they are also members of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries which manipulates the world price of oil, even to the point of controlling supply.

I think that the report in itself is a tremendous step forward. It shows that when people in the industry examine a concrete problem they are capable of seeking solutions. It also, of course, is the basis for possible agreement. I think unfortunately it has the weakness that it does not go to the point of the very significant submissions by the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union which realises that it is vital in rural Australia that employment is given to people in the meat industry. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that at long last the Government and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) are endeavouring to come to grips with the problem which has beset this country, particularly some export ports, because of the dramatic increase in the export of live sheep. I think that the Minister and all those involved in the Australian Sheep Meat Study Mission to the Middle East, including members of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, are to be congratulated for undertaking that task, for bringing back to Australia knowledge of what they saw and heard and for presenting it in a report such as this. I note that in the introduction of the report it is stated that the matter has been a contentious issue. Living where I do, I am fully aware that it has been an extremely contentious issue. It is particularly contentious in the town of Portland where, twice within 12 months, the local abattoirs, which employ an average of some 600 persons in the slaughter of sheep and cattle, have closed down. They closed down in the middle of last year and early this year. Those people, many of whom have worked in that trade for the whole of their working lives, twice have been put in the position of having no jobs and having to accept the unemployment benefit. I think it is to the eternal disgrace of the Prime Minister, the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Malcolm Fraser), that time and again he has rejected requests by people in his own electorate for some assistance in relation to this issue. Always he gives the same reply. He gives no assistance to workers out of work. I think that indicates the makeup of the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: It is stated in the report that sheep sold for live export commonly bring a higher price than can be obtained for similar sheep sold for slaughter in Australia. Because of this sheep producers value the trade highly and oppose any interference with it. It is my contention that buyers of live sheep for export pay only marginally above the going domestic rate. Figures in all the recent bulletins put out by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation indicate that a price of $2 or $3 a head over and above the going domestic rate is all they are prepared to pay for sheep for export. I guess that two or three bucks a head to a farmer who perhaps has got 5,000, 500 or only five sheep to sell is a few bucks. They are a measly few bucks really when one looks at the price obtained for the these same sheep in the countries where they are exported. Frankly, it is my view that the sheep growers of Australia are being ripped off right, left and centre by these meat exporters. It is my contention that the exporters could well pay $5 to $10 a head over and above the going domestic rate for these sheep . They do not do so because there is no competition in the market that they are supplying at the purchasing end, that is here in Australia. As I said, the exporters pay marginally over and above the going rate and that is all.

I suppose that most honourable senators have seen and read of the protests that have been held, particularly in the town of Portland and especially by meatworkers who are out of work. I have known many of these people for years. Knowing them as I do it is not hard to understand their emotions when they see a large multi-storey sheep export vessel coming into that port. They are out of work yet thousands of sheep are penned within a bull's roar of the town waiting to be exported on a massive vessel that is riding at anchor or tied up at the dock at Portland. Last week 120,000 sheep were taken out by one of these vessels . I suggest that people-male and female-who get upset about picket lines and the workers on those picket lines should think a little more seriously and have some concern for the attitudes the picketers express. The picketers see it as work going out of their port, on the hoof, while they are obliged to accept unemployment benefits. This is in a town which has been beset by problems because of the move into it of the large aluminium firm, Alcoa of Australia Ltd, which has upset the whole social structure of the town by its very presence. Rents have gone through the ceiling and services are totally undermanned throughout the social strata of that town and district.

As I said, I think that people should think a little more seriously about what they see and what they read about the town of Portland. They should have a little more concern when they see picket lines. They should be upset at the attitude adopted by some sadistic truck drivers who seem to take pleasure in roaring down on a picket line and threatening people's lives. I understand that the meatworkers were extremely pleased with the attitude of the members of the Victorian Police Force who attended the demonstration last week. We all know that members of the police force all too often are the meat in the sandwich in confrontations such as these, but I am informed that they played a very impartial role and the picketers I spoke to had only commendation for them.

Turning to the Middle East-the other end of the live sheep controversy-it is obvious from reading this report that changes are evolving in all the countries which the mission visited. As I read the report there are indications that those countries are slowly, perhaps too slowly for the meatworkers of Australia, coming around to the concept that chilled and frozen mutton is or will be more acceptable than it has been. I guess that any of us who have been to the Middle East, who have had the opportunity to tour some of those countries and who have seen the lifestyles that have been traditional for thousands of years, can also appreciate these changes are evolving due to an improved standard of living. I do not have the time to go through the report; one could speak on it for an hour . I hope that the moves that have been made, both in the Middle East and at this end to increase the carcass trade rather than trade in live sheep, will be carried forth with a great amount of vigour. I also hope that we will adopt a little more of an aggressive stance in our marketing of sheep meat in the Middle East and that we will see the day when we will no longer have the confrontation that is currently rife in our ports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both Senator Childs and Senator Primmer have referred to the discord and confrontation that has been provoked in the last couple of years by live animal exports. To a very substantial degree that discord and confrontation is a result of the continuing high and rising levels of unemployment. Traditionally most employees in the meat industry have been neither long term nor permanent employees. They have moved in and out of the industry because of its seasonal nature. They have also quite commonly moved into the industry for a short time and then permanently moved out. If it were not for the generally high levels of unemployment there is no doubt that there would be much less resistance than there in fact is from people who are at present employed in the meat industry to what they perceive as a threat to their jobs. In the decade of the 1960s such people would have readily obtained employment in other areas and would not have resorted to the confrontation tactics which have recently been adopted.

SPEECH.PARA: Action by overseas governments substantially distorts market prices in a number of Middle Eastern markets, according to the report of the Australian Sheep Meat Study Mission to the Middle East, which is being discussed. The price to the consumer of freshly killed meat, which comes mainly from imported livestock, is very heavily subsidised by the governments of Bahrain and Kuwait and subsidised to a lesser extent by the Government of Libya. In Saudi Arabia, the major market in the area, the reverse is the case; livestock imports are not subsidised but imports of frozen and chilled mutton are. In Saudi Arabia, in spite of government intervention-the effect of which is to lower the price of imported carcass mutton and let market forces determine the price of locally killed mutton, usually from imported livestock-the price to the consumer for the freshly killed imported livestock, is significantly higher. It continues to be sold, which is about as clear an expression of consumer preference for that type of product that I think anyone could ask for.

In the other cases-that is, Libya and particularly Bahrain and Kuwait-the recommendation of the mission is that the Australian authorities should endeavour to increase the sales of Australian frozen meat and, in most cases, of Australian chilled meat. If the governments of those countries choose to subsidise the importation of livestock-which is effectively what they are doing- a question which presents itself is: In whose hands or in whose pockets does that subsidy ultimately rest? The fact that a premium, which Senator Primmer thinks is $2 to $3-most estimates would put it higher-is paid in Australian sale yards for live animals destined for export, suggests, to say the least, that some of that subsidy coming from the governments of Bahrain, Kuwait and Libya, is finishing up in the pockets of Australian sheep sellers. If that is so, one might ask why Australia should attempt to terminate this arrangement. That is a question to which the mission not only does not seem to have addressed itself but also one that does not seem to have occurred to it.

I do not want to say very much more on the matter but I do want to comment on a program which appeared on, I think, Channel 9 a couple of weeks ago and which included a reference to New Zealand. A widespread misunderstanding has arisen from a belief that the New Zealand situation is completely analogous to Australia's. It ought to be fairly clear that shipping live sheep to the Middle East from New Zealand, other things being equal, would be less attractive than shipping them from Australia because it is a good deal further, apart from higher shipping costs and the increased risk of deaths at sea and so on. More importantly, traditionally the great bulk of sheep being shipped live from Australia are adult sterile males-wethers, as the cockies call them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maiden ones.

—Yes, maiden ones, usually merino. Such sheep are just not available, and never have been available, in New Zealand in significant numbers. The structure of the New Zealand flock is entirely different; it is oriented to fat lamb production and it has a very much higher proportion of ewes and a very low proportion of merinos. For all those reasons, a negligible proportion-when I took the figures out I think it was 2 per cent-of the total New Zealand sheep flock is males above one year of age, and males above one year of age overwhelmingly constitute exports of sheep. All other considerations aside--
—Are you saying the numbers are still significant even though the proportions are smaller?

—No, the number would be less than two million, whereas the comparable Australian figure is in the vicinity of 30 million. All other considerations aside, the type of sheep which have comprised the bulk of these exports are not, and have never been, available in New Zealand. That is a pretty fundamental point which is normally overlooked.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks on this report will be very brief. I join with my colleagues, Senator Childs, Senator Primmer and Senator Walsh, in what they have said. I fully concur with all they have said. In particular, I concur with the thoughts expressed by my colleague Senator Primmer , who comes from the area of Portland where there are great problems at present with the shipping of live sheep. There are also problems of unemployment. I am one of those persons who went through such a phase many years ago because I used to be an employee of Borthwick's, particularly in the lambing season. I know the feeling of these workers there-the situation then would have been similar to the situation now-when it comes to the end of the lamb season and they do not have a job. The circumstances were different previously in that Borthwick's establishment was run by producer gas. Many of the workers at the abattoirs were able to obtain work in the forests cutting wood during the winter. So the gas producers would be fed right through the year generating their own electricity. That does not take place now. The scene has altered greatly but not concerning unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: I have every sympathy for those people who are now facing the prospect, as Senator Primmer pointed out, of seeing their livelihood shipped out on the hoof from Portland in these mammoth sheep carriers. I hope that the meat workers, in their protests over a period, will be able to convince the sheep growers and the owners that they are not getting a greater income by shipping their sheep out live. As a matter of fact, their income would be more secure if they had a secure marketing method for the dressed product. The Government ought to be looking at ways of convincing the people in the Middle East that the sheep can be slaughtered in conformity with their religious rites. The sheep are slaughtered under much more hygienic conditions in Australia than in the Middle East.

I do not want to indulge in elaborating on that at present as I know other people want to speak on other reports. I seek leave of the Senate to have incorporated in Hansard pages 4 to 12, the recommendations, of the report which we are discussing at present. The people who read the Hansard will then be able to see the general summary of the findings of this mission which went to the Middle East. They will be able to see also the remarks made by the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union on what it thinks about the export of live sheep. I seek leave of the Senate for the incorporation.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
SUMMARY OF FINDINGS

A summary of findings to which all Mission members subscribe is listed below. The AMIEU representatives place a different emphasis on certain of the findings; that summary is in the following chapter.

1. Increased incomes and rapid population growth including a heavy influx of expatriates over the last ten years have resulted in very substantial increases in meat consumption in all of the countries visited by the Mission. Growth in demand for meat has far outstripped growth in local production. Rapidly growing imports of livestock for local slaughter, beef, sheep meats and poultry have made up the shortfall.

2. Low rainfall and desert environments limit the scope for increasing local livestock production. Efforts to expand production are mainly based on intensive feeding operations. All five countries are expected to continue to be substantial importers of meat and/or livestock.

3. In each country there are different market segments catering for the differing tastes and preferences of the local and large expatriate populations. The traditional dietary preferences of the local populations are reflected in Government policies which influence the composition of imports in favour of livestock rather than meat.

4. The meat purchasing habits of the indigenous populations are heavily influenced by the old custom of families slaughtering their own sheep for consumption on the same day. Customary family slaughter has declined. The old ways continue to be reflected, however, in a preference for purchasing freshly slaughtered meat, even though much of it is then frozen in domestic freezers for later consumption. Many of the muslim expatriate inhabitants who purchase meat in the general market place have similar backgrounds and preferences. Muslim expatriates in labour camps may share the preference but have less opportunity to express it.

5. The premium sheepmeat is that from Arab 'fat tail' sheep, bred in local flocks and imported from nearby countries. The limited available supply of this type of sheep is supplemented by imports of sheep from Eastern Europe and Australia. Imports from Australia have increased markedly over the last ten years to meet the increased consumer demand resulting from rising incomes and population growth.

6. The Australian live sheep are the heaviest in the market and are less expensive than those from most other countries. They are said to be too fat to be ideally suited to the market and to have an undesirable taste, thought to be imparted by the pellets fed during transport.

7. The religious requirement for meat to be halal-ie for it to be slaughtered according to the tenets of Islam-and suspicion that imported meat cannot be so relied upon, is an important factor contributing to the strength of the preference for locally slaughtered fresh meat. Religious officials in some of the countries did not subscribe to this mistrust; they indicated willingness to support a publicity campaign to inform consumers of the reliability of Australian Islamic slaughter procedures. Authorities in other countries remain to be convinced of the reliability of Australian procedures. It is evident that a campaign to convince officialdom and the general populace of the religious reliability of Australian meat should be a key element in efforts to expand Australian meat sales to these Middle East countries.

8. The Mission was consistently advised by traders and officials that frozen mutton could not be readily substituted for imports of live sheep. So far as the substitution of other frozen or chilled sheep meat for live sheep was concerned the expectations varied from country to country depending upon local circumstances. In Saudi Arabia most live sheep traders claimed that there was little possibility of substitution but some of them were contemplating entering the chilled and frozen trade. Several supermarket and wholesale traders in Saudi Arabia believed there was growth potential in the frozen and chilled sheep meat trade and had programs planned or underway reflecting this. In the other main Australian live sheep importing countries visited, the position concerning future growth potential was complicated due to the existence of discriminatory pricing arrangements favouring fresh meat.

9. Several live sheep importers informed the Mission of efforts being made to develop additional sources of supply of live sheep. These included proposals for substantial investment in developing sheep production in potential supplying countries. It was acknowledged that interruption to the supply of live sheep from Australia would probably cause short-term difficulties. There was confidence that these difficulties would be overcome through the development and tapping of alternative sources of supply.

10. Notwithstanding the preference for fresh locally slaughtered meat, there is evidence of gradual acceptance of imported meat among the local populations in some of the countries. This is most evident in Saudi Arabia where, with the aid of Government subsidies, chilled and frozen imported meat is sold at considerably lower prices than fresh locally slaughtered meat. It is also evident in the United Arab Emirates where again imported meat is available at lower prices than the fresh product because of policies which allow normal price relativities to prevail.

11. Among the imported meats sold in souks and butcher shops, chilled meat appears to be preferred over frozen and commands a higher price. Of the imported sheep meats, light lean lamb is most in demand. This demand is claimed to be due to a composite of factors one of which is a preference for very lean meat. Chilled or frozen mutton is not apparent in the market places mainly patronised by the local inhabitants.

12. In Kuwait and Bahrain the fresh meat preference is reinforced by direct Government subsidies on live sheep imports which result in fresh meat from imported sheep being less expensive than the chilled or frozen product. In Libya , fresh and imported chilled meat are both subsidised and sold at the same price . The Libyan State organisation responsible for all meat imports and distribution does not supply frozen meat except in small quantities to hotels and oil companies.

13. The real cost of meat from imported live sheep in all the countries is generally higher than the cost of imported chilled meat and well above the cost of imported frozen meat. In the absence of subsidies, fresh meat would be expected to sell at the highest price followed by chilled meat and then frozen.

14. In all five countries, chicken consumption and production has increased remarkably over the last ten years. Chicken meat supplies include large quantities of imported frozen chicken except in Libya which is self-sufficient. In all of the countries chicken sells at lower prices than red meat and is a major dietary item for local inhabitants and expatriates alike. The ready acceptance of frozen imported chicken, apart from its convenience, is said to be due to chicken being a comparitively new item in local diets and consequently not subject to long standing traditions. Chicken is subject to Islamic slaughter requirements.
15. Expatriates presently appear to be the main consumers of imported chilled and frozen sheep meats and beef.

16. In Saudi Arabia and the Gulf countries the expatriate demand is segmented. Western style supermarkets and a hotel and restaurant market serve business and professional people. A catering trade serves the large number of foreign workers in construction and oil camps. There is a gradual trend for the more westernised of the local people to purchase at least some of their meat requirements from supermarkets in chilled or frozen form.
17. In Libya, segmentation of the market is less apparent. There, imported chilled meat, mainly beef, is sold through the same outlets as locally slaughtered fresh meat.

18. Meat from a wide range of supplying countries is evident in all segments of the imported meat markets. Price competition is strong between products of like quality. Products which consumers regard as being of superior quality can command price premiums which sometimes are substantial. Secure and attractive packaging provides a marketing advantage for retail packs. The packaging of Australian meat at retail level should be improved to match competing countries' product presentation.

19. Regulations imposing restricted entry periods and shelf life for chilled and a frozen meat are likely to limit the expansion of Australia's meat exports to some countries. Other local health regulations which prohibit the sale of frozen meat alongside fresh, the freezing of chilled meat and the thawing of frozen meat place limitations on the ability to promote demand for imported meat . The technical justification for these requirements could be questionable.

20. The Mission learnt of the emergence of Mainland China as a mutton exporter to Kuwait. 1981 exports from China to Kuwait represented in excess of 1500 tonnes or expressed as a percentage of total imports 22 per cent. Imported mutton from China is utilised in the catering industry.

21. All of the countries visited have plans to build new modern abattoirs which will significantly increase slaughter capacity. In Saudi Arabia the expansion was explained as being part of a policy to encourage butchers and individual consumers to have livestock slaughtered in an abattoir rather than in backyard facilities. However, it appears the planned expansion in all of the countries would provide capacity in excess and in some cases well in excess, of present or likely future domestic market requirements.

22. There are also plans to provide a variety of by-products processing plants and for facilities for further processing of locally slaughtered meat into consumer cuts and products and for a capacity for freezing meat.
23. Supermarkets and fast food outlets are currently enjoying a buoyant period with considerable expansion planned for the future.

24. Except in Libya there is no shortage of cold storage facilities either at portside or internally. Libya has very limited capacity for storing frozen meat and only a small expansion is planned. Household refrigerators and freezers are said to be commonplace especially in the main urban centres.

25. The Mission was informed of recent animal disease outbreaks in certain ports serviced by vessels carrying live sheep from Australia. One outbreak was identified as rinderpest and descriptions of others suggested that they may have involved diseases exotic to Australia.

26. Concern was expressed in certain markets about Australia's unreliability as a trading partner due to industrial disputation. On pursuing this question not all delays could be substantiated as due to this cause.

27. The Mission was told of the desire of Middle East businessmen to invest in agriculture and processing industries in Australia. One reason advanced for such investment was to ensure future supplies.

28. The Mission learnt of the establishment of another large National livesheep buying and shipping company, Saudi Livestock Transport and Trading Company. On the basis of plans outlined to the Mission it would appear that this organisation, together with Kuwait Livestock Transport and Trading Company, will account for a very large proportion of sheep purchased and shipped from Australia.
SUMMARY OF FINDINGS BY REPRESENTATIVES OF THE AUSTRALASIAN MEAT INDUSTRY EMPLOYEES' UNION

1. The AMIEU is concerned at the planned building of new abattoirs in the countries visited. The countries are importing the maximum number of sheep available from other suppliers. It is evident that the expected increase in the throughput is to be supplied by Australia.

2. The demand for Australian mutton continues to grow. Imports in 1980 by the countries visited reached 88,150 tonnes, (3,875,000 live sheep, equivalent carcass weight 77,500 tonnes, plus 10,650 tonnes of processed mutton).
3. The figure continued to rise in 1981 when mutton imports reached 102,000 tonnes, (4.5 million sheep, equivalent tonnage of 88,150 tonnes, plus 12,028 tonnes of processed mutton).
4. The foregoing figures clearly indicate that the major demand is for big framed wether carcasses and continues to increase annually.
5. The local populations in all the countries visited have a strong preference for fresh meat, particularly sheepmeat.

6. Prior to refrigeration becoming widely available (within the last 10 years), the only way to keep meat fresh was to keep it alive. The tradition of arranging the consumption of the whole carcass at one sitting was because meat left over could not be preserved.
7. All countries visited continue to tolerate the belief that the only way to be sure that sheep meat from Australia is Hal-Al, is to slaughter it locally.
8. Kuwait, Bahrain and Libya directly discriminate against processed mutton by regulation or embargo.

9. In Kuwait and Bahrain the fresh meat preference is reinforced by price fixing and subsidy arrangements which result in fresh meat from imported sheep being less expensive than the chilled or frozen product. Libya imposes a total embargo against frozen or chilled mutton from Australia.
10. In Saudi Arabia the preference for fresh sheepmeat is maintained despite prices of fresh meat being substantially higher than chilled and frozen meat prices.

11. Frozen chicken is widely available, its low cost ensures that it is the predominant meat item fed to the large number of foreign workers maintained in labour camps throughout the countries visited. The volume of poultry consumed by foreign labourers may be the reason that the authorities appear unconcerned that the meat is not necessarily Hal-Al.
12. A demand exists among the wealthier expatriates for chilled and frozen lamb of 8-12 kg; a demand exists also for chilled and frozen beef and veal.

13. Competition for the preferred type of sheepmeat is keen with other suppliers better able to provide the smaller framed lamb carcass. The large expatriate population of the UAE are the main consumers of chilled and frozen sheep meats.
14. The expatriate demand is segmented-a supermarket trade and a hotel and restaurant trade serving business and professional people.
15. There is a gradual trend for the more westernised members of the local people to purchase at least some of their meat requirements from supermarkets in chilled or frozen form.

16. Australia's domestic consumption accounts for 80-90% of lamb production, the average carcass weight of which is 16 kg. Therefore heavy lamb, hogget and young mutton offer the best opportunities for expanding Australia's sheep meat exports to the expatriate market. This is subject to current discriminatory regulations being eliminated.
17. With the exception of the UAE, mutton consistent with the following specification represents 80-90% of sheep meats consumed.

18. The countries visited have a strong preference for big framed wethers weighing in excess of 50 kg live weight (and preferably heavier). There are no other countries capable of supplying the market with sheep of similar type.
19. Libya has a preference for wethers of a more common weight i.e. 40-45 kg live weight. Despite this, Libya is forced to purchase at least 50% of its requirements from Australia.

20. Frozen or chilled mutton will have to be shipped by sea if significant quantities are to be involved. This will require a review of live sheep regulations by the countries visited and the assistance of the respective Governments in overturning the existing prejudice based on religious grounds.
21. Several traders, particularly in Saudi Arabia are interested in testing the market for this type of meat if given market development assistance from Australia.
22. In devising marketing arrangements for these meats there should be an effort to have them sold alongside fresh mutton on a price competitive basis.

23. In Kuwait and Bahrain this would require the co-operation of the local authorities in varying existing price control and subsidy arrangements which favour the import of live sheep rather than meat. In Libya the current embargo against Australian mutton would have to be terminated.
24. We will also need to seek variation of regulations in some countries which prohibit thawing of frozen carcasses or which require chilled meat to be sold on the same basis as frozen.

25. Provided that the negative factors contained in Items 7 and 8 are eliminated the prospects for mutton exports to the countries visited is encouraging. In the circumstances the imposition of a ratio is clearly a matter of political judgment.

26. It is clear, however, that live sheep importers have taken all possible steps to obtain live sheep supplies from alternative sources. The Mission was unable to identify other suppliers capable of replacing Australia from its current dominant position.
27. Ninety-six percent of sheep slaughtered in Kuwait are imported from Australia.

28. The AMIEU is of the view that the demand for big framed wether mutton will continue to rise. A ratio would ensure that a proportion of the market would therefore be supplied with frozen or chilled carcass mutton.

29. In all the countries visited, the requirement was for sheep meat from Australia to be Hal-Al and the view was that imported mutton from Australia cannot be relied upon. This is the major factor contributing to the preference for locally slaughtered sheep meat.

30. Religious authorities in some of the countries did not subscribe to this mistrust but acknowledged that it existed; they would lend their support to a publicity program to inform consumers of the reliability and correctness of Australian Islamic slaugher procedures. Success would depend upon demonstrable Government support.
31. The Mission was informed of outbreaks of animal diseases exotic to Australia. The diseases included, Sheep Pox, Foot and Mouth, Rinderpest and Screw-worm Fly.
32. The AMIEU is concerned that livestock vessels are regularly visiting Australia shortly after sailing from areas where the above diseases are prevalent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I think the authors of the statement deserve high commendation. It is only when one reads this document that one appreciates the complexities of Australian citizenship, particularly when one has to relate one's own national attitudes to international obligations. Pages 4 and 5 of the report mention an area of abuse. If a woman in Australia on a tourist visa gives birth to a child there is a bit of a tug of war as to the child's citizenship. This has occurred with Asians on a number of occasions. If they are Chinese and return to Malaysia or Singapore, particularly Malaysia, they get the full viciousness of Malaysian hostility to Chinese. On a number of occasions Australia has had to bail out a family because the hard line Malaysian attitude was that a child born in Australia and going back with its mother and father to Malaysia was, in Malaysian eyes, an illegal alien.

In other situations the parents could plan to acquire citizenship for the child and then use it as a lever to get permanent domicile themselves. The compromise on page 5 of this statement endeavours to get the best of the two worlds. It will be interesting, when this statement has been digested, to see how people view the matter. On reflection, it is probably the best possible solution. The report, I am pleased, mentions the removal of 'British subject', as distinct from 'Australian citizen'. The word 'subject' is more of a relic of colonial days. I commend the former Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and his advisers on its removal.

The other matter I mention is very delicate in view of a number of deportation cases, particularly two that are pending. The statement deals with people committing offences just before or just after they are granted citizenship. I regarded it as an historic day in the Senate when Mr Justice Murphy, who was the Attorney-General, removed discriminatory clauses in the Crimes Act which were a hangover, an obsession of non-Labor governments in the 1920s. There was a maritime dispute. Two men who had permanent residence, Australian citizenship, namely, Jacob Johansen and a chap named Walsh, who were of Scandinavian and Irish origin, were regarded as the demons of the trade union movement. They were never deported but the provisions hung like the sword of Damocles until 1972. An enlightened Attorney-General, Lionel Murphy, then removed them.

I admit that maybe some Nazi war criminals have come to Australia who could have been sent back to face retribution. As late as this year several Baltic nationals who were SS men came to Australia. One was aged 70. To the best of my knowledge he has been sent back and other charges are pending. We had a similar case with a chap named Vicks. A minority of members of the Australian Labor Party wanted action to be taken. The then Attorney-General, Lionel Murphy, felt that Australia was leaning on the side of civil liberty. I felt that people such as war criminals should not have been the beneficiaries of the liberal attitude we took on citizenship. To show how slowly we are moving with the times, that discriminatory practice was removed by Canada in the 1930s.

The other points that I want to refer to are in themselves not large. I refer, firstly, to the amazing discrimination involved in the provision whereby a British woman ordinarily resident in Australia who bears a child out of wedlock out of the country can register that child as an Australian citizen but if the woman is not British the child cannot be registered as an Australian citizen. The step that has been taken is not big but it is a belated recognition of equality. I have some reservations in relation to this consolidated franchise. Some United States nationals come here to avoid their call-up and Vietnam commitments, others went to Scandinavian countries. Some of them have been rather scornful since acquiring Danish citizenship or Australian citizenship. I do not think any of us should be jingoistic in our attitude to citizenship, but we do not like free riders. It is no reflection on Senator Peter Baume, but if Senator Chaney were in the chamber I would say to him that I believe that to some degree the unravelling of the reciprocal arrangements for social security benefits with one or two countries in Europe might have deterred some people who were on the threshold of obtaining citizenship and who felt that they would lose some social security benefits if they proceeded. I do not say that they were quite so mercenary about it.

My use of the word 'mercenary' reminds me of the activities of mad Mick Hoare and his fellow mercenaries. He is presently facing trial in South Africa. It burns me up that he ignored Australian laws about Australian citizens being involved in brushfire wars. Our diplomatic people have had to become involved in this matter. I question whether a person such as that, who is prepared to get involved in these private wars, is entitled to hold Australian citizenship. However, that is a low grade matter; it is not a major matter.

The reference in the ministerial statement to children of marriages of an overseas nature transferring to Australian citizenship recalls to mind the situation of a mate of mine who has been out of Australia continuously and who is active in the commercial world of Japan and other Asian coutries. There was a time when I was a bit amused with the problems that Britain had with the dominions beyond the seas following the acquisition of independence of African countries and the role played by Indians with British passports. Frankly, I felt some of these people should have stayed with their African brothers, helping with their merchandise skills and contributing taxes, rather than going to Britain. But, whether these people were of Indian or African extraction, Britain was their country of nationality. I apply that situation to Australia in speaking of the mobility of Australians. I recognise that our people of the diplomatic corps and those accepting United Nations assignments face some very intricate problems in this regard.

I conclude by referring to the fact that it has been indicated that a large number of people have not sought Australian citizenship. I was encouraged last night by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle pointing out that we are overcoming some of the bureaucratic roadblocks-for example, the slowness in Federal or State police screening. Also, we have been able to infuse additional clerical staff into the system. I am sure that Barry Cotter of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association will be happy with the efforts of people on this side of the chamber to bring about the breakthrough. With those words of wisdom, I commend the ministerial statement. I hope that we will have further discussions on these matters before they become law.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This statement by the former Minister for Communications, Mr Sinclair, purports to deal with issues surrounding the development and establishment of a domestic satellite system in Australia. The statement is remarkable not so much for what it says but for the issues which it leaves unresolved in relation to the domestic satellite which has been proposed. The first issue which it leaves unresolved, of course, is the cost. At this stage the final cost of a domestic satellite for Australia is completely indecisive. The only fixed cost that can be pointed to is that of $166m which is to be paid under contract to the Hughes Aerospace Corporation of the United States in respect of the satellite. That cost is fixed. Every other cost is open-ended.

I make the point that the Department of Finance, which is responsible for providing the money, has queried the cost of the domestic satellite. Yet no Government statement has been made in response to that query from the Department of Finance. I do not know whether this Government, which talks about the market place and so on, is a very good example to the market place in the way in which it does business in relation to issues such as the investment of what will probably be in the order of $600m in respect of that satellite as there has been no financial statement provided as to the projected cost. There has never been an economic analysis, a cost-benefit analysis, of the cost of the provision of a domestic satellite to Australia.

This is a government which talks so much about knocking off some little committee here or something else there under the direction of the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee, the so-called razor gang-an exercise which every public servant in Canberra knows is costing much more than the continuation of those bodies would cost. We are now almost at a stage where we can identify some of the costs of the razor gang's recommendations in terms of the ongoing costs and the actual costs of changing arrangements in the Public Service. The Government, which talks a lot about these issues, is here talking about spending $600m of taxpayers' money without any economic analysis or cost- benefit analysis of what is involved. I think it is important to note in relation to financial matters that, except in regard to broadcasting to the outback of Australia and the provision of telephones to the outback of Australia , the satellite is just a technical alternative to the terrestrial system of communications which we already have. It will be used for data transfer, television relaying, et cetera. I simply make the point that the major cities of Australia are already terrestrialy linked in respect of the television transmission, data transfer and so on to which I have referred. In terms of benefit as against the cost the only perceived benefit at the moment, as distinct from the benefits that can be provided by a terrestrial system, is in respect of some outback broadcasting and the provision of television services to some people in the outback. We do not for a moment say that is not important.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about telephones?
—I mentioned telephones.
—And perhaps the flexibility.

—As Senator Peter Baume would know, the satellite provided only an alternative route to the existing terrestrial system. The signal goes up and down instead of across the land mass. If one looks at the matter in perspective, the all-up cost of perhaps $600m is over half of Telecom Australia's current annual investment of about a billion dollars. That investment of $600m, of course, is to be spread over several years. If that is so, it should be regarded as just like any other investment in telecommunications, because that is what it is-an investment in telecommunications-and it should be stripped of its mystique . There is no reason why the costs of the satellite should not be subject to the same frank disclosure by Government as are the costs of other telecommunications services. It is high time the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), whose Department has queried the costs of the satellite on a number of occasions, came into this chamber and made a statement about the costs of the satellite and gave some estimate of the cost and benefits as that Department sees them.

SPEECH.PARA: There is nothing in Mr Sinclair's statement about these matters and there is nothing about the management of the satellite, particularly how that management will be integrated with the terrestrial system, that is, the system provided by Telecom. Perhaps that is why Mr Sinclair has been moved to the defence portfolio -because this sort of statement does not stand up to any critical analysis which should be made of a development such as this and at this cost. I shudder to think what will happen if defence estimating is done on the same sort of basis, although, of course, it is already, if one examines some of the projected expenditure on capital works in relation to defence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't that pre-judging the situation that you are advising should happen? If you are saying it would not stand up to examination, you are pre-judging the examination.

—No, I think I said the defence expenditure would not stand up to examination. There has to be an examination of that. I am pre-judging that, if you like. There is nothing in this statement about limitations of ownership in the company Aussat Pty Ltd which will manage the satellite. There is, more importantly, nothing about possible conflict of interest between companies which are both shareholders in that satellite company and users of the satellite service. A most important principle in telecommunications throughout the world is the separation of hardware from software-engineers call it hardware-software separation-and the separation of those who provide the services from those who use them. In this statement no consideration is given to that very important question. I can tell honourable senators now that, if people who are providing a service are also using it, it will be said, and quite properly, that there is always the suspicion that users who are also shareholders in the service company will obtain some benefit or other which other potential users will not have.

SPEECH.PARA: All these matters are related to the inquiry into telecommunications being conducted by the Davidson Committee. Last year, in correcting Mr Mansfield, the secretary of the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association-the relevant union-Mr Sinclair said that the Davidson inquiry had nothing to do with the satellite. As reported in the House of Representatives Hansard of 6 may this year-I do not have time to quote the remarks now-Mr Sinclair referred to the Davidson Committee's important decisions about the domestic satellite. There is nothing in this statement about other methods, about the second proposed commercial satellite. There is nothing in the statement about methods of bringing television services to remote areas using terrestrial means such as radio concentrators. One cannot help feeling that this whole satellite project is simply an expensive, uncosted exercise in gee whiz technology, 'gee whiz' being, of course, the nickname given to the former Minister who launched this project, and a number of other red hares, I suppose I had better say, instead of red herrings, in communications policy which the present Government is now desperately trying to follow up. It is time for a proper evaluation of the cost of this satellite.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of former senator Joe Fitzgerald. We welcome him back to the chamber and hope it brings back many happy memories.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak only very briefly to outline the major concern that the Australian Democrats have about the establishment of a national communications satellite system. We agree with the comments of the Opposition as outlined by Senator Button that there has been no cost-benefit analysis of a satellite. We are talking about a large amount-$600m or more. It is a very large expenditure at a time when governments are looking at ways and means of saving money, and one has to query the priorities at this time. Certainly there should be a cost-benefit analysis, but such an analysis has not been carried out. That is one area of oversight by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: But even assuming that a satellite has to come to this country and that we have to face up to such an expenditure at this time, we are particularly concerned about the ownership of Aussat Pty Ltd. The Government has said it will control 51 per cent of the shares but it has put no restriction on the private ownership of the other 49 per cent of the company. It is wide open for users or individuals to own very large parcels of that 49 per cent of shares. We see grave dangers in this in that users can also become very large part-owners, shareholders, in the operation of the company. This would give the users and the shareholders a very powerful say in how the satellite is to be used. We, as a party, are already concerned about the concentration of ownership of the media and communications generally in this country. We believe that the national interest is best served if there is the widest possible diversity of ownership in communications. So we would like to see the Government impose a limit of 5 per cent on private shareholdings in the Aussat company. If this were done it would ensure that the satellite was used to the benefit of all Australians and would give them some feeling of involvement in a very important new area of technology.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for consideration of ministerial papers has now expired.

—I report to the Senate a communication that the President has received from the Chairman of the Administrative Review Council. I lay on the table a letter from the Chairman of the Council dated 13 May 1982 responding to a resolution passed by the Senate on 29 April 1982 relating to administrative advice tendered to certain Ministers on the use of agent orange and other defoliants in Vietnam. The text of the letter has been distributed to honourable senators for their information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As a result of the letter received by the President from the Chairman of the Administrative Review Council, the Senate, I believe, finds itself in a catch-22 situation. The motion referred to by Mr Tucker in his letter to the President, as he says was agreed to by a majority of the Senate on 29 April 1982. The notice of that motion had in fact been on the Notice Paper of the Senate since 18 August 1981. We had a debate in this place involving people on this side of the chamber and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) and for all that time the Government had the opportunity to consider this motion. My point is that of all the arguments used against the motion-the Government opposed the motion on the night of 28 April 1982-the one argument that was not used by the Government was the argument that the Administrative Review Council had no power to deal with the administrative advice tendered to certain Ministers on the use of agent orange and other defoliants in Vietnam. I believe that I would have found it to be a fairly compelling argument. We may have considered changing the motion in some way but we did not do so. The argument was not put forward as a reason to vote against the motion. Either the Government had not considered seriously the motion and the powers of the Administrative Review Council or it was indulging in a political tactic knowing quite well that the Administrative Review Council would consider that it could not deal with the matter referred to in the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I wish to make arises out of the very sensible letter by Mr Tucker to the President. Mr Tucker points out that the functions of the Review Council are as follows:
(a) to ascertain, and keep under review, the classes of administrative decisions that are not the subject of review by a court, tribunal or other body.

(b) to make recommendations to the Minister as to whether any of those classes of decisions should be the subject of review by a court, tribunal or other body and, if so, as to the appropriate court, tribunal or other body to make that review;

In other words, classes would appear to be general rather than specific and it would appear that the Administrative Review Council can consider only these classes and not specific forms of administration as the Senate requested in its motion. Therefore, as Mr Tucker says, his interpretation is that the matter does not come within the ambit of the Council's statutory functions. He then goes on to add:
the Commonwealth Ombudsman is empowered to investigate 'action that relates to a matter of administration'.

He further points out that the Ombudsman can deal with specific instances as was mentioned in the motion agreed to by the Senate. The difficulty, of course, is that the Ombudsman's function is qualified. The Ombudsman cannot conduct a public inquiry; he reports only to Ministers and to the Government. So we are in a catch-22 situation when we want to investigate administration, or maladministration, of this type. The Administrative Review Council cannot deal with specific forms of administration. The Ombudsman can do so, but not publicly , and he does not report publicly. I suggest that Mr Tucker's letter, quite unexpectedly to me demonstrates that we have a hiatus between the functions of the Administrative Review Council and the Ombudsman. I think it is something that the Senate, the Government and the Opposition will have to consider in the future. We will now reconsider our position on this matter. We will come up with a more definitive reply later. I thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President, for producing this letter and giving us the opportunity to comment on it in the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the seventh, eight and ninth reports of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Committee I also lay on the table 'Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 8' dated 20 May 1982, and a submission relating to the eight report. I seek leave to move a motion relating to the ninth report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the report be adopted.

The purpose of moving this motion is to give the Senate the opportunity to consider proposals made in the ninth report of the Committee. This report fulfils the requirement, contained in the resolution of the Senate of 19 November 1981, that prior to 30 June 1982:
The Committee report to the Senate on the work of the Committee and the need, if any, for a separately constituted Standing Committee.

The report contains a number of conclusions and recommendations, the most important of which is that the work which has been performed by the present Committee should be continued by a separately constituted standing committee to be established by Standing Order of the Senate.
