TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee has been gratified to note the response to its activities, both within and outside the Parliament, and has no doubt that such responses have contributed to its effectiveness and have assisted in its arriving at the conclusions and recommendations contained in the report. A number of matters raised by the Committee have resulted in useful amendments to legislation this year. The Committee wishes to pay special tribute to its counsel, Professor Dennis Pearce, of the Australian National University. Without his dedication and skill in performing the onerous function which has been imposed upon him-particularly during this experimental period of the Committee's operations-the task of scrutinising the many Bills which have come before the Committee would have been virtually impossible.

INTERJECT.PARA: While I have moved at this stage for the adoption of the report, the Committee is concerned to ensure that senators have sufficient opportunity to study the comments made, and its conclusions and recommendations. At the same time, the Committee wishes to ensure that the work it has been performing continues until the Senate is able to reach a decision on the report. For this reason, I will be seeking leave to give a notice of motion, which if agreed to by the Senate, would make transitional arrangements for the continued operation of a scrutiny committee until such time as the Senate determines whether a standing committee for the scrutiny of Bills should be permanently established, and, if so whether, an appropriate Standing Order should govern its operations.
Debate (on motion by Senator Jones) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) (a) That a Standing Committee of the Senate, to be known as the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, be appointed to report, in respect of the clauses of Bills introduced into the Senate, and in respect of Acts of the Parliament, whether such Bills or Acts, by express words or otherwise-
(i) trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties;
(ii) make rights, liberties and/or obligations unduly dependent upon insufficiently defined administrative powers;
(iii) make such rights, liberties and/or obligations unduly dependent upon non- reviewable decisions;
(iv) inappropriately delegate legislative power; or
(v) insufficiently subject the exercise of legislative power to parliamentary scrutiny.

(b) That the Committee, for the purpose of reporting upon the clauses of a Bill when the Bill has been introduced into the Senate, may consider any proposed law or other document or information available to it, notwithstanding that such proposed law, document or information has not been presented to the Senate.
(2) That the Committee have power to consider the Minutes of Evidence and records of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills appointed by Resolution of the Senate of 19 November 1981.

(3) (a) That, unless otherwise ordered, the Committee consist of six Senators, three being members of the Government to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, and three being Senators who are not members of the Government, to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate or by any minority group or groups or Independent Senator or Independent Senators.

(b) That the nominations of the Opposition or any minority group or groups or Independent Senator or Independent Senators be determined by agreement between the Opposition and any minority group or groups or Independent Senator or Independent Senators, and, in the absence of agreement duly notified to the President, the question as to the representation on the Committee be determined by the Senate.
(4) That the Committee may proceed to the despatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(5) That the quorum of the Committee be three.

(6) That the Committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such sub-committee any of the Bills, Acts or other document or information which the Committee is empowered to consider and that the quorum of a sub-committee be two Senators.
(7) That the Committee elect a Government member as Chairman.

(8) That the Chairman may from time to time appoint a member of the Committee to be Deputy-Chairman and the member so appointed act as Chairman of the Committee at any time when there is no Chairman or the Chairman is not present at a meeting of the Committee.
(9) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the Chairman, or the Deputy- Chairman when acting as Chairman, have a casting vote.
(10) That a Senator, though not a member of the Committee, may participate in its public sessions and question witnesses, unless the Committee orders otherwise, but shall not vote.

(11) That the Committee or any sub-committee have power to send for and examine persons, papers and records, to move from place to place, and to meet and transact business in public or private session and notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.
(12) That, unless otherwise ordered by the Senate, all records and all documents received by the Committee remain in the custody of the Senate.
(13) That members of the public and representatives of the news media may attend and report any public session of the Committee unless the Committee otherwise orders.

(14) That the Committee be empowered to print from day to day such papers and evidence as may be ordered by it, and that a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings of the Committee as take place in public.

(15) That the Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint Counsel to advise the Committee, and other persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the Committee, with the approval of the President.
(16) That the Committee not meet while the Senate is actually sitting, unless by special order of the Senate.

(17) That the Committee have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such recommendations as it may deem fit, and be expected to make regular reports as to the progress of the proceedings of the Committee.
(18) That the Committee may authorise the televising of public hearings of the Committee, at the discretion of the Committee, and under such rules as the Senate may adopt.

(19) That this Resolution operate as an Order of the Senate until such time as the Senate may determine the motion for the adoption of the Ninth Report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills appointed by Resolution of the Senate of 19 November 1981 and, contingent upon such adoption, the Report of the Standing Orders Committee on proposed new Standing Order 36AAB may be considered by the Senate.

(20) That, until such time as the membership of the Committee may be determined under this proposed Order, the members of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs be members of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.
(21) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received a letter from the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) requesting that Senator Lewis be discharged from further attendance on the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence and nominating Senator MacGibbon to be a member of the Committee.

INTERJECT.PARA: That Senator Lewis be discharged from further attendance on the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence and that Senator MacGibbon, having been duly nominated in accordance with Standing Order 36AA, be appointed a member of the Committee.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the votes contained in Group F be now passed without requests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the reasons why I wish to speak briefly again to these estimates is that last night, when we were talking about the cost of providing for children within the Australian Capital Territory, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) said that most of the children being looked after were children who had some particular problems, such as coming from broken homes or being orphans, and that because of that element the cost of looking after them was probably higher than it should have been under normal circumstances. I make just this point: If that information is correct, it certainly was not given to the Estimates Committee. It was not given by the Minister. From the Hansard report of the discussion in Estimates Committee F, we find that a number of statements were made, particularly one by Mr Wall. He referred to the cost of keeping children or looking after children in the Australian Capital Territory, but he also said that only a slight number of children had some problems and were looked after outside the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that we would need to get information from the Minister as to the number of children who are being looked after in those homes and who have some particular problem, be it medical or psychological, or some problem which would mean that the cost of looking after the child would be much higher than under normal circumstances. I again draw the attention of the Senate to the problem that exists, or the problem that I see. The cost of looking after a child was listed at $250 a week. We then looked a little further and noted from the information given to Estimates Committee F that to foster a child the cost was $30 a week. Looking back at the Government's record in relation to child endowment, I am not sure that the Government pays extra money to single parents who have to look after children, and I am not sure that the Government pays extra money to a parent who has a child who has a special medical problem. It seems to me that it is a fairly fallacious argument to use-because of the high cost-that all these children have special care.

In the statements made to the Estimates Committee, there is no statement by the Minister that sets out those details. I ask the Minister to give the number of children held in those institutions or homes, those that have special problems, and what is the cost of those children as compared with the costs for children whom we would call normal children in those homes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I realise that there was not a full discussion on all those aspects in the Estimates Committee. I drew the attention of Senator Jones to that last night. As to the specific question about the numbers involved and the details of that, I shall endeavour to get that information for the honourable senator. We do not have it available at present. I shall seek to supply it to the honourable senator as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a matter that I wish to raise again with the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner). I raised it on the first reading of the Bill. It is in relation to an answer which I am still awaiting to a question that I gave on notice on 18 November 1981. I shall repeat the question for the Minister in the hope that, if his officers do not have the answer today, I shall be in receipt of it before the debate resumes, on my notice of motion, on Thursday of next week. As I said the other day, I was most disturbed that, whilst some six months ago I sought an answer to my question and had not received it, Senator Messner, in his reply to a debate here on 29 April- on a notice of motion of mine in relation to Commonwealth home loans-was able to use some figures which I had sought. He said to me, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: I know that Senator McLaren mentioned one or two people who had low interest loans in the Australian Capital Territory but I note that there were many others . In fact, 5,900 people in the Australian Capital Territory.

The Minister was able to pluck that figure out of the air to use in a debate in endeavouring to rebut my argument, but he has not been able to provide me with the figures, and I would be interested to know where he got that particular figure from.
I shall just refresh the Minister's memory with the question I put on notice on 18 November:
Senator McLaren: To ask the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory-
(1) How many people in the Australian Capital Territory are in receipt of long term Commonwealth Home Loans at interest rates fixed at 6.25 per cent per annum, or lower.
(2) What income brackets are these people in and what are the terms and interest rates applicable to each income bracket.
(3) Are any of the recipients Cabinet Ministers, if so what are their names and the terms and interest rates applicable to their respective loans.
(4) How many persons, if any, in each of the States were able to obtain the same generous long term low-interest provisions of the Commonwealth Home Loans.

I shall not enter into any debate on this matter today, because there is a debate in process in this Parliament, which I hope will be determined before the Parliament rises. However, I want to make a brief explanation. In paragraph (2) of my question, I ask what income brackets these people are in. I have no complaint about people on low incomes having low interest rate home loans. I have no complaint about ex-servicemen who served this country in World War I or World War II having such loans, but I have a complaint about such loans being granted to people on very high incomes, such as the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon), who has now paid off his loan, and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) who, as far as I am aware, still has a long term, low interest home loan. It is loans for those people to which I object.

I have presented many petitions to this Parliament calling upon the Government to make these same generous terms available to the many disadvantaged people who are now paying abnormally high rates of interest for home loans. I have no objection to people on low incomes being in receipt of low interest rate home loans. That is quite right. I have no objection to those provisions being made available for ex-servicemen who have served this country in time of need. If the Minister does not have the figures now, I hope that he will provide me with them before we enter into the debate next Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recall the earlier references from Senator McLaren and, in particular, the question that he asked on 18 November last year. In relation to his further comments on 6 May, I think, when he commented upon certain information that I made available at that time, it was very limited information, of course, and it referred only to the total number of loans. I think that the number was 5,900. I may also have referred to the fact that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) had discharged his loan with the housing authority. That was the only information which I supplied at that time, and it did not go very far along the road to answering the full question asked by Senator McLaren on 18 November. The information I provided then was basically public knowledge. As I think will be acknowledged, there was some public comment about Mr Nixon discharging his loan, and there had been newspaper reports about the numbers of people at previous times having loans of this kind.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the further points, I shall not take the matter any further, because I shall seek to get the information for which the honourable senator asked in the latter part of his comments. I just make the observation that those cheap loans were made available back in 1964 at a time when interest rates were much lower than they are today; but, because of the documentation that was prepared at that time, that was a feature of all loans made at that particular time. I understand that the necessary documentation covering such loans in these circumstances has been changed since then, so that there are now applicable to these kinds of loans variable interest rates as distinct from the situation that existed before . But as to the exact detail which Senator McLaren is seeking, I shall need to take that request on notice. I undertake to get that information as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to deal with an item that comes under the appropriation for the Department of Transport. Last night during the consideration of the estimates for this Department mention was made by Senator Jessop of the Port Augusta airport. He said he had raised this matter during the hearings of Estimates Committee F. I just want to quote a couple of lines of what he said as recorded at page 298 of the Senate Estimates Committee Hansard of 22 April. Talking about the Port Augusta airport he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a very small aerodrome at the moment, catering mainly for the flying doctor and light aircraft.

That statement has caused some concern in the Port Augusta area because a commercial air service provided by Pagas Airlines does operate into that airport . Many charter aircraft also use it. There is a Bandeirante 8-seater aircraft which operates through there on a regular basis to Leigh Creek. I just want to acquaint people with the fact that that service is there.

The other matter which Senator Jessop spoke about last night was the plea that he had made to the then Minister for Transport for some upgrading of the airport and some undertakings that he claimed he had been given. Of course Senator Jessop in years gone by has claimed to have been given many undertakings in relation to the far west of South Australia, particularly in respect to television services. As yet a lot of them have not eventuated. What we in South Australia are now hoping is that this matter for which he has asked for high priority to be given in the Budget is not just another furphy floating around. I will quote what he did say lat night as recorded at page 2192 of the Senate Hansard. He said:
The Minister for Transport has given me the undertaking that he will give it priority.
Well, of course my interjection was:
What undertaking has the Minister for Transport given to Mr Wallis?

Mr Wallis is, of course, the honourable member for Grey, and has been for quite a number of years. As a matter of fact, it was Mr Wallis who unseated Senator Jessop when he was the honourable member for Grey. Mr Wallis has been pursing this matter ever since he has been the honourable member for Grey in an attempt to get the airport upgraded. I spoke to him this morning. He had also heard what took place last night. Further on in the speech Senator Jessop said:
I think I have had a lot longer interest in that subject than the person to whom Senator McLaren referred.

Mr Wallis has now asked me, seeing that Senator Jessop was so deeply involved in that airport, whether Senator Jessop in fact had had any part in the siting of the airport at the time. It was sited wrongly because of the height of the hills . Now, when the airport is going to be sealed, it has to be reoriented some seven degrees to bring it up to civil aviation standards. Mr Wallis also reminded me that immediately the reshuffle of the Cabinet took place he wrote to Mr Fife, who is now responsible for civil aviation matters, and asked him to determine as a priority the sealing of the Port Augusta airstrip and its upgrading. I just want to point out that whilst Senator Jessop may claim some responsibility for whatever is going to happen there, Mr Wallis has been right on the ball for many, many years in trying to get this airport upgraded because he uses it on a regular basis, at least when Parliament is sitting, flying to and from Canberra. He is concerned not only for his own safety but also for the safety and wellbeing of every other person who uses that airport, and in particular the people who operate aircraft in and out of Port Augusta.

I make this plea on behalf of Mr Wallis because the other place is not sitting. He was going to make this plea in the other place some weeks ago but of course they operate in a different fashion from the way we operate in this place. A member can be stopped in full flight when he is on his feet. Mr Wallis rose to speak about the problems during the debate on the Civil Aviation (Carriers Liability) Amendment Bill. He was also going to bring up the matter of the state of the Port Augusta airport. I think he got about four words out of his mouth before the gag was applied. He could not make that speech. It would have been most important, particularly for the people in the far western part of the State in which he resides and which he represents. He was most upset about that. Fortunately that does not happen in this place. Once a senator is on his feet, irrespective of whether he is annoying the people opposite or the Leader he cannot be sat down unless he offends Standing Orders. As long as he sticks to the subject under consideration he can go ahead and say his piece. That does not happen in the other place. It was unfortunate for Mr Wallis otherwise what he has been endeavouring to do over the years to get some work done on that airport would have been on the public record. I just make a plea on behalf of Mr Wallis that Mr Fife should take immediate notice of the letter which Mr Wallis has written to him on behalf of the people who use that airport, and in particular on behalf of the local council. I am not going to get into that argument because Senator Jessop has made some claims about local ownership. I am sure the local council and the airport committee, of which Mr Wallis is a member, will be able to handle that in the way that it ought to be handled when they are given a copy of this Hansard which is already in the mail to them. They will be perusing it early on Monday morning.

I again make the plea to Senator Messner that he remind Mr Fife that if he has not already got that letter from Mr Wallis it is in the pipeline because he wrote to him immediately he received the appointment and asked him to give this matter urgent priority. I hope that when we come to the Budget session there will be an appropriation to do the work at the Port Augusta airport which we on this side of the chamber are very concerned to see take place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might be able to expand on the status of the development of the Port Augusta airport at this stage for the benefit of Senator McLaren. The aerodrome is owned and operated by the Corporation of the City of Port Augusta as an authorised landing area. The Corporation has made submissions to the Department recently about local ownership. The Department considers that work to bring the aerodrome to full standards for current and known future aviation needs, and to satisfy licensing requirements, could be justifiable in the context of local ownership entry. That means that the Corporation could well qualify for prospective grants of 50 per cent of the costs under the normal program. This entry to the plan would proceed if agreement can be reached with the Corporation on the scope of the works necessary and for which Commonwealth grants would be sought and agreement can be reached with central agencies on the justification for entry. But all of this would depend upon the availability of funds. This of course brings us back to the point I made last night, that is, that this is a matter for the Budget and it will be considered in that context.

I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) to ask the departmental officers to give me some additional information. The Department's answer is that the Department has considered this comment and will make changes to the automatic data processing system which will permit this check to be carried out in two specialities from 1 July. I ask: Why only two speciality areas? If it is possible for two areas to be checked, why is it not possible for all areas to be checked?

SPEECH.PARA: I also asked what steps had been taken to overcome the matters raised by the Auditor-General. The answer that has been provided states that of the 20 matters raised by the Auditor-General the Department has advised that, from 1 July, 14 matters would be resolved with the introduction of the new ADP system. Four matters were disputed with the Auditor-General's Office with the Department recording its comments. We have not received any record of the comments that I am aware of. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to a question of mine, Dr Langsford, the First Assistant Director-General of the Public Health Division responded that the working party on occupational health needs of women in the work force has not met for some time but that its considerations had been taken over by a major committee which looks at reproduction and family health. This is reassuring because some of the major concerns of the working party related specifically to reproduction related aspects of the health of working women, such as menstrual problems, conception, pregnancy, lactation, the menopause and the very many implications of poor or hazardous working environments or processes for the health of women and/or their offspring.

SPEECH.PARA: A well attended seminar on women's occupational health was convened by the National Women's Advisory Council in May 1981. This was probably the first full scale serious look at the subject since a survey of working women in Victorian industry was carried out in 1928. The 1981 meeting examined the available data and concluded:
Women workers as a group experience more stress than men
A large number of women employed outside the home also carry the main responsibility within the family for household tasks and child care
Many women are segregated into a number of industries which are particularly hazardous--
But they are not normally seen to be so-
(e.g. the manufacturing, food processing, and clothing industries)
Women tend to fill the low-status occupations, ones which tend to be highly repetitive and produce on average greater tension and stress, as well as physical problems . . . greater insecurity
Working women face potential health problems associated with their reproductive functions
Finally, and very importantly-

Housework is also work-but it is not recognised as such; it is unpaid, involves long hours, often heavy physical work, there is no compensation, leave or safety inspections, and it is subject to numerous conflicting demands.
All of us are well aware of this. The National Women's Advisory Council in its 1980-81 annual report observed:
These investigations led us to believe that specific advice on the occupational health needs of women should be considered and presented to the Commonwealth Government.

I eagerly await some evidence of the deliberations of the National Health and Medical Research Council committee on reproduction and family health. One of the most fundamental and crucial contemporary questions would concern the potential mutagenecity, tetragenecity and carcinogenecity of the plethora of chemicals, gases, solvents and metals to which many workers, both male and female, are currently exposed. Many experts have recently drawn attention to the lack of proper analysis, registration and monitoring of the use of potentially very toxic chemicals which are in daily use. I believe that all honourable senators received during this week a publication Livestock and Grain Producer which included an advertisement headed: 'Bulk buys available NOW'. Among the things that people were being urged to buy in bulk was a liquid arsenic dip which was provided in 20 litre containers. There was no indication in this advertisement about any danger which might be associated with the use, the storing or anything else of liquid arsenic dip which farmers were being urged to buy. That represents just one example of the sorts of unacknowledged dangers with which people are coming in contact daily.

Dr John Matthews of the Australian Council of Trade Unions Trades Hall Council Occupational Health and Safety Unit stated that whole industries have been associated with excess cancer deaths. Sir Edward Hughes, the head of the Monash University's School of Surgery, has called for the collection of occupational data in conjunction with the Victorian Government's cancer registry. Every registry of congenital malformations should also contain the occupational histories of both parents. The Government has a responsibility to prevent birth deformities and cancers of the types that are caused by exposure to harmful industrial and agricultural chemicals. I sincerely hope that the National Health and Medical Research Council and its various committees will prevail upon the Government to identify the hazards and move expeditiously to ensure that no Australian, living or anticipated, is exposed to these unnecessary and largely avoidable risks.

There are dozens of issues which are desperately in need of investigation particularly in relation to women in the work force. The effect of shift work, for instance, has not been even adequately investigated. There has been no investigation done at all, as far as I am aware, at an official level, of the social, psychological and physiological damage that is caused by the stress of shift work.

There are two issues which I would like to touch on very briefly. They concern the use of visual display units and radiation and tenosynovitis. Newly introduced computers, particularly visual display units, have created a great deal of anxiety especially among the women who use them for hours and days on end. The VDU is said to be harmless. But in a notorious case four women who were employed as VDU operators by the Toronto Star gave birth to children with congenital defects. No causal link had been proved but neither had the machines been cleared. I know that women who are employed by Telecom Australia are extremely anxious about the possible ill-effects of the constant use of visual display units. Incidentally, I have been told that radiation from VDUs, if it exists, is assumed to emit from the screen in a direct fashion, but in fact it is just as likely to be emitted downwards from the bottom of the unit. So if male users are worried about any adverse effects that radiation might have on their reproductive organs they should be careful not to tuck them under the desk on which the VDU sits.

The repetition industry affects very many women workers. Pat Young of the Workers Health Resource Centre referred recently to the very high incidence of tenosynovitis-that is, repetition injury-among cleaners, food packers, electrical assemblers, mail sorters, bank clerks who count money and even garbage collectors. Pat Young said that many workers go off on sick pay and then leave the job. She said:
Many are frightened they will be sacked if they complain: One electrical factory got rid of the problem by firing 45 women.

Many doctors do not know enough about the injuries to recognise them. Surely this is a state of affairs which is crying out for urgent attention from the NHMRC. In conclusion I would strongly recommend that the Department of Health study chapter 7 of the 1980-81 report of the National Women's Advisory Council, to which I have referred earlier. The report represents the experience of many women who are workers themselves and their voices should be heeded. If the working party on the needs of working women is not to be reconvened by the NHMRC some other means should be devised for bringing these matters urgently before the Council.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Initially I wish to deal with the Department of Social Security. First of all, I refer to a matter which was the subject of some discussion during the Estimates Committee hearing. That is, of course, the matter of staffing. The subject of the staffing of the Department of Social Security is always a feature of the questioning at Estimates committees and this year it was of greater interest because of the dispute between the Government, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) and members of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association regarding staffing levels. Matters have developed since then. I think that they are worth discussing and bringing up during the consideration of the Appropriation Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past two weeks we have seen a remarkable upgrading of staffing within the Department. On 4 May the provision of 580 additional staff was announced. This produced a new staff ceiling of 12,279. Today another 314 positions have been announced for 1982-83, taking the staff ceiling, on my count, to 12,593. The distribution of those additional staff I will deal with a little later.

First, I would remind the Committee of the position that existed six months ago . ACOA members of the Department were then asking that an additional 1,000 staff be provided. Later that demand was broken down to one for the immediate provision of 300 additional staff. Work bans were imposed on overpayments as an attention getting device and irritant until the Minister for Social Security took seriously the staff shortages, which were having a depressing effect on the morale of the Department, whose staff members were worried that they were giving poor service to clients-who, heaven knows, were in enough trouble as it was.

Most honourable senators know what happened. First, there were stand-downs and then the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act, or CEEP legislation , was revived. To use the jargon, they were 'CEEP-ed'. The Minister was not interested in the reasoned case that the departmental officials were making. I suggest that he was going on like a school master who was interested only in disciplining them, in trying desperately to shore up his position as el supremo in the area, whatever the cost to his front line troops, as they might be called , on the counter, and to the hapless claimants who were forced to line up in their hundreds at the charitable agencies or emergency relief counters of State departments. More than $1m was spent in advertisements and so on abusing the staff. That money was recouped by stopping their pay. Mediation offers were ignored. Pleas by courageous senior staff, who wrote telling the Minister how staff limitations had depressed the quality of services to recipients and jeopardised safeguards on the spending of large amounts of Commonwealth Government money, were ignored.

Throughout the dispute the staff ceilings were defended as not only adequate but generous. When the stand-downs, penalties and bans stopped, a couple of weeks before Christmas, the Minister finally agreed, in consultation with the ACOA, upon an independent inquiry into staffing needs-a simple course which could have, and I suggest should have been the beginning and not the end of the process. One of the reasons why it had not been the starting point was that the Director-General of the Department had unilaterally, in October 1981, cancelled the national consultative mechanism for settling disputes. We are told that the independent inquiry is to report in a month's time but the urgency of the proven staffing needs could not even await that. As I have said, on 4 May 580 more jobs were approved by the Public Service Board, independently of any increase granted as a result of the independent review. The ACOA welcomed it as leading to a better service for the needy and underprivileged and claimed that it would be of great satisfaction to members, who had made considerable sacrifices on the issue in November and December last.

Today we learn that another 314 positions will be provided in the coming financial year. Thus, an additional 894 jobs will have been provided in the Department even before the independent inquiry has finished its work. All of the 80 positions provided on 4 May in the unemployment benefit area went to New South Wales, where the pressure by the ACOA had been most evident and forceful. I suggest that the Public Service board recognised the justice of the ACOA claims within a few months of the union's stand. By comparison, the stand of the Minister was not only petulant, not only extreme but also quite clearly wrong. An analysis of the additional positions granted reveals a few startling assumptions. If one deducts the positions allocated to STRATPLAN, the new $100m computer, to freedom of information staff, 80 per cent of the new staffing is to be devoted to the effects of pension population growth-which does not require much staff work once processing has taken place-and to increase work expected in the unemployment and sickness benefit areas. That is, the bulk of the additional staff, the extra 80 per cent, will be devoted to the processing of unemployment benefits.

An addition of 15 per cent to 20 per cent will be made to the staff in regional offices in 1982-83 because of judgments concerning projected unemployment figures. It is our first signal that the Government expects further considerable increases in unemployment benefits payments and beneficiaries. It would appear that the services area of the Department is again to be the poor relation. It is not to be given additional staff and at this stage it appears that employees there are in total confusion about the intentions of the Ministers and the Director-General. For some months there have been rumours about a reorganisation within the Department, even rumours about the possible abolition of the social welfare division, a combination of service and subsidy areas, and a separate rehabilitation directorate. I suggest that morale is low because confusion reigns as a result of the differing statements that have been made inside and outside the Department, and the lack of communication between the Government, and the directorate of the Department and the rank and file workers.

The Auditor-General's report this year directs some attention to the way in which staff shortages have prevented work taking place on the acquittal of the pre-school capital program. A rather bland letter from the Minister assuring me that there are no staff shortage problems in New South Wales has not in fact reassured me, as in two areas-pre-grant interviews for unemployment benefits and the children's services area referred to earlier-his statements are at variance with the comments of the Auditor-General. Quite clearly, all of the fuss and bother that went on last year, all of the the posturing by the Government about the matters of the Public Service in the Department-about how unjust were their activities and claims in the face of what the Minister called generous staffing procedures-have been shown in the last few days to be wrong. The response by the Government has been shown to be wrong. In fact, to a fairly large extent the claims of the organisation which represents the employees are now being met. They could have been met at any early stage, when they could have been demonstrated, to be true, fair and reasonable. Instead we had the performance that we went through last year and the shouting and screaming across the barricades which occurred.

I hope that in future the Government will take more notice, not only of the union and other representatives of workers in the Department, but also of the State Directors of Social Security, at least one of whom, as Senator Chaney knows well-we discussed it during the Estimates committee hearing-reported the difficulties to him a long time ago. It was just that the Government chose last year to make what it thought was political capital out of an unfortunate industrial incident.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond immediately to Senator Grimes because he seems to be under a considerable misapprehension and I would hate to prolong his misunderstanding of the situation that he has tried to describe. He appears to have fallen into the same error as did the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association originally with respect to the announcement of staff ceilings as at 30 June 1982 -an error that fortunately we have managed to clear up with that body.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not canvass all of the matters that Senator Grimes raised because he tried to rerun some of the reels that were run so unsuccessfully last November and December. The position with respect to the announcement of the staff ceiling which is to apply as at 30 June 1982 is simply this: In the course of the year the Department assumed additional functions. Because of Budget provisions we took over certain functions in the health field and we undertook certain additional functions which warranted the obtaining of additional temporary staff ceilings. The reason why a temporary staffing ceiling was obtained was that until those new functions had been tried in the Department and put into operation it was thought that one could not make a final determination as to the staff levels which were required. Indeed, I think it was even conceded by the union that the temporary staff cover which we obtained for the major function we took on, the health function, was quite adequate and proved to be as much as- indeed, probably more than-was required.

During the year that temporary ceiling varied. Some of the temporary ceiling was retained for training purposes. But, as we move towards the end of the financial year, the Public Service Board has now made determinations which put all those ceilings on to a permanent basis. In other words, the temporary arrangements which have applied throughout the year, because of the variations in the functions of the Department have been subsumed into a set end-of-year staff ceiling which provides our commencement point for the next year. So, to some extent, I think there certainly was public misunderstanding about that. The figure of 500 which was announced, in part, picks up those temporary positions.

The other changes were made on the basis of the standard staffing formulas which have been in use in the Department for some time whereby certain staff are granted according to the volume of work in particular sections-for example, the number of pensioners and beneficiaries. There is a ratio between the number of beneficiaries and the number of staff. So there are adjustments in that area as well. Indeed, the interim ceiling which was then announced for June 1983 represents an estimate on the part of the Board of the work load which will be carried by the Department at that time given predictions as to the numbers of pensioners and beneficiaries at that time. In other words, I stress that we have always tried to make fair staffing arrangements within the Department. The Government has been anxious to see that the Department which impinges so much on the lives of many Australians is fairly staffed. I stress that we are currently following exactly the same staffing ratio methods as have applied in the past. I say that because I think it is important that it be understood publicly and in the Senate that the staffing of the Department in many of its functions relates quite simply to the volume of work in a way which is measured and accepted.

It was never my position last year-there were plenty of public statements to this effect-that the staffing position in the Department was static. Indeed, I made it quite clear that there would continue to be adjustments through to the end of the financial year and beyond. That has occurred, as it should. I made it plain to the union when the recent announcements were made about staff ceilings that the announcements were without prejudice to the findings of the inquiry which was commenced earlier this year after I had again had some consultations with the union. I regard my dealings in this area as being essential to the good running of the Department. I put on record, yet again, the very simple reason for not being prepared to deal with the union during the dispute last year. It was that we had done a whole series of things, including obtaining temporary staff ceiling cover for new functions, which were very much in accord with the union's requests and demands over the years. I was not prepared in the face of quite reasonable activities on the part of both the management of the Department and the Government to lie down in front of threats of trade union activity of a very destructive kind. I make no apology for that.

That strike was a total failure. The left wing faction, in its publications since that strike, has put it on record that that strike totally failed. However , I regard the strike as something which is in the past and best forgotten. It is important that the staff of the Department, the management of the Department and the Government devote themselves to the good running of the Department in as co-operative a manner as possible. Certainly I intend to approach staffing and all other matters in that spirit. I am sorry that Senator Grimes has found it necessary to try to rerun the reel here this afternoon. There is no substance in the points he has made. If he would like to conduct a closer examination of the figures and their method of calculation and computation he is more than welcome to do so. I offer him that detailed information if it is of interest to him.

The only additional point I comment on is that there certainly has been some bias in the allocation of additional staff which has been granted under those formulas. Again, I do not think there is anything peculiar about that. As I said during the strike, it was never my claim that the position in every social security office was satisfactory; rather, that the general position was satisfactory but there were problems that we were attending to. It is certainly true that there is an uneven work load. That, I think, will be better disclosed by the inquiry which is currently under way. But it has been the judgment of the management of the Department, with which I have not sought to interfere, that it is warranted to direct some of those additional resources into the areas where there would appear to be greater problems with respect to work. I think that is perfectly sensible management. I would not, of course, wish to interfere with it .

I welcome very much the fact that the unions concerned, with which I have had dealings recently, have seen fit to welcome the publication of the staff ceilings which have been announced. They have certainly been concerned that this has not been a pre-emption of any consideration of the inquiry which was undertaken earlier this year. I have given them my assurance that that is so. I simply wish to assure this Committee that staffing matters will continue to get the same careful attention from the management of the Department and from me as they have received over the past 18 months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Department of Health for distributing to members of the Committee copies of the first four quarterly reports of the National Perinatal Statistics Unit. These reports are entitled ' Congenital malformations monitoring report'. The first was issued in January 1981. Apparently they have appeared quarterly since then. I am certainly very interested in being placed on the mailing list for these reports. These reports contain data from four States on congenital malformations. It is anticipated that the monitoring system will eventually include data from all States and Territories in Australia. The four States which are presently included in the data collection are New South Wales, Queensland, Tasmania and South Australia. According to the first issue of this report, the objectives of the monitoring system are: Firstly, to monitor the reported incidence of congenital malformations in Australia; secondly, to study trends in incidence rates of individual malformations and of infants with multiple malformations and with malformation syndromes; and thirdly, to compare incidence rates in each State and Territory with national rates.

SPEECH.PARA: The monitoring system may enable the early detection of new teratogens or it can provide baseline data for the evaluation of reported associations between drugs or environmental agents and malformations. Similar monitoring systems are now functioning in about 20 countries. I wonder whether every effort has been made to obtain at least the acknowledgment of the non-participating States of the need for a standardised system of collecting data. It is futile for States which are still outside the national collection to insist on collecting their own information-I know that an exercise of this nature is being undertaken competently in Western Australia-unless it can be added to the national profile.

I referred earlier today to the necessity for registers of birth deformities to include the occupational histories of both parents. I stress this again. It is absolutely essential as a means of identifying occupations or aspects of such occupations which should be avoided by prospective parents. There is already substantial evidence that, for example, recovery rooms associated with operating theatres, unless properly ventilated, contain dangerous levels of halogenated hydrocarbons. We know too that many of the solvents used in laundries and drycleaning establishments are believed to be accountable for still-births, miscarriages and birth deformities. I could use dozens of other examples. I want to point to the absolutely essential nature of this aspect of data collection. I am delighted that we now have this register and that it is functioning. I stress again that to be of optimum value it must be national and it must be comprehensive. I hope that the Department of Health will do what it can to attain this state of affairs in the shortest possible time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise another matter but in passing, in reply to the typical response of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) to my remarks earlier, I merely make the point that the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, Mr Roy Dowell and other State directors of the Department of Social Security pointed out to the Minister the deficiencies in the staffing of his Department-particularly the deficiencies in the areas of unemployment and sickness benefits, at the front counters and in regional offices. An attempt was made to negotiate with the Department and the Government , and only after that were work bans applied. Although the Minister pretends to be and tries to say that he is a reasonable person, it was with a touch of hysteria in his voice that he came out with stories of left wing factions in the ACOA, et cetera. The simple fact of the matter is that of course the ACOA welcomes the new staff ceilings. That is what it asked for all the time. They are a justification of the claims it made.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind honourable senators that the Minister spent more on self-publicity in that dispute, castigating his staff members, than the Department spends on publicising benefits and pensions to potential recipients. It is an example of his priorities. I hope that now that his State colleague has been removed from the area of industrial relations he will talk to the more reasonable Minister from Victoria and perhaps learn from him rather than from the combative and confrontationist approach of the previous Minister, who has been discredited throughout this land for his handling of industrial relations. Senator Chaney can dream about his left wing factions in the ACOA and the Public Service, and about reds under the bed. All that demonstrates is that some things never change in this country, and one of those things is the attitude of extreme conservatives like him. I wish to deal with the handling of invalid pensions. Another area which was also raised in the Estimates Committee--

TALK.START.PARA: —Grimes fairy tales.

—Despite her present invalidity Senator Walters regularly finds great amusement in any reference to the disabled made either in this chamber or in Estimates committees. She thinks it is a joke that people should require assistance because of disability and invalidity, and repeatedly she says so. Despite the fact that her injury, sustained after celebrating what she saw as a great victory on Saturday night, is disabling her it has not affected her earning an income and therefore she has no sympathy for those in a more unfortunate situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The administration of invalid pensions has been disturbing to many honourable senators. This concern arose with the tightening of eligibility procedures which were introduced by Mr Lanigan when he was the Director-General of Social Services. He is well known to people in this place. He commissioned a legal opinion from Mr Hulme, a well-known tax expert, and Mr Gavan Griffith, a man who is famous for having argued in the Green-Daniels case on behalf of the Department of Social Security. The view put was that social services were 'a gratuity, not a right'. Mr Lanigan used that opinion to direct that only medical criteria were to be taken into account in granting invalid pensions and that no other factors were to be considered. As honourable senators know, at that time thousands of invalid pensioners were taken off pensions virtually overnight. New applicants found it very difficult to get pensions if they were in any way capable of moving about. One of the famous statements in that opinion was that quadriplegics frequently could do something and therefore may not necessarily be eligible for invalid pensions.

Taking into account the fact that the number of invalid pensions has dropped every month since June 1980 and the regular growth pattern of invalid pensions over the past decade, one could be looking at tens of thousands, some 30,000, pensioners who would have received pensions in the past two years had this change not occurred. In 1977 invalid pensioners represented 10.7 per cent of all pensioners and beneficiaries and now they represent about 9.5 per cent. There were a considerable number of protests from advocates for invalid pensioners and new guidelines were introduced. They appear to have made very little difference. What progress has been made in getting justice for invalid pensioners has come about it seems entirely by the appeals process and in particular the cogent arguments and the considered decisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The first breakthrough came from the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in the Panke case, which the Minister aproached at the time in, unfortunately, a rather flippant manner. During the hearings of Estimates committees last September, he said:

that decision . . . is in accordance with the guidelines. It is simply that a wrong decision was taken in that case. Having in mind the number of decisions made, there would be no argument . . . that of course some wrong decisions will be made . . .

I think we should look at how many wrong decisions are made. Thousands and thousands of wrong decisions have been made because of the restrictive definition of invalid pensioners and the necessity for the Department to enforce that restrictive definition. On the most recent figures from the Minister, in a six-month period from 1 July to 31 December 1981-a period which I have no reason to believe is other than typical-2,846 appeals were made by invalid pension claimants. Of those, 1,286 were conceded without even getting to the Social Security Appeals Tribunals; that is, almost half were granted when the Department took a second look at them. Another 474 won their appeals against the Department even though it is well known that many of the doctors on the Social Security Appeals Tribunals are conservative and more than conscious of their obligations to the Department. For that six-month period, 61.2 per cent of invalid pensioners appealing won their cases. In other words, in almost two- thirds of the cases the Department was judged as wrong and did not dispute the findings.

It is not easy for disabled people to appeal against the decisions of the Department. It is a big step for people to take and one knows-we all know-that some people are put off from taking on the bureaucracy or the Department in this way and do not appeal. Yet of those who appealed nearly two-thirds won their case. The Department was wrong in two-thirds of those cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gee, you can do a lot with statistics.

—I hear the voice of Senator Walters again. She obviously believes that this is a source of great amusement, and that this is a satisfactory performance. We know her view on this sort of thing. At the moment thousands of cases are banked up at the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. These are cases of people appealing to that high authority. I hope many more will join these people to demonstrate the difficulties being faced by them. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal has considered 28 appeals against rejection of invalid pensions on medical grounds, not on income grounds. Of these 28 appeals, the appellants have won 24 cases. The Department has been wrong in about 86 per cent of cases on medical grounds. People involved in the other four cases were referred to training or rehabilitation schemes, and their cases are to be reviewed. The fact that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has taken an overall look at the invalid pensioner claims, their work histories, their medical histories, their psychiatric problems and the likelihood of any employer taking them on should, I believe, have made a difference to decisions taken by the Department of Social Security. The evidence shows that it does not do so unless appeals are in fact made against these adverse decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: A recent letter within the Department of Social Security has drawn attention to the unsatisfactory standard of departmental submissions to the tribunals and to the propensity of the Department to persevere with disputed decisions which might otherwise have been conceded. The letter comments on the failure of the Department of Social Security to ask the Department of Health to get further and better specialist opinions and on its failure to consider socio-economic factors which may render the appellant 85 per cent or more permanently incapacitated. It is a difficult problem for any doctor in this community to assess whether someone is, for instance, 85 per cent or 80 per cent disabled or otherwise. Many of us would suggest that this is an unsatisfactory set of parameters to apply but it becomes even more unsatisfactory when, as so often happens, the judgment of someone who has seen and treated the patient, who has examined the patient, is overruled by a departmental medical officer who has not set eyes on the disabled person or, if he has seen the patient, has seen the patient only briefly in what is repeatedly described as a cursory interview.

I received today a request from one of my colleagues, the honourable member for Wills, Mr Hawke, concerning a person who was on an invalid pension from 1972 but who last year was taken off that invalid pension. He has five certificates from highly qualified medical practitioners who have high degrees in their specialities and who have all examined this man. They all said that in their opinion he is permanently disabled. They said that he has more than 85 per cent disablement and will not be able to continue his work. Five medical practitioners expressed that opinion and yet a departmental doctor overruled those views. The departmental doctor had no knowledge of the lengthy history and treatment of this man who has lost his pension. He has been told that his pension will not be paid. He now has to go through the appeals procedures. Undoubtedly, like so many other people, his appeal will succeed.

I think every honourable senator in this place knows that the handling of invalid pensions in unsatisfactory. This matter is brought up at every Estimates committee hearing. It is brought up every time the Appropriation Bills are debated. I believe that something has to be done about it as the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has said repeatedly. It all stems from the crazy set of guidelines which were established for the Department by Mr Lanigan some years ago. We are suffering from the aftermath of that. We will continue to suffer from the aftermath of that until we have a radical change in the administration of invalid pensions in the opposite direction from that made by Mr Lanigan some years ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to respond briefly to the matters which have been raised. Senator Giles raised a series of detailed suggestions with respect to the investigation of the health problems of women. I think the best action I can take with respect to the points she made in the Committee this afternoon is to refer them to the Department of Health for consideration. The areas which she mentioned are, in the main, receiving attention. I am sure her comments will be taken into account . I will obtain written responses to the matters raised by Senator Walters who sought an amplification of written responses already provided by the Department of Health. They will be obtained.

SPEECH.PARA: With respect to the matters raised by Senator Grimes, I can only say that he is the lone defender of what was one of the most pointless, unnecessary and certainly the most unsuccessful strikes in the history of industrial relations. Senator Grimes might think it is quaint to refer to the left wing groups and refer to me as a tory or whatever but I should like to quote from a publication entitled 'Grey Collar' which took the trouble to print an assessment of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association. I will quote a few words--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who publishes 'Grey Collar'?
—It is a sub-group within the organisation which produced a great deal of printed material, some of which was referred to in the Senate during the dispute. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The dispute in the Department of Social Security which exploded in the last two months of 1981 was an important turning point for ACOA. Hundred of members were stood down for six weeks. Large chunks of the Department were paralysed and industrial action peaked with a three days strike of the entire union in New South Wales. Yet, the dispute ended in defeat for ACOA. What went wrong? We in the Public Servants Action Group think it is important to look closely at the way the campaign went and draw lessons from it.

So it went on. I commend publications of the Public Service Action Group to any honourable senator who is interested because I think they show the difficult problems that can be produced by a minority within an organisation. I believe that group represents a tiny minority of public servants and I regret that its members have any influence at all in the system. Certainly they did nothing but promote a massive dislocation last year. I regret that Senator Grimes continuously seems to find it necessary to defend what I think most people regard as indefensible.

The issue of invalid pensions, as Senator Grimes correctly said, has been raised at successive Estimates committee hearings and on other occasions in the Senate itself. I agree with his comment that it is difficult to assess whether a person is 80 per cent to 85 per cent disabled and cannot work. It is difficult to do so. That is part of the problem the Department faces in trying to administer that test. The test is administerd by public servants who seek their medical advice from the professional officers of the Department of Health. As Senator Grimes said, that advice often is augmented by outside specialist opinion. I think it is important to concede that one is often engaged in making most difficult judgments. One's mind tends to leap to the picture of a man or a woman in a wheelchair, a person with a severe physical disability which will clearly prevent them from engaging in most forms of activity. That sort of case does not, of course, give rise to difficulty at all. The problems arise with cases of psychosomatic origin-I do not suggest unreal origin; a psychosomatic illness can be as real for the person suffering it as any form of physical illness. There may be marginal physical situations where the assessment is difficult to make.

I think the efforts of the Department over the last year and a half or so to devise guidelines which will provide more assistance to members of the medical profession in relation to what sort of advice they should be tendering my Department which has the responsibility for making the ultimate decision are an indication of our concern about the difficulty and about the fact that some wrong decisions are made. Of course, the whole object of having a system of appeals, both internal appeals to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and external appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, is to provide a check on the administration of these systems so that we can find out whether the administration is going wrong. Senator Grimes referred to some statistics which he suggests indicate that there are continuing problems. I agree with him that there are continuing problems. A close examination of those statistics shows that there appears to be an unevenness in the administration of the system. The unevenness is a difference from State to State in the statistical position and the statistical trend. Because of that difference, the matter is receiving close attention from both my Department and the Department of Health. Work is being done on producing a better form which will provide more guidance to the medical practitioners involved. A careful assessment is being made of the way cases are being dealt with in those States where there would appear to be a trend which is against that of other States. Those matters are receiving close attention. I do not deny that they require attention; I simply say that they are obtaining it.

My concern was certainly aroused by the statistics as they came through. It was in fact at my request that a closer dissection of the statistics in terms of invalid pensions either granted or refused was carried out. It was that dissection which showed the unevenness to which I have referred, and which is, I think, an important element of the problem at the moment. I have recently spoken with officers on that. Consultations are occurring between departments and also at my request with people outside the department with an interest in this area. Concerning the decisions which have so far come through, I would merely wish to say that neither Panke's case nor any other has produced a decision which would suggest that the new guidelines which we produced last May are incorrect. Rather the decisions have indicated that the guidelines are not on all occasions applied properly or successfully or with full regard to all of the relevant facts. Of course it is our duty to try to ensure that the number of such errors is minimised.

I am sorry that Senator Grimes found it necessary to make some, what I would regard as, rather cheap jibes at Senator Walters's finding problems of invalids amusing. That is clearly a silly remark which is so far from the truth, but since it has been broadcast I do feel it is necessary to comment on it and respond to it. I reject it. It is a silly partisan and political remark which has no place in a discussion on a serious issue. I acknowledge Senator Grimes's serious interests in the problems of the invalid pensioner. I acknowledge that there are serious problems which I, as a Minister, and my Department are tackling. I come back to the point that there are real difficulties in applying tests about the extent of incapacity which indicates that a person is permanently incapable of work. That is a very serious judgment to be made and it is one which has both technical difficulty and sometimes the difficulty of people who do not provide us with all the information that might be required, and so on. They are matters of continuing concern and they are receiving continuing attention.

The other point which could be made is that in those cases where there is doubt , where people are on the borderline and are judged as not being 85 per cent incapacitated for work, it is, of course, almost invariably the case that some other form of income maintenance is available. The person who is sick rather than invalid is entitled to receive the sickness benefit. The person who is unable to obtain employment because of the state of the labour market is entitled to the unemployment benefit. So, usually in these situations of difficulty-the situations about which we are concerned-it is not a fact that the person is left without income support; rather he or she is put on a form of income support which is not a permanent one but one which applies for as long as the condition of either unemployment or illness remains. I think the issue raised is a serious one. It is one on which further work is to be done and on which I am certainly not fully satisfied with the present state of administration. I will be persisting in efforts to remove the difficulties which remain.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise one other matter and to seek a reply from the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). It is the problem which arises out of the unresolved situation of invalid pensioners in Greece whose pensions were suddenly cancelled by the Australian Government in April 1978. I hope we can obtain some firmer assurances from the Minister about the rights of these people to fair play. However delayed it has been, it will be a considerable victory for decency and fairness, I suggest, if these neglected people receive some sort of justice.

SPEECH.PARA: I brought up this matter in October 1981. When the alleged conspiracy, involving members of the Greek community, occurred, 183 people were arrested in April 1978 in Sydney. Another 600 in Sydney lost their pensions and a further 138 pensioners in Greece had their pensions cancelled at the same time. After examination lasting only a few minutes the pension cancellations of these people were, in fact, confirmed in 105 cases. According to Senator Chaney, on 21 April this year invalid pensions were subsequently restored in 27 cases. I assume that those 27 people were the people who by some means or other returned to Australia to prove their eligibility. If that is the case I would like a breakdown of the number who were restored in Greece and the number restored in Australia. I raised this matter first during discussions on the Estimates eight months ago. At the time, the Minister expressed some interest in looking at the problem of the invalid pensioner who had remained in Greece. When I raised this matter in October, I was assured that the Minister was taking it very seriously, but I have not yet received any results of this alleged seriousness.

The whole sorry affair is not only tied up with the case in Sydney, where committal proceedings have dragged on for over three years, but also, I suggest, tied up with the Government's determination to prune the number of invalid pensioners-a matter I referred to earlier this afternoon. The invalid pensioners in Greece were in fact the first to feel the severity of the Government's tough approach. Their pensions were cancelled on the spot. They had no three months grace as pensioners in Australia have when they are no longer considered eligible on medical grounds. They had no opportunity to appeal in Greece as the invalid pensioners here now have the opportunity to appeal. Invalid pensioners in Australia can produce additional medical evidence supporting their cases and socio-economic factors are also taken in support of their cases, but that does not apply in Greece. The problem is that these invalid pensioners were apparently simply abandoned by the Government. Many of them had no other income. Some of them begged and borrowed from their families. They had no recourse in law and no sympathetic government. In fact they became non-persons as far as this Government, this country and this Department were concerned. As I say, some of them scraped, begged and borrowed and came back here, and, in fact, had their pensions returned to them. In October I asked that all remaining invalid pensioners in Greece, whose pensions were stopped in March and April 1978, be re -examined in Greece by an independent medical team using the same criteria as those now applied in Australia, and which include work availability, previous work history, age, educational attainment and medical factors which were not previously considered. If we can do this to the people when they return to Australia and re-apply, we must in all conscience, I suggest, do it to all Greek pensioners who do not have the money or the strength to return to Australia to go through the whole process again.

I have received, and continue to receive, a large number of letters from the Greek-Australian Pensioners Association in Athens and from others who are still courageously battling on and fighting for some justice. I believe because they are in Greece we should not ignore them. The people who write the letters are becoming more desperate and therefore the language is becoming more desperate. I quote from one of them, which states:

We have considered, Sir, the whole affair, as a racist purge from the Australian Government's point of view and we protest for that. Our members are facing, for the time being, a real tragedy. They are calling us very often, asking for help. They don't have sufficient food. Sufficient money to sustain themselves and their families. They are trapped in Greece with no medications, with no medical care, with no money to pay their fares to return to Australia to undergo a fresh medical examination from Australian doctors, to have their pensions restored or to get any other form of assistance. These unfortunate people, are not entitled to any national benefit in Greece, because they are not contributors to a fund. Any treatment at a public hospital, would cost them a fortune. The General Practitioner's visit, is very expensive. Their health condition, under these circumstances, becomes more deteriorated. Our Association has already sent two members to Australia, having their fares paid out of its funds. We try to find out more money to send some more who are in our list, but it is difficult for us, because we have no means and assets to raise funds to help . . . Continue your actions and presentations to the Australian Government, the only responsible body for the whole sad affair, until our members get the right which they deserve from the Australian justice . . .

This letter is signed by Mrs K. Andricopoulos and Mrs F. Spyrou. In addition to the pensioners in Greece who have not had the means to return to re-establish their eligibility, I brought up at the time the treatment of those who have managed to return, including the two who had their fares paid by the Greek- Australian Pensioners' Association in Athens. These people have proved their eligibility. They have proved it on the same grounds as they were given pensions initially and they have proved that they had a continuing eligibility. Therefore , I believe they are entitled to back payments for the years before they could return. One really should consider payment from the time of the cancellation at that time of hysterical behaviour in 1978.

In answer to my question on notice-I received the answer four weeks ago-Senator Chaney advised me that five appeals have not yet been finalised in respect of pensioners who have returned from Greece, have had their pensions restored and are seeking back payments. They date from March 1981. Three have had submissions sent to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal from the Department. In two cases the Department has not put its submissions together. I am interested in why the Department is fighting so hard against back payments in these cases. Why does it not just concede? Quite clearly the Department was wrong. I hope that we can get a better reply than on the last occasion when this matter was raised. On 18 March this year Senator Primmer asked the Minister for Social Security what action had been taken on behalf of the invalid pensioners in Greece who had been taken off the pension in 1978? Senator Chaney replied in a totally negative fashion. He stated:

The action I took following the matter being raised last year was to refer it to my Department for advice and consideration on the various factors which are involved. I have received a number advisings on the matter. Those advisings have not put me in a position where I feel able to make any move in the matter that I am sure Senator Primmer or Senator Grimes would regard as positive. I still have the matter under consideration. That consideration has gone on for longer than I would have wished . . . At this stage I do not have anything positive to offer the honourable senator with respect to the matter raised by Senator Grimes last year.

I ask the Minister: Can he please do better now? I think we should remind him that the invalid pensioners in Australia whose cases have been reviewed in Australia and have appealed have had a 61 per cent success rate before the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and, I think, an 86 per cent success rate before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Finally, I emphasise that it took just one phone call from Canberra four years ago to stop those pensions being paid in Greece. Four years of inertia have passed and we still have not got the Government to take on board the notion that some of those people could have suffered a dreadful wrong at that time. Some people have demonstrated that they suffered a wrong at that time. It may be that legal problems are holding up the Government's considerations about cancelling these pensions. The Government may feel that they are ex-pensioners living outside the country and that, therefore, there is no legal obligation. I think there is certainly a moral obligation to reconsider the sad situation of these people. Senator Chaney's predecessor, the present Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), approved the action that was taken. These people have very few rights under the Greek social security system. They worked in this country, paid taxes and had rights under our social security system. A large percentage of those who have managed to return to this country have demonstrated that their pensions were removed wrongly. We should treat them as we treat citizens of this country because they are our responsibility. Until we do so this whole situation will remain an unfortunate stain on our system as it exists now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to Senator Grimes that the situation has not advanced beyond the position it was in when I spoke in response to Senator Primmer.
