The position broadly is that there is no legal right to a payment in the cases which he has raised. He has raised it this afternoon in the context of there being some moral right to payment. Part of the reason why the matter has not advanced further is that either I or the senior officer most closely involved in this matter have been away and have not had the opportunity to confer further. I envisage we will have an opportunity to do so in the coming weeks. The position with the bulk of those claims is that there would be no entitlement under Australian law. We are not dealing here with grace and favour payments; we are dealing with entitlements under the social security legislation. I think there are very significant difficulties. They are difficulties which I am still addressing.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditures agreed to.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the votes contained in Group H be now passed without requests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to place on record the fact that Estimates Committee H, when considering the Supplementary Estimates, adopted the principle of contacting all the members of the Committee and asking them to list the areas on which they required information. That list was provided to the departments concerned. We were able to deal with the questions in an excellent manner. We requested that officers not attend unless they were asked for, but of course, this matter rests with the departments and the Minister. Apart from one officer who was held up because of a problem with an airline schedule from New Zealand, we had every one we required. The answers we received at the session have never been better and the expediency of the operation in general was absolutely first class.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past I may not have been the easiest person to satisfy at Estimates committee hearings. I think it is only right that, under these sorts of circumstances, credit should be given and given freely where it is due. At the conclusion of the meeting there were only 11 matters on which we required additional information. All that information has come to hand. I suggest to honourable senators who have not yet been able to get round to reading the most interesting report we put together that that practice be adopted by other committees. I recommend to anybody who is interested in the relationship with New Zealand and the closer economic relations proposal that they read the 84- page summary of the matters involved. I would like to thank the officers, the Ministers and the Committee members for the manner in which they co-operated to make it an extremely valuable exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that Senator Archer wanted to be the last speaker in the Committee. On behalf of the Government, although without the imprimatur of the Government, I thank the Committee for the initiative it has shown in this area. I think it has always been of concern to honourable senators that often we have a large number of advisers here who are of no particular interest to the Committee but who are needed in order to cover the field should questions arise unexpectedly. I commend the attention of the Senate to the experience of Estimates Committee H. It seems to be a most worthwhile further development in our approach to Estimates committees. I acknowledge the points made by Senator Archer in Committee this afternoon and trust they will be considered by other Senate Estimates committees.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditures agreed to.
Schedule agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported without requests, but with two recommendations; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Chaney) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 28 April, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise the following matter during the second reading debate of Appropriation Bill (No. 4), although I suppose I could have left discussion until the Committee stage. I am concerned that in this Bill under the heading of 'Primary Industry' an amount of $3m is mentioned as the discharge of the obligations incurred under the Co-operative Farmers and Graziers Direct Meat Supply Ltd (Loan Guarantee) Act 1978. When the Bill was passed through the Parliament on 12 April 1978 Senator Wriedt was then the Leader of the Opposition and spokesman for the Opposition on this matter. He saw fit to sound some very grave warnings about this loan being agreed to. He moved an amendment which was defeated on a vote. Only one amendment was taken to a vote and it was defeated. I make mention of that amendment which was defeated in the Committee stage. It relates to clause 5. Senator Wriedt stated:

SPEECH.PARA: After paragraph (c), insert the following paragraph:
(ca) the State of Victoria appoints a full-scale inquiry into the operations of the society in order to ascertain the precise reasons for its current financial difficulties;

That amendment was put to a vote and was defeated. Quite a few honourable senators from our side of the chamber spoke on this legislation as did honourable senators from the other side, for example, Senator Wright and Senator Tehan. They sounded grave warnings about the need for this legislation to be passed. Senator Wriedt, Senator Walsh, Senator Primmer and I spoke on this. We all sounded grave warnings about taxpayers' money being made available-$4.5m from the Commonwealth and $4.5m from the Victorian Government. There was quite a bit of publicity about the matter. That was so even at a later stage when Mr Smith, who I think was then Minister of Agriculture in Victoria, made a statement at a Liberal conference to the effect that the Victorian Government was caught in a bind by the then Whitlam Government because there was an election in the offing and it wanted to win votes. That matter got quite a lot of publicity in the Press. We on this side of the chamber spoke at some length on the matter.

Today I looked back through the Hansard record of the debate that took place when the Bill was before the Senate. I am sorry that Senator Messner is not here because he puts himself up as somewhat of an expert, as an accountant, on financial matters. I will quote what he said in relation to the Co-operative Farmers and Graziers Direct Meat Supply Ltd which was the company getting the loan. On page 1213 of the Senate Hansard of 12 April Senator Messner said:

I understand from the information available to me that this Co-operative has had a very chequered career and is a worthwhile organisation. We should at least give it a chance to see whether it can pay its way in the next few years. It seems to me that the Co-operative, which has as many as 10,000 shareholders in Victoria and some from my own State of South Australia, has proved that it is capable of making a profit.

Of course, Senator Messner's words on that occasion have since been proved to be quite wrong. The company was not capable of making a profit. Now the Government has been called on to make a final payout. I expect that this is what the amount of money is for. I will ask a question as to whether this will be the final payout. During the course of the debate on the Bill the speakers on this side of the chamber expressed concern not only on behalf of those 10,000 shareholders but also on behalf of all the other shareholders-the taxpayers of Australia. They were being called on to provide $9m to fund this operation. We were a bit sceptical about that. That was the reason why Senator Wriedt moved the amendment calling on the Government to conduct a full-scale inquiry into the operation of the company in order to ascertain the precise reasons for its then current financial difficulties. Of course, the company went from bad to worse. Now the taxpayers of Australia are being called on in this Bill, as I read it, to find $ 3m. I will not take the matter any further. Everything was well documented in the debates which took place here on 12 April 1978 and again in the Senate in the early hours of the morning of 22 November 1979 in the debate on Appropriation bills. The matter was discussed at some length then. I hope I can get an answer at the end of the second reading debate rather than having to pursue in the Committee stages the question of whether the $3m provided in this Bill is to be a final payout or whether we can expect to be called upon at some later stage to find more money to close off this very unsuccessful financial venture.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as I know there is no further financial obligation. This amount of money is the discharge of the obligation that was incurred. To my knowledge no other expenditure of money is envisaged. I would need to refer the matters raised by Senator McLaren to deal with them in absolute terms. As far as I know the Bill before us represents the discharge of the obligations. That is all the information I am able to provide. We had no knowledge that Senator McLaren had some interest in this matter. At this time we are not able to provide any further information.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 May, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Services Legislation Amendment Bill 1982 is not opposed by the Australian Labor Party although we will move an amendment at the end of the second reading debate to add certain words. It is appropriate that the former Minister for Social Security, the present Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), is in the chamber at the moment. She used to get her social security Bills passed when she was the Minister. Her successor, Senator Chaney, has had a little difficulty in doing so. However, for once we do not have any major objections to legislation on social security.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation precludes temporary residents of Australia, such as diplomats, defence personnel of other countries and some other foreign residents, from claiming family allowances and similarly prohibits illegal immigrants from claiming family allowances on behalf of their children. It provides that a person who registers as unemployed with the Commonwealth Employment Service and makes a claim for unemployment benefit within 14 days of that registration will be deemed to have made the claim on the date of registration. It provides that where a person claims sickness benefit in respect of a period of sickness, the cause of which was connected with a previous sickness for which the person received a benefit, the sickness benefit is paid from the day on which the incapacity for work commenced-therefore preventing repeated application of the 7 -day waiting rule. It amends the Social Services Act to remove difficulties and deficiencies which arose from the 1979 amendment of the legislation in reclaiming double payments arising from sickness and compensation payments. There is a series of other formal technical and machinery amendments of lesser importance although the standardisation of the specific notification of change of circumstances for families receiving the handicapped children's allowance may cause some concern in the future.

Before dealing with the essence of the legislation, I do as I have done before and make a plea for the consolidation and simplification where possible of this cumbersome Social Services Act. It has been added to, amended and deleted from over the years and can be a minefield for experienced legal counsel and bureaucrats, let alone members of parliament and those it is designed to help. Consolidated copies are hard to come by even, I understand, in the Department of Social Security. The fact that many of the technical amendments are overdue by many years is a reflection of the difficulty in keeping the legislation up to date. I think it is beyond time that some consideration was given to a proper, overall look at the legislation. Senator Chaney, who is now in the chamber, being a lawyer will undoubtedly do this at night after he goes home to relax, considering the new sitting hours.

We do not oppose the changes which are made in this legislation but we will be moving an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill flagging some deficiencies in the provision of family allowances and compensation referred to in this legislation. We could, of course, have listed all the serious deficiencies in the provisions of social services in this country-things like the inadequate levels of benefits; the harshness of the income test and fringe benefits, particularly the discrimination against the single unemployed and the young unemployed; the harshness of the present application of the invalid pension parameters; and a large number of other deficiencies-but time limits and the Standing Orders would prevent a reasoned debate if those subjects were listed in what would be almost an endless amendment. Hence, the amendment is, in fact, a limited one.

There is clearly no justification for the Australian taxpayer paying family allowances to foreign diplomats, to visitors or to foreign military personnel, who frequently get many other benefits, both directly from the Australian taxpayer and through revenue forgone because of the privileges afforded to such people by the Government and, therefore, the Australian taxpayer. Therefore, we certainly do not oppose that section of the legislation. One can, I suppose, justify the non-payment of such benefits essentially to the children of prohibited immigrants though the number in this case must be pretty small. In light of the fact that no attack on the prohibited immigrant who later on is made legal in this country by reclaiming prior payments is included in the legislation, on balance, we support this provision though we are rather uneasy, I must admit, about the target apparently being the innocent children of such immigrants. It is interesting that in the past when we have brought up the matter of paying family allowances, particularly since family allowances were introduced in exchange for the old child endowment and tax rebates, we have questioned the fact that these were paid to diplomats and others in those circumstances. I wonder whether the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney ) can tell us why it has taken so long for the Government to take action in this regard. But as I said before, we certainly do not oppose the legislation.

The change in the legislation affecting unemployment benefits is also worth supporting. There are difficulties through postal delays, through the fact that officers of the different departments are in different towns and through the confusion which is created by what is a fairly complicated form which results in delays of days and sometimes weeks for a person who is unemployed and who has applied for assistance with employment. We believe that the introduction of the 14-day period of grace which can be extended in unusual circumstances is a sensible change and we have no objection to it. We hope, of course, that the Department will be flexible in the extension of what it sees as 'unusual circumstances' so that the aim of the legislation-and the aim of the Parliament in supporting the legislation-is carried through. Similarly, the change in the legislation regarding sickness benefit, whereby people who have chronic or recurrent illnesses will not have to make a series of applications resulting in repeated 7-day waiting periods because of recurrence of the illness or because of related illness, is something we do not oppose. I hope that the definition of 'associated illness', 'consequential illness' or 'related illness' is applied with compassion and proper medical advice so that we do not have endless disputes on the matter. I am sure that most members of parliament and others who represent the disadvantaged in this situation will be keeping an eye on the application of this amendment. The technical changes as they refer to the change in circumstances of children and families receiving the handicapped children's allowance are reasonable, but again must be administered with compassion and flexibility. Parents of such children have a difficult time and sickness, the mere difficulty of caring for a handicapped child and other factors may delay notification. We hope that not too much rigidity is applied in this amended form of the legislation.

The difficult section of the Bill lies in the vexed question of the relationship between sickness benefit and compensation payments. It is dealt with in Part III and attempts to cope with a problem which causes a lot of stress to compensation claimants and those who counsel them, including members of parliament. I am sure that every member of parliament has frequently had to deal with irate constituents who are caught up in the confusion that exists in this area. The area is also subject to legal manipulations and contriving by both the lawyers of the claimants and the lawyers representing insurance companies frequently for the benefit of both sides.

I have some sympathy for the legal counsel and the Government in trying to cope with this area, and I am sure that the Minister shares that sympathy. It is obvious that the attempts made in 1979 were not adequately covered by the amendments made in that year. Senator Chaney and I spent some eight months with the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs looking at the whole compensation situation in this country and at the proposals of Mr Justice Woodhouse and his inquiry to introduce a national compensation scheme. We certainly ended up wiser about the situation after those eight months but we were probably even more confused in some areas than we were when we started.

The basic problem lies in the compensation system itself in this country, which is characterised by uncertainty of outcome, inordinate delays, legalistic confusion and high costs. The system causes much resentment amongst those who have to use it. It inhibits rehabilitation, as that Senate Committee was told over and over again by experts in the field, and as Mr Justice Woodhouse has pointed out. I believe that no amount of fiddling with the social services will fix that system. The delays in settling compensation claims which are so characteristic of the system of compensation in this country mean that many people spend considerable time, often unnecessarily, on sickness benefit while awaiting settlement of their claims one way or the other. I believe that there is no doubt that the knowledge that people receive sickness benefit, that they receive some assistance from the social security system, exacerbates the delays. A lack of urgency is felt by representatives of the litigants and particularly by those who are being sued.

This Bill attempts to overcome several technical problems which are inherent in the system. The social security system of sickness benefit, quite correctly, is not meant to supplement the compensation system but to complement it with the sickness benefit which acts as a sort of bridge. A no-fault system of the sort which exists in New Zealand, which is at present being modified in New Zealand and which provides immediate and adequate benefits would introduce some form of justice to the system and would overcome the problems that exist now, but to introduce such a system into our legal and constitutional state of affairs would be difficult, if not almost impossible. This is not to suggest that I support uncritically the proposal put forward by Mr Justice Woodhouse in his report; but I dare say that I would support some variation of it. Certainly, the Senate Committee which looked at that proposal found that very grave difficulties and inequities would have arisen if it had been introduced as suggested.

There are two proposals in this legislation which we hope will improve the present system of delays in settling the sickness benefit and compensation problem. The first concerns improving the gathering of information about the beneficiary's compensation entitlements and the second concerns the ability of the Director-General or his delegate to claim payments to cover previously paid sickness benefit from the payment rather than having to chase the compensated person. The inclusion of payments under the no-fault motor vehicle insurance schemes which exist at least in Victoria and Tasmania is also a desirable and sensible change and will provide justice to both the taxpayers and the recipients. There are provisions in the legislation for the compensated person to be informed of the claims for the recovery of sickness benefit and, most importantly, there is a provision for the Director-General to disregard payments in cases of need and special circumstances. That is a clause which should be handled carefully and, again, with considerable sympathy and compassion.

It is to be hoped that the changes enabling the Department to intercept the payments made to the claimant and to ensure that the claimant is informed of what is going on will preclude the need for the Director-General to use this discretion, but I agree that it is terribly important that the discretion should be there. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal, in a couple of judgments, has suggested that this should be so. My information is that the amount of sickness benefit reclaimed under the relevant section last year was about $5.6m. I would be interested if the Minister could give the Senate an estimate for future years in the light of these changes. I hope that he and the Government recognise the fact that in the context of the overall Budget it is certainly not a large amount of money. That is another reason for sympathetic interpretation by the Government. In the past there have been difficulties, as has been demonstrated by some of the successful appeals or appeals which resulted in critical remarks from the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
On behalf of the Opposition, I move the following amendment:
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that the Government should-
(a) increase family allowances for first and second children, thus removing the disadvantage affecting most Australian families with children, and
(b) provide a system of national compensaton to eliminate the excessive costs, delays and uncertainty which exists in the present system.'

I believe that that amendment speaks for itself but I wish to make some remarks about both of the subjects with which it deals. When the Government introduced its family allowance system in 1976-a system which the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and others described as the single most important reform in the Australian welfare system since Federation-one of its greatest attractions was said to be its simplicity, the simplicity of having a universal payment, a positive payment to all parents with dependent children, and of having it out in the open as a welfare payment instead of hidden as a taxation offset. This simplicity and this openness have enabled us to see how the government's policy of freezing the value of these payments has in fact compounded hardship and poverty in this country. The Minister has given the figure of $1,570m as the cost of family allowances had they been indexed. That is some $530m more than this year's Budget estimate. The Government is in fact saving $530m at the expense of young Australian families.

Since 1977 the Government has saved approximately $1.5 billion by not keeping family allowance payments in line with cost of living rises. When the family allowances were introduced-they were introduced at a time when the expectation of people was that there would be tax indexation-we pointed out that this may have been a means whereby these payments could have been frozen, whereas under a system of tax indexation the rebate for children, as it then was, would have had to be indexed. In fact, this has happened. I shall give some examples of how this freezing of family allowances with a limited increase in recent Budgets has affected the family budget. If the payments had been indexed, families with one child would have been receiving another $10.70 a month; families with two children, another $25.95 a month; those with three children, another $31.30 a month; those with four children, another $36.65 a month; and those with five children, another $42.85 a month.

It is not as though the Government was unaware of the inequities in this system . Its National Consultative Council on Social Welfare has raised the inequity of family allowances in each of its reports. The Social Welfare Policy Secretariat report on poverty measurement pointed out:

Couples with children are more likely than those without to have low incomes in relation to needs while sole parents are the neediest of groups. There are more couples with one or two children with low income in relation to their needs than couples with three children or more, although a greater proportion of the larger families has low incomes in relation to their needs.

In this last Budget the Government took the cheap way out. It totally ignored couples with one or two children, who constitute 74 per cent-three-quarters, essentially-of the families with young children. They got nothing. Larger families with three or more children got limited increases, and those increases cost at the time $89.6m.

In Melbourne at the Salvation Army a few weeks ago, Colonel Gordon Fischer consistently used the word 'frustration' in connection with his work with the most desperately poor people, the people who have to bury their pride and ask for handouts for their families. Most of these people are unemployed and most are single parent families. The frustration comes from the inability of any charitable organisation, with the best will in the world, to meet those needs. These people have increasing costs, and a large section of their increasing costs is the cost of parenthood, the cost of raising children. Some recognition, I suppose, of the costs of raising children was made in the 1976 Budget, but neglecting the inroads of inflation into family income has been a feature of subsequent Budgets.

In our amendment we are urging the Government to end this snub to young families and to recognise the additional costs of food, clothing, education needs and so on, which they have shouldered without the Government taking a sufficient share of the burden. The costs of parenthood are considerable. These costs have a greater effect on the income of families. But so often we hear that the increases should be in the area of the dependent spouse rebate, as if marriage itself was the great factor which increased the economic cost to families.

Similarly, our amendment mentions the inadequacies of the compensation system. I understand that Senator Haines will be moving an amendment to this section of the Labor Party's amendment. I imagine that we shall support that. We ask that the Government look again at providing a system of national compensation to eliminate the excessive costs, delays and uncertainties which exist in the present system. As I have said, that does not mean that we just want a holus- bolus introduction of the system suggested by Mr Justice Woodhouse. But after taxation, the big inhibiting factor-I find it so from correspondence to me-to people employing more workers is the cost of compensation premiums.

As long as we have a system in which the outcome is so uncertain, in which people with the same sorts of injuries and disabilities resulting from those injuries can get compensation varying from nil or the invalid pension to $1m, $ 2m, or $3m, as long as the system is such that cases get bogged down in the courts for years, and health costs and legal costs can eat about 50c in every dollar of compensation obtained, while we have a system in which lawyers and insurance companies find it necessary to create artificial schemes of settlement whereby for the period that people are eligible for sickness benefit they are given a dollar a week and for the rest of the time they are given lump sums or very much larger payments, and while we have the sorts of bargaining that we have to have in the area of compensation in the courts, I suggest that the system is not satisfactory. I do not believe that anyone on the committee on which I served, with the possible exception of former Senator Wright, believes that overall the present system is satisfactory.

If a conservative government in New Zealand-admittedly working from a lower base of social security payments-can introduce a reform whereby compensation can be streamlined and the costs reduced, we should look at it. If we cannot do it constitutionally as a Commonwealth Government, we should be looking at getting the co-operation of the States to introduce it on a national basis in that way. Already Tasmania and Victoria have introduced no-fault schemes for motor vehicle accidents. That is a step in the right direction. I understand that that system is to be introduced in the Australian Capital Territory. But we need it in a much more comprehensive way to avoid the uncertainties in the present system.

I have said that the Bill is an omnibus Bill. It aims at reducing some of the anomalies in the present Social Services Act. I should just like to make passing remarks about two inequities which have been raised before by many people in this place and which I believe will be raised again until the inequities are removed. Single parents who are in the unfortunate position of being on unemployment benefits are among the poorest groups in the community. Single parents on unemployment benefits rather than widows' pensions or supporting parent's benefits are in the worst position of all. There are about 2,418 in the country. Because they are on unemployment benefits only, they get no guardian's allowance, no fringe benefits, no pharmaceutical benefits, no transport concessions, no rent assistance, and no supplementary assistance. Most of them, I suspect, are families who do not satisfy the residency provisions for pensions . There is no reason to leave them in this situation.

For instance, a lone parent on unemployment benefit who has two children receives only $98.20 a week for the three of them, which has to pay for all rent , utilities, transport, clothing, food, and so on, for three people. At the last count, this put them $31.50 a week below the poverty line. The next Social Services Bill of this kind should, at the very least, make these families eligible for the guardian's allowance, and consideration should be given to extending to them the supplementary assistance and health benefits available to pensioners. This is an injustice, among many other injustices, which should not be allowed to exist.

Another anomaly is the absurd and unfair anomaly that the female spouses of invalid pensioners are eligible for a spouse's pension whereas a male spouse of a female invalid pensioner is not eligible. I believe that you have raised this matter yourself, Mr Acting Deputy President, on many occasions. Such a person must, if he wishes to give up work to look after an invalid wife, qualify for a special benefit, which again is a payment that is more strictly means tested and has no fringe benefit attachments. There are only a handful of these people. It is a disgrace that this anomaly is being perpetuated-to save, I assume, a few dollars. All this arises because of the complexity and complication in our system, but when these anomalies are picked up and known about, they really should be changed, and changed as soon as possible.

To sum up, we do not oppose the changes in this legislation. We move a second reading amendment flagging just two of the insufficiencies in the present system . We understand that an amendment will be moved by Senator Haines, and I can tell her now that I consider that we shall accept that amendment, but perhaps we shall talk about it briefly when she has moved it. We urge the Government to look at the whole of the legislation rather than consider it in a piecemeal manner as has been done in the past by all governments, I suppose. In this way we can have a legislation and a system which treat all people more fairly than they do now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: — In the interests of the smooth running of the Senate and being as aware as I am that the next lot of business is due to come on at 3.30 p.m., I shall attempt to be as brief as possible. Senator Grimes has, as has the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) in his second reading speech, already canvassed the main issues in this legislation, and I do not intend to do so again. The Australian Democrats have no objections to the changes inherent in this legislation; indeed we support them fully. Clearly it is anomalous, as Senator Grimes has already pointed out, that Australian taxpayers should support the children of diplomats, consuls, foreign defence personnel et cetera as well as other temporary residents in Australia whether they are prohibited or not. It is equally silly, to say nothing of financially damaging, for some people entitled to the unemployment or sickness benefit to be denied them because of an unintentional delay in applying for them or because of some other entanglement in red tape. The amendments in the Bill correcting these problems are sensible and even if they affect, as Senator Grimes also pointed out, only a small group of people they are nevertheless in our eyes worthwhile. Similar comments can be made about the amendments relating to the provision of the handicapped children's allowance when the child moves out of the home in which he or she was being looked after.

SPEECH.PARA: The major changes proposed by the Bill and the ones which are the most complex are those clauses amending section 39 of the Social Services Act 1979 which were never proclaimed but which were in fact intended to repeal section 115 of the Social Services Act 1947. Section 115 currently provides the means whereby an amount of compensation, paid or payable to a person who is, or is qualified to be, or was, a sickness beneficiary in respect of the same incapacity, is brought to account. The provision reflects the principle that a person should not retain both sickness benefits paid in respect of an incapacity and compensation paid in respect of the same incapacity. In essence, the person has the rate of the sickness benefit reduced or is required to repay the amount, or part of the amount, of sickness benefit received to take account of the payment or right to payment of compensation from a third party. The intended effect is that there be no 'double payment' in respect of the same incapacity, and that is a fair enough aim.

The section does, as the Minister stated in his second reading speech, have a number of shortcomings which have been exploited to circumvent the recovery provisions defined in the section, and this legislation aims to correct these. To remove these deficiencies, shortcomings and anomalies, the Government has introduced a series of amendments, for which action, as I have said, the Government is to be commended. The amendments streamline the legislation, speed up the processes generally and add a human element in the extension of the discretionary role of the Director-General as far as the sickness benefit and compensation payments are concerned. As long as all these things operate to the advantage of the beneficiary they are, of course, to be applauded. We have all heard of people who have been financially disadvantaged by the system, inadvertently, by the delaying tactic of some of the more venal lawyers around the place who are perhaps more interested in building up their bank balances or indulging in nice intellectual debate or by the rigid application of the letter of the law rather than the spirit of it. If this legislation can prevent those things from happening then the Democrats, as does the Labor Party, support it fully.

This brings me briefly to the Opposition's amendment to the Government's motion that the Bill be now read a second time. The first part of the Opposition's amendment is commonly known around this place somewhat cynically as a motherhood motion, perhaps more precisely than some of those which go by that name since it refers to an increase in family allowances for first and second children. Again, the Democrats support this contention. I suppose I ought to declare that I have a vested interest. I have only two children, and most parents with two children will tell you that the first and second children are the ones who engender the maximum expense particularly when they happen to be one of each variety.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about hand-me-downs?

—Clothes cannot be handed down when children are one of each variety. These days perhaps there is more chance of that happening than there used to be, but I do not encourage it. It may be that to accommodate the increase in allowances for first and second children some sort of means test must be applied so that those in most need receive the most increase. I believe that as long as the means test is a reasonable one and is automatically indexed there can be no philosophic argument against it if the country's financial position of course is so parlous as to require it.

SPEECH.PARA: The second part of the Opposition's amendment is also reasonable in concept but I believe it does not go far enough. It is not sufficiently precise particularly in view of the remarks made by Dr Blewett in another place relating to the Woodhouse Committee recomendations. For that reason I propose to move an amendment to paragraph (b) of the Opposition's amendment which seeks to amend the motion for the second reading. I therefore move:
Leave out paragraph (b) of the words proposed to be added, insert the following paragraph:

'(b) provide a system of national compensation, as recommended by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, which is designed to eliminate excessive costs, delays and uncertainty of the present system, but which does not incorporate the more extreme proposals of the Woodhouse Report.'.

I do this because the Democrats, who have already both in this chamber and outside it indicated full support for the concept of a national portable contributory superannuation scheme, also have no philosophic objection to the implementation of a national compensation scheme. Senator Grimes mentioned a no- fault car accident scheme. I would also like to mention the fact that the number of sporting accidents not covered by any form of insurance is, if nothing else, sufficient reason for looking at the concept of a national compensation scheme. Having said that I must make the point that we are no more happy about the Woodhouse Committee report or the 1974 draft Bill which followed it than we were with the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs which inquired into that Bill and reported in July 1975.

Briefly in the last few minutes I would like to refer to some of the comments made by members of that Committee. There was an addendum at page 189 of the report by Senators Chaney, Missen and Wright which states:
There are a number of reasons detailed in the Committee Report which in our view, preclude the Bill achieving the theoretically laudible objectives of the Woodhouse Committee to provide:
' . . . a universal and comprehensive scheme designed to alleviate the problems of persons afflicted by any physical or mental incapacity . . .

I will not go into the rest of it in great detail, but that feeling was shared to a considerable extent by Senators Button and Grimes who also made the point that they found some aspects of the Woodhouse Committee proposal for implementing the concept of national compensation superficial and believed that if the Bill were amended in accordance with the Committee's recommendations many of those difficulties would be overcome. Senator Chaney went further and added an additional comment of his own, again pointing out that rather than persisting with the present national Compensation Bill it would be preferable to develop a constitutionally sound alternative in co-operation with the States to improve the fairness, justice and efficiency of the provision of benefits to persons suffering injury or sickness.

The legislation before us today is commendable in that it is a genuine attempt to remove certain anomalies which exist in the present system, and we are happy to support it. Nevertheless, as Senator Grimes has also pointed out, some inequities still exist in the social services area. A number of them, if not all , would be removed if family allowances for first and second children were increased and if a national compensation scheme were introduced along the lines of the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in 1975. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard three addenda to which I have referred.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
Addendum 2
ADDENDUM BY SENATORS BUTTON AND GRIMES

We have read the addendum prepared by the Chairman and we agree with most of the conclusions which he reaches. For reasons of emphasis and style, we prefer however, to state our conclusions in the following way:
(1) We accept the fundamental concept of the Woodhouse Committee Report and the National Compensation Bill.
(2) We consider the implementation of that concept as socially desirable, necessary and indeed inevitable.
(3) We find some aspects of the Woodhouse Committee's proposals for implementing the concept of 'National Compensation' superficial, and we believe this is reflected in the Bill.

(4) If the Bill is amended in accordance with the Committee's recommendations many of these difficulties would be overcome. We remain concerned, however, with matters such as the enormous ramifications of Clause 50 of the Bill and the relationship between 'the scheme' and other social welfare programmes.
The Government must resolve these problems without delay.
(5) Subject to the qualifications expressed in the last two paragraphs we specifically adopt the views of the Chairman on the following matters:
(a) the need to proceed with the injury part of the scheme,
(b) the need to seek appropriate powers to implement such a scheme in the event of a constitutional challenge succeeding.
Addendum 3
ADDENDUM BY SENATORS CHANEY, MISSEN AND WRIGHT
There are a number of reasons detailed in the Committee Report which in our view, preclude the Bill achieving the theoretically laudible objectives of the Woodhouse Committee to provide:

. . . a universal and comprehensive scheme designed to alleviate the problems of persons afflicted by any physical or mental incapacity that has a significant and adverse effect upon the quality of their lives. Its essential purpose will be to provide a form of social insurance in respect of every risk to life and limb during the whole 24 hours of every day.' (Paragraph 344 (a))
Other matters render the proposed scheme impracticable.
The major problems we see are:
1. The constitutional doubt as to its validity, particularly in relation to the abolition of common law rights.
2. The need for State co-operation (unlikely to occur) to enable its effective operation.

3. The need for a solution to the problem of double payments particularly arising in respect to superannuation schemes which are beyond the powers of the Commonwealth and which would require State legislation. It is fairly clear that this is not to be forthcoming.

4. The uncertainty of the costing of the scheme, particularly the sickness part of the scheme. The knowledge that many of the clauses (and discretions contained within them) have not been, in any satisfactory way, costed by the proponents of the scheme, or of the Bill.
5. The effect of increased government expenditure and of the dislocation of investment patterns on the insurance industry and the national economy, particularly at a time of economic stress.
6. The effect on State government finances and on the finances of semi- government authorities.

7. The failure of the Government to finalise, or to propose to the Parliament, any method of financing the Scheme and the failure of the Government in evidence before the Committee to disclose any real consideration or conclusions as to the economic effects of the alternative methods of financing.

8. The fact that the implementation of the national compensation scheme may hinder the appropriate resolution of such disputed priorities and may lead to substantial increased expenditure for the purpose of upgrading other welfare programmes or to the neglect of programmes more vital to the relief of poverty.

9. The tremendous expense involved in the application of Clause 50 of the Bill to medical and paramedical expenses and losses, or alternatively the injustice of depriving beneficiaries, especially employees, of compensation for medical and hospital expenses outside Medibank and the failure to resolve whether or not such expenditures will or will not be covered under the Bill.
10. The complete absence of provisions in the Bill for safety and rehabilitation which were, according to the Woodhouse Report, the primary purposes of the Scheme.
11. The indication of objections to the Bill by the Trade Union Movement and other substantial organisations and the failure to resolve their major objections to the Bill.
12. The deficiencies in the Bill in respect of widows, persons over 65 years of age, and young persons who are denied proper remedies under the Bill.
(2) Constitutional Power
The extreme doubt about the constitutional power of the Commonwealth Parliament to enact this legislation is of fundamental importance and must, in itself, weigh against the passage of the Bill.

In Chapter III of the Report, reference is made to the opinion of three Queen's Counsel, Mr F. G. Brennan, Q.C. of Brisbane, Mr A. M. Gleeson, Q.C. of Sydney and Mr R. E. McGarvie, Q.C. of Melbourne, all of whom expressed the view that Clause 97 of the Bill (which is the vital Clause removing common law rights) does not have constitutional validity. All counsel expressed the view that the Clause, which is vital to the Bill, was beyond the legislative power of the Australian Parliament. IT does not come within any of the specific powers granted to the Commonwealth, nor is it within the 'incidental' power of the Australian Parliament. It is therefore likely to fail if challenged. Similar views were expressed by a number of witnesses before the Committee. It was clearly apparent that many State Governments had been so advised and that the Bill, if enacted, would be challenged in the High Court.

It is true that, at an earlier stage, the Australian Government obtained advice from Mr M. H. Byers, Q.C. the Solicitor-General, contrary to that given to the Committee by the three counsel previously referred to (see Appendix C) In his written opinion Mr Byers dealt with a number of the Clauses of the Bill. He expressed the view that Clause 97 (i) and (ii) (then Clause 91 (i) and (ii)) was -
'valid to the extent that they operate as conditions of the grant of the benefit'.
He stated at page 13 of his Opinion that-

'it would be clear enough that a provision requiring of the beneficiary surrender of his common law or Workers Compensation rights before either receipt of a payment or entitlement to a payment arise, would be a law with respect to the provision of the benefit. I do not think there is any substantial difference between that class of law and the one here in question'.

In our opinion there is a great deal of difference between the two matters. This is not a case of the surrender of any rights voluntarily but it is a provision of benefits which the claimant must either 'take or leave'. Under the provision of this Bill, once there is a benefit specified under the Bill, the claimant loses his entire rights at common law and can either take or refuse the benefit. If he manages, by some method, to receive common law damages then he is required, by Clause 98 of the Bill, to repay it to the Commonwealth.
Mr Byers acknowledged that-
'it is no doubt true, or may be true, to say that the law with respect to the provision of benefits may not authorise an enactment compelling their acceptance '.
But he then concluded-

'Nonetheless I think that the provision is valid as providing what in substance is a condition by reference to which the Parliament confers the benefit. I do not think that in any legal sense it makes receipt of the benefit become compulsory.'

We find the argument in no way convincing. We would suggest that, in essence, this removal of common law rights is not a condition of taking a benefit but, in reality, the claimant has no alternative rights. If the benefit is not taken up, the common law right is still abrogated.

The other opinions obtained by the Committee reject the proposal that the provisions of this vital Clause 97 can be justified under the insurance of social services power, or that it is merely a condition of the grant of a benefit, or incidental to any of the existing powers.
Mr F. G. Brennan, Q.C. (at page 19 of his Opinion), says-

'To give effect to power to provide a benefit for a person it is not necessary to take away or sterilise that person's enforceable right to compensation. The legislative taking away or sterilising of a right of compensation is unrelated to the provision of a benefit'.
Mr R. E. McGarvie, Q.C., at paragraphs 24, 34 and 35 of his Opinion concludes-

24. 'In my opinion Clause 97 would not, upon enactment, be a law with respect to the provision by the Commonwealth of sickness benefits or widows' pensions. Its operation is to abolish rights to damages or other compensation where a benefit is provided by the Commonwealth. Further, in my opinion, Clause 97 is not a law with respect to something which is incidental to the provision by the Commonwealth of sickness benefits or widows' pensions nor is it a law with respect to a matter incidental to the execution by the Parliament of its power to legislate on these subject matters.'

34. 'In summary, it is my view that, except for periodical payments falling within the description of invalid pensions, there is no legislative power to achieve the results which Clause 97 is designed to achieve. The Australian Parliament could not validly legislate to abolish rights under state law to workers' compensation rights outside the description of invalid pensions or to abolish rights under state law to common law damages.'
35. 'In my opinion, the Australian Parliament does not have constitutional power to enact Clause 97 of the National Compensation Bill 1974 and the Clause, if enacted, would be invalid.'

We hold the view that it is highly unlikely that this legislation would pass the scrutiny of the High Court. This leads inescapably to the conclusion that the Parliament should not persist in a course which endeavours to abrogate common law rights. The suggestion of a delay in the proclamation of the Bill to enable the High Court challenge to be heard is unsatisfactory and wasteful of the community's resources. There is no doubt that, in the meanwhile, the Department would be expanded and moneys would be spent to no purpose.
Addendum 4
ADDENDUM BY SENATOR CHANEY

I agree with the Committee view expressed in paragraph 1.21 of the Committee report that existing compensation systems are random in their coverage, often provide inadequate compensation and can give rise to inequities. Undoubtedly a better system must be found. Rather than persisting with the present National Compensation Bill, it would be preferable to develop a constitutionally sound alternative. This requires making every effort, in co-operation with the States, to improve the fairness, justice and efficiency of the provision of benefits to persons suffering injury or sickness.

My attitude to the recommendations made in the body of the Senate Committee's Report must be read in the light of this Addendum. If the current National Compensation Bill is to proceed and receive a Second Reading in the Senate, then I concur with the great majority of recommendations contained in the Senate Committee's Report as they would substantially improve the Bill and remove anomalies and injustices. But my basic recommendation is for the withdrawal of the Bill and the development of a proper system of compensation in co-operation with the States, which have shown in their submissions to this Committee a readiness to adopt new approaches.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3.30 p.m., under sessional order the Senate will now proceed to the consideration of committee reports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the consideration of committee reports be postponed until after the further consideration of the Social Services Legislation Amendment Bill 1982.
I do that, undertaking to respond very briefly to the points which have been made in the debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak briefly to the amendment moved by Senator Haines. The Australian Labor Party accepts this amendment. It gives me the opportunity to make it quite clear, as I did before, that when I speak of national compensation I do not speak of the proposal in toto which was put down by Mr Justice Woodhouse on the occasion when, along with five lawyers, I was a member of that learned committee. I came to realise, as did the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), Senator Button, Senator Everett, Senator Wright and Senator Missen, the difficulties and the excesses inherent in the proposals of Mr Justice Woodhouse. On signing that report, I did not endear myself, nor did the rest of us, to the Prime Minister of the day. However, all of us remained, I think, fairly firm in the belief of the need for a considerable reform in the compensation system in this community. As Senator Haines's amendment expresses that and makes it clear that we do not agree with the more extreme proposals of the Woodhouse report, the Opposition certainly accepts her amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to thank the Opposition and the Australian Democrats for their support for the provisions contained in the Social Services Legislation Amendment Bill. Essentially the Bill tries to remove some anomalies from the existing legislation. In addition I believe it is a first step along the track that Senator Grimes requested us to follow when he sought a consolidation of the Social Services Act. There are a great number of amendments which tidy the Act and will make it a lot more understandable to the people who have to use it and who are meant to benefit from it. In that sense, quite apart from the actual amendments of substance which are included, I would expect it to be beneficial. The Bill does provide for some minor savings by way of the removal of anomalies. The number of diplomats who receive the family allowance for their children, I understand, is quite small. But it has been an inappropriate provision within our law and it is good that it is to be removed. The amount of savings will be small.

SPEECH.PARA: In the field of the sickness benefit, I am not able to give an estimate that I would regard as reliable to Senator Grimes in response to his request about the amount of additional savings which might accrue. He has put forward the figure of $5.6m on the savings which will be brought about by the existing provision. I note his caution that one would want a humane administration of this provision. I can only say that I believe the people who administer my Department in the main are anxious to administer the discretionary provisions in a way which is beneficial and helpful to the people with whom they are dealing. The debate has really centred on the amendments which have been moved by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. The Opposition having now accepted the Democrats' amendment I should perhaps indicate to the Senate that, whilst we will be voting against the Labor Party's amendment, as would be expected, I do propose to support the Democrat amendment to the Labor Party's amendment for the sorts of reasons which have been explained by Senator Haines and Senator Grimes.

The Woodhouse proposals were subjected to considerable scrutiny in this place. As it happens, both Senator Grimes and I were part of that scrutiny. I think we would be at one in saying that the suggestions of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs do represent considerable advances on the original proposal that was put forward in the draft legislation. For that reason , were any motion passed I would prefer it to be passed in the terms of the amendment moved by Senator Haines on behalf of the Democrats.

I now put the Government's position regarding the two amendments. The first leg of the amendment calls for an increase in the family allowance for first and second children. In opposing the amendment, I do not for a moment oppose the fact that it would be a good thing to provide additional assistance for one- child and two-child families. The decision was taken in the Budget context last year to provide assistance for third and subsequent children only, because there was a limited amount of money available to add to the pool which goes out in the family allowance area. The cost of making provisions for third and subsequent children was a cost that we felt was within the proper budgetary limits. It was a burden that we were prepared to lay upon the Australian taxpayers because, of course, they are the people who pay for it. We were not prepared to have an additional impost of $368m which is what would have been required had we also extended the benefits to the first and second child.

I make the truism that it is not the Government's money that we are allocating in this case; it is, of course, the money of the people of Australia-the taxpayers' money. We did not feel able to raise additional taxes or incur a further deficit to the extent of another $368m. I note that the amendment seeks to record a view of the Senate that we should be concerned about the position of families with one or two children as well as the position of families with three or more children. I would merely say in defence of the selection of three or more children that, quite apart from the economic factors, the fact is that families with three and more children are more likely to be in difficulty and economic hardship than smaller families. To that extent there is a good welfare reason for the differentiation that was made.

On the second point regarding the system of national compensation, I would be the first to admit that there are gaps and at times great inconsistencies between compensation systems. Clearly there are imperfections. I do not think that any honourable senator would underrate the difficulty in producing a non- complex, simple and uniform scheme for the whole of Australia. The trade union movement, which has a very great interest in the workers compensation scheme, would be very reluctant to see that interfered with unless it was absolutely certain that what was being replaced had the very great benefits which have been achieved by the trade union movement over the years for those people who are injured at work. This is a matter of great complexity. The Government did have some consultations with the States on 1976 and 1977 but little progress was made in those discussions. At this stage I do not think there is a very realistic prospect of a national scheme emerging as a matter of agreement between those other responsible governments, namely, the State governments and the Commonwealth Government. For that reason basically, the Government will oppose the amendment while thanking the Senate for the support which it has given to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had understood that the debate on the Social Services Legislation Amendment Bill would conclude at 3.30 p.m. I had not been given any prior warning that there would be an extension of time. The motion passed by the Senate enables this legislation to pass through the Senate today. The Senate Order of Business paper stated quite specifically that the debate would conclude at 3.30 p.m. I was clearly of that view. Therefore, I was engaged in an in-depth discussion and consideration of the Bill to amend the powers of the Senate which will be coming up later on today. After all, the measure, which has been proposed by the Government, is not opposed in any shape or form by the Opposition. Those honourable senators who have spoken thus far seem to be heatedly in agreement concerning its provisions. The only matters of contention appear to be the additions to the motion that the Bill be read a second time. In this regard, I am in a cleft stick. I agree with part of the proposition, namely, that relating to family allowances, but I am not altogether enamoured of the second proposition, namely, that a system of national compensation, as recommended by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, should be provided. I am a little diffident about that for the very reason that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) has just given.

SPEECH.PARA: The trade union movement throughout Australia, because of its close interest in the issue of workers' compensation, would be very concerned to be assured that its members would, in no sense, suffer a loss of rights as a result of the introduction of a system of national compensation. I recall that I had lengthy discussions with a former Minister for Social Security, Senator Wheeldon, about this very issue. I believe that we were reaching the point at which such an understanding could have been achieved. In the absence of the Senate being provided with details of a particular measure which would ensure that the trade union movement, and workers generally, would not be disadvantaged, insofar as workers' compensation rights were concerned, by the introduction of a national compensation scheme, I would be hesitant to support the Senator Grimes proposal as amended by Senator Haines's proposal. Therefore, I am not able to vote against the amendment as such but would like to vote for half of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to Senator Harradine's foreshadowed amendment. The Opposition moved what I thought was a fairly simple amendment relating to one aspect of the inadequacies of the family allowance system and to the lack of fairness and justice in the national compensation system. Senator Haines clarified that amendment somewhat by pointing out that this Senate would not agree with the excesses of the Woodhouse proposal. DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 May, on motion by Senator Sibraa:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 May 1982 I presented the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence entitled 'The Gulf and Australia'. On that occasion I spent some time talking about the main recommendations of the report so I do not intend to spend a great deal of time this afternoon on them. However, some important points ought to be made at this time. I say this because I am very pessimistic about the continuing war between Iraq and Iran. It is the forgotten war, it is the war that is being allowed to continue and it is the war that it seems nobody can stop. One Western view that has a lot of currency is that the war is good for the United States of America, it is good for Israel and it is also good for the West. But I believe that the war contains a conflict that could engulf the Middle East and eventually pose a greater threat to world peace than the Arab-Israeli conflict. I see this conflict as a battle between the Islamic fundamentalists, whom I call 'the mediaevals', and the twentieth century Arabs. It is a war that is already spilling over the boundaries of Iraq and Iran. It is already ignoring the traditional left or right labels on the regimes in the area. It is ignoring previous loyalties to either the Eastern or Western blocs and what I think is perhaps more serious is that it is slowly involving the super-powers in a conflict between the countries that have the second and third largest oil reserves in the world. I believe that this should be a worry to all of us.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, this war ignores previous loyalties. At the moment Iraq is being supported financially by the Gulf States and by Saudi Arabia. It was estimated in February this year that already the Gulf States and Saudi Arabia had poured $ US30 billion into Iraq to support it during the war. It is also being supported by Jordan, which has sent a volunteer brigade to fight on the Iraqi side, and it is being supported by conservative Arab regimes such as the one in Oman. On 23 February 1982, in a debate in the Senate, I said:
Even Egypt says that it sides with Iraq in the war; if Iraq's borders are threatened it will sell arms to that country.

We have seen recently that Egypt has taken sides in the war following the return of the Sinai. Egypt has taken a very active role in this conflict. It is selling arms to Iraq and obviously it is doing that because it believes that Iran and obviously it is doing that because it believes that Iran is posing a threat to the borders of Iraq. Also, we have recently seen the United States of America remove Iraq from the list of countries embargoed from receiving United States military equipment. I think we ought to ask ourselves why that decision has been taken. I am sure that the United States is aware of the increased Soviet influence in Iran. In the speech I made in February, to which I referred, I said that reports at that time suggested that 2,000 to 4,000 Soviet military advisers were in Iran. Recent estimates are that 5,000 military advisers are helping the Iranian forces. The United States is also concerned because Syria, which is aligned to Moscow and is probably the most pro-Moscow State in the Arab world, now supports Iran. It is the one Arab country to support it.

We have to ask ourselves why these countries are taking the particular views that they are. Why are they supporting the particular countries they are supporting at the moment? Why is a group of conservative Arab countries supporting Iraq? Why, for instance, is the Gulf Co-operative Council-a body I am sure we will hear a lot more of in the future-holding joint Defence Ministers meetings at the moment? I think the answer is that those conservative Arab countries believe that the Iranian leaders are becoming the terrorists of the Gulf. They believe that the Iranian leadership at the moment is trying to export its fundamentalist revolution to the Shi'ite minority populations throughout the Arab world. If we want to see an example of this we have only to look at what happened in Bahrain recently when it was proved that the attempted coup was Iranian sponsored. The people who were arrested, the people concerned in that attempted coup, had got their weapons and their training in Iran.

Since the speech that I made on 23 February the military balance has changed in the Gulf war. At that stage Iraq was being seen to be successful. At the moment the military opinion would be that Iran has reversed the previous trend and in fact is pressing on the borders of Iraq. Iran is doing this despite the horrendous casualties it has recieved. It was reported earlier this year that between 90,000 and 100,000 troops had been either killed or captured. There were reports that Khomeini's revolutionary guards were armed only with pieces of paper given to them by the Mullahs that were supposed to ward off bullets. The Jordanians described these pieces of paper as transit visas to heaven. These revolutionary guards were storming the Iraqi positions and being followed up by Iranian troops. One has only to see the claims being made at the moment about the battle for Khorramshahr which the Ayatollah Khomeini has called the city of blood. Apparently in this battle, which is taking place at the moment, the Iranians have pushed thousands of teenage troops behind the city to stop any retreat by the Iraqi forces at present inside the city. It is only in the last three or four days that reports of that battle have suggested that the Iraqi forces in one particular push killed over 22,000 of these young revolutionary guards who have been pushed into the conflict.

We also have to ask ourselves why Iran is willing to pay this quite horrendous price in terms of people killed, in terms of military equipment and in terms of cost to its economy, which from all reports is in tatters. Iran is determined to try to bring down the current regime in Baghdad. I think the danger that that poses to Australia is that there is a very real chance that the new regime that would emerge in Iraq if the present regime were to fold would be a more pro- Moscow regime than the one there at the moment. Another point that we have to consider very strongly is that after the Ayatollah Khomeini's regime goes in Iran-this could happen at any time in the future-we will see in that country a regime more pro-Moscow.

At the present time the Australian Press has front-page stories every day about what is happening in the Falkland Islands and the fact that Britain and the Argentine are prepared to go to war over the Falkland Islands. I am not playing down in any sense what is happening in the Falkland Islands. I am simply saying that the Australian newspapers have front-page articles saying that this conflict is a great threat to world peace and they have reports about the implications for Australia if that conflict spreads, but they do not seem to have reports-if they do they are at page 19 or 20 of the Australian or the Sydney Morning Herald-about the war that is taking place in the Gulf, a war that has been fought for at least 19 months and a war that has claimed between 100, 000 and 200,000 deaths. If it spreads it could easily destabilise countries such as Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain-in fact the whole of the Gulf. Naturally, it also could completely destabilise the regimes in Iran and Iraq. As I said earlier, those countries have the second and third largest oil reserves in the world today. If we examine that situation we will find that the implications for Australia and for the West, if only as far as oil supplies are concerned, are most horrendous indeed. I therefore believe that this report from the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on the Gulf and Australia is one of the most important reports brought before this Senate for a number of years. It is a report that deserves to be read not only by honourable senators but also by the Australian public generally.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
