DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 November 1981, on motion by Senator Sibraa:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, I want to say a few words about this report. I was concerned by the Press coverage the report received when it was brought down. The Press coverage was limited to the more emotive issues contained in the report, whereas it also contains a great deal of material which is worthy of careful note. The adequacy of Australia's defence must be judged according to the threats to Australia. Therefore, as part of a general monitoring of the implementation of the Australian Government's announced defence program, the Committee decided that it should first develop a thorough understanding of the types of threats and contingencies which may be faced by this country.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not a Government assessment; it is the assessment of a committee of the Parliament which included members of both Houses from three different political parties. This gives it both strengths and weaknesses. Its strength is principally that it cannot be said to be pursuing a particular line for political purposes and, further, that the Committee can be open and frank without compromising Government policy. Its weakness is that the Committee is limited in relation to classified information and its assessments must be read with that reservation. It was the hope of the Committee that the report would have the effect of dispelling unnecessary fears, lead to an informal and balanced appreciation of Australia's regional relationships and improve the climate of understanding between Australia and its neighbours. It was hoped that the report would be read in that spirit.

For convenience, threats to the security of Australia were considered under four heads: First, the potential for global conflict and its implication for Australia; secondly, the threat of invasion to Australia; thirdly, intermediate level threats, such as limited lodgments on Australian territory, major raids on , say, military bases or key civil installations, external aggression against a regional country the security of which is highly important to Australia, and the blockade of an Australian port; fourthly, low level contingencies, which include such prospects as overseas-based terrorist groups using violence in Australia, harrassment of our shipping, fishing activities or off-shore exploration and exploitation, or harassment of our nationals in overseas countries.

In relation to the potential for global conflict and its implications for Australia, the Committee concluded that any general war involving conventional forces of the super-powers would most likely escalate into a nuclear war and, perhaps contrary to some suggestions now being received from the United States, that it would be unrealistic to believe that any resort to limited nuclear war by the super-powers could be contained before the rapid onset of full scale nuclear war. The Committee recognised the dangerous state of the world in relation to the potential for nuclear conflict. Out of its findings a number of important observations can be made.

First, it is critical that the United States be able to deter the Soviet Union from a pre-emptive nuclear attack or a general war which, as I have stated, would be most likely to escalate into a nuclear war. Therefore, in urging arms limitation it is important that we recognise that we are likely to have greater influence upon our ally, the United States, and that we must beware of the United States responding, as it may be argued that it has done in recent years, to world opinion whilst a potential aggressor increases its armaments and upsets the balance.

Secondly, subject to that restraint, it is however in our best interests to encourage progress in the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks and in the Strategic Arms Reduction Talks and to support, as we are, the United Nations Conference on Disarmament. Thirdly, we have an obvious interest in the isolation of any regional conflict to prevent its escalation into general war. Here we can act in a responsible way, particularly within our region, and make a contribution to lessening the possibilities of nuclear conflict. Fourthly, we have an equally obvious vested interest in contributing to the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons. We can contribute by urging and attempting to influence those states which have not joined the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty to do so. In the report it is stated:

The probability of nuclear weapons being used outside the super powers central relationship is probably greater than the chances of them being used by the super powers. There are a number of 'adversary pairs' in the world in which there is a nuclear component or potential capability on either one or both sides .

Any contribution that Australia can make to lessening tension between such adversary pairs can only be in our best interests. Thus, the Australian contribution in the Sinai might be seen as such an example. There is obvious comfort in learning that there is little reason for Australia to be a nuclear target with perhaps the exception of the three joint Australian-United States defence installations. The assessment of their potential as nuclear targets is not based on absolute knowledge of designation and functions of the installations but rather on what might be the Soviet perception of their role. The obvious conclusion is that it would be prudent for Australian defence planners to assume that in a major global conflict they would be potential targets. So there is a risk in their continuance.

On the other hand it must be remembered, as is noted in the report, that they contribute substantially to America's national technical means of verification which is a means of monitoring the Soviet Union's strategic nuclear forces upon which the SALT agreements are predicated. The bases are therefore a contribution on our part to the control of nuclear weapons. Furthermore, in our contribution as host at North West Cape we are playing a role in the command and control system of the American submarine launched ballistic missile force and thus making a contribution to the stable central balance between super-powers. We must expect to pay a price for our alliance, which it is stated in the report:
. . . acts as a deterrent against hostile actions against Australia which are of such a magnitude that they are beyond Australia's own capabilities.

Nevertheless, we are warned in the report that if the United States resources were fully occupied in a major confrontation with the Soviet Union, Australia would have to be prepared to fend off any threats from other powers with only incidental help from our American allies.

The second part of the report deals with the threat of invasion of Australia and finds that invasion by means of conventional warfare is remote, principally because of our geographical location and the formidable natural deterrent it offers. Furthermore, the Committee found a lack of motive on the part of nations for such an invasion, and reports, to our credit, that as a trading country we have been willing to make our resources available on commercial terms, and instances of denial of our resources have been rare. This statement in itself contains an implied warning of our international responsibility in relation to our fortuitous natural resources.

Similarly, in the third part of the report, which deals with intermediate level threats, the Committee again noted our good relations with our neighbours and the little motive that exists for such threats. The part, however, contains several particular warnings which are worth referring to. In one section it draws to the attention of those who read it:

In the event of serious ideological or other divisions-contrived or real-within Australia, a foreign power might attempt to exploit these divisions to its own advantage. External attacks are likely to be more succesful when a country which is the object of attack is debilitated by internal disorder.
I believe that is a warning particularly worth remembering. A second warning which I wish to state on this occason is:
An increased vulnerability to attack is one of the consequences for a state which has become diplomatically isolated because its policies are unacceptable to world opinion.

In our position of geographical isolation and apparent security it is important that we do not become out of step with the balance of an often less fortunate and less secure world. Finally, under that head, the Committee raises for further consideration the subject of the potential for greater co-operation or alliances with other regional powers, a subject to which I believe effort should continually be given.

In the fourth part of the report the Committee finds that low level contingencies are difficult to control. Furthermore, the threats can become a reality with little warning. Deterrents are suggested, such as surveillance capability and strong and efficient anti-terrorist capabilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to debate the 192nd report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which concerns the collection and dissemination of statistics. The Committee is one of only three statutory committees of the Parliament. It has significance in that its membership is drawn from both sides-Government and Opposition-and from both Houses of Parliament. It has an immense output and its papers are highly respected. In addition to acting as the watchdog on the finances of government in a whole range of matters it has in recent years widened its brief. In addition to reporting on many matters that are raised by the Auditor-General and on other issues, it also prepares discussion papers. The paper before the Senate today is but one of those.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the Senate's attention to another innovation. The Committee is holding a series of parliamentary seminars. One is to take place in Parliament House tomorrow. We believe it is important to draw not only the attention of Parliament but also the attention of the wider community to many aspects of public administration. This document on the collection and dissemination of statistics is one. Honourable senators will realise the last major report on the collection and dissemination of statistics was in 1973. It was the report of the committee on Integration of Data Systems, known as the Crisp report. Many of the matters that had currency then are equally relevant today despite certain legislative changes that were enacted in 1974 and 1975. We still have poor communication between producers and users of statistics. We still have a limited accessibility to much existing data and there is still inadequate co-ordination.

Many people in business recognise that there is too great a paper burden on them and that business has imposed on it a very high cost in producing a great range of statistics for a large number of governmental departments. Business, therefore, would like to see a centralisation in the collection of statistics. Government needs to have available to it accurate, up to date and comprehensive statistics so it can monitor the effects of policy decisions, provide information for formulating new policies on the full range of governmental activities and plan for the future.

The members of our Committee believe that there needs to be a reduction in the paper work burden. In some countries, notably in the United States of America and Canada, governments have taken substantive action to reduce the paper burden on their citizens. We believe the Australian Government should take similar steps. Throughout the world the demand for more statistics appears to be insatiable. In spite of the large manpower and financial resources which are currently being put into the collection and dissemination of statistics, unfortunately a number of difficulties still exist.

Our report makes 15 major recommendations. I refer only briefly to a number of these. We believe that the co-ordinating powers of the Australian Bureau of Statistics need to be clarified and strengthened, if need be, by amending legislation. We also believe that there is a need for a central register of statistical information, similar to that which exists in the United States. We believe that agencies should be required to consult this register and obtain the Bureau's approval before embarking on any statistical collection. This, we believe, would reduce the paper work created by various departments asking for essentially similar or the same information from business. We also believe that there is a case in some circumstances for charging for the Bureau's statistical publications but not necessarily across the wide ambit of activities. This discussion paper is a further example of the Public Accounts Committee's concern to improve the level of administration in the Public Service and to provide a benefit to the community at large. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a resumption of a debate on a private member's Bill introduced by Senator Gareth Evans of Victoria. It was last debated in this chamber on the evening of 18 March last, prior to the Senate's adjourning, and I was speaking. Today I requested that my name be crossed off the speaker's list to save time because we have two hours in which to debate this issue. It was my understanding that an agreement had been reached among the parties to complete not only the second reading debate today, which the Australian Democrats concurred, but also to have a third reading debate in which the Democrats would have co-operated. In the spirit of that co-operation I removed my name from the speaking list. Then I find-I am not necessarily blaming anyone here, I am stating a fact-that nine more speakers are now listed for the second reading debate. This means that any hope of getting a second reading vote today has gone. That is no criticism, because this is a very important issue.
—I think it should be said that it was more a hope than an agreement that it would get to that stage.
—Senator Evans should be both pleased and disappointed.
—That summarises it exactly.

—He should be pleased as many honourable senators are now taking an interest in this very important issue. He should be disappointed because the enormous amount of work which he has put into this, for which I commend him, will not reach fruition today. As Leader of the Australian Democrats I console him by again commending him for his extraordinary efforts in this regard and for the wisdom of the philosophy of his proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: I will speak relatively briefly because my colleague Senator Michael Macklin, who will speak after me, is the Democrat spokesman on this issue. As I understand it, he has worked very well and with great co-operation with Senator Evans in bringing the Bill, with its relative amendments, to this stage. In summary I know this will probably offend purists like my friend Senator Evans but as a layman I say that the Bill has two main thrusts. One is to try to take out of the hands of petty politicians, who happen at any time to be a leader of a political party, the right to determine an election date that suits their whim or the wishes of their political party and to have fixed terms of parliament and a fixed date on which federal elections should be held. I commend that point of view with vigour. The second thrust of Senator Evans's Bill is to reduce-this is a fairly brutal summary, I admit-the power of the Senate to refuse Supply and to bring down the Government. I know there are many refinements to that, and I hope Senator Evans will forgive me, but for the benefit of the people listening that is what this debate is generally about.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would forgive you for anything after that earlier wrap-up.

—Senator Evans will be pleased to hear that there are no buts either. On the question of fixed terms of parliament, I have reprimanded those political leaders who believe that the date of an election of a parliament, whether it be State or federal, should be solely in the hands of the leader of the political party which happens to govern at that time. It is an outrageous proposition in a democracy that we allow the leader of a political party, who happens to be Premier or Prime Minister, to manipulate matters to such an extent that he or she can take the Government to the people at a time that suits the political party which he or she happens to lead at that time. We have seen this demonstrated by a series of manipulations. If we have a very good Budget this August speculation will be in the air that Prime Minister Fraser may well be seeking an early election. He can seek an early election and presumably because of the disposition or interpretations of recent governors-general the mere asking for an early election seems to indicate that it will be granted by the Governor-General or, in the case of the State, by a governor. I have expressed very strong views on that matter. That is absolutely opposed to the whole spirit of vice-regal representation. It is rather interesting to look at a speech made by a former Governor-General, Sir John Kerr, which he made in India in about 1975 or thereabouts. He said, very clearly, that it was not good enough grounds for a representative of the Queen or a Governor-General to grant a double dissolution or an early election simply because the Prime Minister or the Leader of the Government of the day asked for one. There had to be some substantive reason, namely the inability of the Government to govern, the difficulties of the Government on the floor of the House or whatever. I put that to one side.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from the immorality of a proposition that one political party can determine an early election or fix an election date-and that is immoral-there is also the instability which this present system breeds in a community. Almost since Prime Minister Fraser won government at the last election there has been monthly speculation as to whether there will be an early election and whether there will be a double dissolution. We are getting to a time when soon we will be past the time when a double dissolution will be a viable situation. During the whole of next year we will have newspaper speculation such as: 'Will Prime Minister Fraser have an early election?' That will start about January or February. There could well be a mini-Budget in March and an election in April or May--

TALK.START.PARA: —What does that do to economic planning?
—Senator Missen interjects and says: 'What does that do to economic planning.' That was an excellent and sensible suggestion.
—What does it do to the Democrats?
—I will acknowledge Senator MacGibbon's interjection if he cares to repeat it because I did not hear it. I will see if it is as sensible and as sensitive as that of his colleague, Senator Missen.
—I do not think you are destabilising the electorate with the proposition that we can go to an election at any time.

—I thank Senator MacGibbon. That is a respectable point of view. If Senator MacGibbon believes that instability is not caused among the business sector of this community every four weeks or so when the Prime Minister prompts or allows to flourish, speculation about an early election, he is spending far too much time away from ordinary people and away from the small business sector which he, as a member of the Liberal Party, purports to represent in this place. It is outrageous to contemplate the proposition that small business persons in particular, can plan ahead to any great extent, for example, planning expansion, investment of new funds, diversifying lines of production if they think that there may be an election in the air within the next three months. I am astonished at the lack of wisdom of Senator MacGibbon's interjection. Therefore, it follows that we should adopt the philosophy of a fixed term as in the United States of America where there is no fiddling of election dates. The electors and politicians know that an election will be held on a certain date. Budgets or unemployment figures or anything else cannot be fiddled with. The Government must face the music at a certain time. In Australia no local government can fiddle with an election date. Councillors in local government face the electors at a fixed time. They cannot hold elections at a time to suit their own convenience. Therefore, I have a very strong support for the philosophy of Senator Evans's Bill in this regard. Again I commend him for that.

SPEECH.PARA: The second prong to his Bill is that of reducing the power of the Senate to block Supply or to stop the supply of money for the ordinary services of the Government. If I am not mistaken, it was in November last year that Senator Evans's Bill was first brought before the Senate. Since then he has been amenable to suggestions of alteration. The Bill currently before the House has certain provisions which would reduce the power of the Senate to block Supply. The Australian Democrats have reservations about the detail of some of those provisions. Senator Macklin will handle them in detail. As I understand the scuttle-butt around this place, there is enough support amongst honourable senators on both the Labor side and the Liberal side to pass those clauses of this Bill which will bring about a fixed date for elections. But, as I understand it, there is not enough support now in this chamber to pass those clauses which reduce those powers of the Senate.

Philosophically, the Democrats are behind Senator Evans in his wish to perform this second function. We have demonstrated our good faith on this aspect because those three Democrat senators who were returned at the last election signed a statutory declaration saying that under no circumstances, not even reprehensible circumstances, would they ever block Supply to bring down a government or vote against tax Bills that would prevent a government of the day from governing properly. We are the only political party in the Senate which has demonstrated that will by signing declarations. I think our gesture of support philosophically is there.

I say to Senator Evans that, while we commend philosophically his intentions in the Bill, there is a view put around by some senators more astute than I that if we are hopeful of getting any amendments to the Constitution it would be better to put those amendments to the people in one question. This is a highly technical matter. As I understand section 128 of the Constitution, any proposed law agreed to by both Houses of the Parliament or initiated by one but disagreed with by the other must be put to the people. What we are debating this afternoon is a proposed law. A Bill is before us. If we pass that Bill and then by some miracle it is passed by the House of Representatives and assented to by the Governor-General, it becomes a proposed law to which the people of Australia will be asked to say yes or no. It has been put to me with some vigour that each of these propositions would have a much better chance of succeeding if they were contained in separate Bills and put as separate questions to the electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would never get them through a referendum.

—I am saying that, if there were a chance of getting either through, both propositions would stand a better chance if put as separate questions to the people rather than in a package as would have to be done if this Bill before us now were passed as a package. I would agree with Senator MacGibbon in a flash in saying that any amendments to the Constitution are difficult to get through. What I am saying, if I can plagiarise from my friend and associate Senator Macklin an excellent expression he has coined, is that by passing this Bill as it stands we would be maximising opposition to any constitutional reform at all by passing two matters in the one package. Therefore, I conclude by expressing some sorrow that the Senate is not able to pass this Bill before it rises at least to show that it is a chamber intent on constitutional and electoral reform. Again, at the risk of being tedious, I commend my friend and colleague, Senator Evans, for the work that he has put into the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill 1981 which is designed to achieve a number of measures which not only directly impinge upon the independence of the functioning of the Senate and our bicameral system but also seek to strike down the Senate as an effective and relevant chamber. The main provisions of the Bill as they apply to the alterations of the Constitution are: Fixed terms for the House of Representatives, fixed election dates, alteration of the legislative power of the Senate, new provisions relating to disagreements between the Houses, and limitations of the powers of the Governor-General in relation to the appointment of Ministers. While all those matters are of vital importance, in the limited time available to me, I shall by necessity confine myself to those provisions of the proposed Bill which most directly affect the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill before us involves the crippling of the legislative powers of the Senate. As a representative from Western Australia, one of the less populous States of Australia, I oppose this and any other proposals the effect of which is to downgrade the power and influence of the Senate in the Commonwealth Parliament. Everyone knows that the Senate was created to provide checks and balances on the Federal system of Government and to safeguard the interests of the States. Everyone knows that at the convention debates of 1897 and 1898 the representatives of the more populous eastern States sought paramouncy in the Federal Parliament. But the representatives of less populous States would have none of it and as an essential of federalism the Founding Fathers created a Senate constituted in such a way as effectively to fulfil the prime role of checks and balances and the protection of the interests of the States, the main elements of this being equal representation of the original States and, except for the financial initiative, powers which in effect are equal to those of the House of Representatives. The Senate not only has the power of veto over all proposed legislation but also, in respect of those money Bills which it cannot amend, has the right to make requests to the House of Representatives for amendments. If the Senate had not been accorded these powers, it is probable that the constitution would never have been accepted and there would not have been a Federation.

We have before us a Bill which seeks to cripple the legislative powers of the Senate and to undermine the entrenched protection of the less populous States. In real terms the effect of this Bill is to reduce the actual powers of the Senate-in fact, to gut the powers of the Senate. As it affects the Senate the Bill will impose upon Australia virtually a unicameral system with all effective powers residing in the eastern seaboard dominated House of Representatives and more particularly the Executive Government. In my view, it would be a great deal more honest of the Australian Labor Party if it were to say that it wished to see the Senate abolished and the rights and the protection of the States which it guards dissolved, a view expressed by Sir John Forrest during the 1897 Constitutional Debates when he said:

If the powers of the Senate are to be limited and circumscribed in this way, would it not be better to sweep it away altogether. If honourable gentlemen are not prepared to give reasonable powers to the Senate, a straightforward way of dealing with the matter would be to sweep it away altogether. We want no inferior or discredited body in this Constitution. We want both branches of the legislature strong: We desire that they should both live in the respect of the people.

I believe that in 1970 Mr Whitlam described the ALP design for government structure as 'a House of Representatives for nation-wide and international matters, an Assembly for each of our dozen largest cities and a few score regional assemblies for the areas of rural population and resources development outside those cities'. That was, in fact, a call for the abolition of the Senate and the six State Parliaments. Mr Hayden, in referring to the Senate on 14 August 1980, is quoted as saying:
We are committed to its eventual elimination.

I believe the real aim of the ALP is to abolish the Senate but it is pragmatic enough to realise that the proposition has no appeal to the electorate of Australia as a whole so it has chosen to camouflage its true ambitions with this Bill which in effect would provide the ALP, should it be successful, with the same result. I have absolutely no doubt that the people of Western Australia will have no part of such a proposition. The people of Western Australia perceive correctly that the Senate is a States House and that it is the only chamber in which they have an effective voice.

It ought to be remembered that the only conditions upon which States such as Western Australia entered the Federation were if the States had equal representation in the Senate and if the Senate had equal powers with the House of Representatives, with the exception of the power to initiate or to amend certain money Bills. If one takes away equal representation and an equal chamber , one takes away the power of the smaller States. The Senate is not just a second chamber in the bicameral system of our Federal Parliament merely to reflect upon the activities of the House of Representatives; it is a chamber in which the States, as separate and disinct entities and as sovereign parts of Australia, are represented for the purpose of maintaining and protecting their constitutional rights against whatever threats may exist and to ensure that their views, grievances and opinions are reflected by those who represent them. The States have equal representation in one equal chamber of the Federal Parliament to allow them to resist proposals which threaten to violate and to invade the rights which have been reserved for them. Of course, it is equally natural that they have equal representation because they were, before entering Federation, and are now, equal in constitutional power and status, although certainly not equal in terms of territory or population. Territory and population should hardly be the absolute test of political status.

One of the terms and conditions upon which the States entered the Federation was that, in consideration for the transfer of certain powers to the Commonwealth, they would maintain their equality. That, of course, could be done only if they had equal representation in the States House. Had not these conditions been agreed upon there would have been no Federation. In fact, alteration to that provision in the Constitution regarding the relative representation of the States in the Senate cannot take place by the normal provision of a referendum of the majority of people in the majority of States voting in favour of it but rather a majority of people in all the States voting in favour of it-a very sensible and wise provision which makes it, in practical terms, quite impossible for that equal representation to be varied. Does anyone seriously argue that these provisions would apply if it were not intended that the Senate have the powers that it has responsibly exercised over the last 80 years? Equal representation was vigourously pursued because clearly it was going to give the smaller States a powerful voice in the affairs of Australia and to ensure the protection of their interests.

The reason I labour the question of equal representation is that it demonstrates the great importance the States placed on the powers of the Senate. The greater the powers, the greater the need for equal representation. The reason the founding fathers from the smaller States fought for equal representation was that they were mindful of the great powers they were vesting in the Senate. Let it also not be forgotten that the reason they fought so fiercely for a strong Senate was that they were mindful of the powers they were handing to the Commonwealth.

Perhaps it ought to be remembered by those who would seek to destroy the Senate that the Federal Government is a creature of the States, and not vice versa. Perhaps certain people, in their headlong rush to centralise all power in Canberra, ought to remember that it was six quite separate, quite distinct and quite sovereign States which chose to join together to form a federation. It was they who decided what powers they would surrender and under what conditions they would surrender them. Yet we now have a call for the abolition of those very same States and for the repository of all effective power in Canberra. I quote Mr R. J. Hawke who said in the 1979 Boyer lecture:

The answer, I think, is that we, who are by nature a fairly conservative people , have come to be infatuated by an assiduously cultivated phenomenon called ' States rights'. I must confess that I do not have any idea what 'States rights' are.
Mr Hawke went on to say:

I believe the logical implication of this analysis is that Australians would be better served by the elimination of the second tier of government-that is the States-which no longer service their original purpose and act as a positive impediment to achieving good government in our current community.

The Australian Democrats have said that the replacement of States with regions is a long-term objective. Prior to federation the separate sovereign colonies joined together at a series of conventions for the purpose of designing a federation. In other words, the States chose to create a federation. The smaller States joined providing they did not give up or sacrifice a disproportionate share of their autonomy, rights, or sovereignty in relation to the more populous States. They were the ones who were deciding what they would allow of their authority to be written into the Constitution and placed in the hands of a Federal Government.

The problems in forming a federation in Australia were not unlike those that faced the framers of the American Constitution-it was how to reconcile the creation of a strong national government while at the same time preserving the identity and sovereignty of the separate States. The result is a partly national and partly federal parliament. The national part of the Parliament is the House of Representatives; the federal part is the Senate, the organ of the States-that part of the Federal Parliament that is the tangible, visible and proper presentation of the States, joining them together as equal representatives in the federal system which they themselves created.

The major provision of Senator Evans's original Bill as it affects the Senate was to take from the Senate the power to reject, defer or amend any money Bill. This provision has now been amended to restrict that proposal to laws appropriating revenues or moneys for the ordinary annual services of the Government. However, in practical terms, the result will be exactly the same. The first and obvious result of the proposal is that it removes all discipline from corrupt, authoritarian, incompentent or delinquent governments and it further compounds the one real danger the smaller States face from a centralised government-total lack of influence over their own financial affairs.

Under the proposals before us a Labor government could simply declare in a Bill that it is a Bill appropriating moneys for ordinary annual services and include in that Bill any legislation it so chooses. Section 54 of the Constitution as it presently stands makes it quite clear that any proposed law which appropriates revenue or moneys for the ordinary annual services of the government shall deal only with such appropriation, and under section 53 the Senate cannot amend any proposed law for the appropriation of revenues or moneys for the ordinary annual services of the government. However, the Senate may amend a proposed law for the appropriation of revenues or moneys for any purpose other than the ordinary annual services of the government. In as much as the resolution of proposed laws is not one for the courts but rather for the two Houses of Parliament, the Senate is presently able to reject or delay any Bill and therefore can provide its own remedy against the tacking of other measures on to the ordinary annual service Bill. This prevents the Government from forcing its legislation through the Senate by tacking it on to a money Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—Order! Senator Crichton-Browne.
—However, under this Bill now before the Senate, the Senate is unable to amend any proposed law--
—Order! Senator Crichton-Browne, a point of order is being taken.

—I think that establishes my point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I draw your attention to Standing Order 406. Senator Crichton-Browne was so engrossed in reading his speech that he did not even hear you call him to order.
—I have been observing Senator Crichton-Browne quite closely and he obviously has some extremely copious notes to which he is referring. I ask the honourable senator to continue.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I did not hear you because of the yelling, screaming and abuse coming from Senator Walsh's side of the chamber. Whenever I hear a mumbling, bumbling noise in the Senate I seek to ignore it because invariably it happens to be coming from Senator Walsh. However, under the Bill now before the Senate, the Senate is unable to amend any proposed law which the Government describes unilaterally as an ordinary annual service Bill, which simply means that the Government can tack any legislation, however unpalatable to the Senate, on to such a Bill. Clause 8 will amend section 53 by inserting after the fourth paragraph the following paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: be presented to the Governor-General for the Queen's assent as if it had been passed by both Houses of the Parliament.

So, in effect, the Senate will no longer have the power to reject or amend any legislation. It is argued by some that the Senate no longer fulfils its function as a States House. However, while much of its strength as a States House is admittedly not always apparent, it continues to function for the purposes for which it was originally designed. On our side of politics there are no doubt many matters that do not even get past the Cabinet room, not to speak of the party room, because the Government sensibly judges that an issue, if it is to be unpopular with the States, would not succeed in either the party room or on the floor of the Senate. I can assure honourable senators on the Opposition side of the chamber that when matters which impinge unfairly or unfavourably upon one or more States are raised in the party room they are invariably consigned to the too-hard basket. The parliamentary Liberal Party has developed a sophisticated, competent and powerful committee system. The present Chairman of the Government members' committee chairmen group, Mr Giles, when he addressed the Australasian Study of Parliamentary Groups in Melbourne, stated:

These powers are, firstly, to screen and give approval or otherwise to all legislation prior to the introduction into the party room that occurs prior to its introduction into the Parliament. In many instances committee opinion has caused alteration to, and even elimination of, parts of major Bills. I believe action of this kind, exercised responsibly, improves legislation and is, therefore, helpful to governments in that they have the power of veto.
The system is a proper check and balance on Executive power and becomes more important than ever when hard decisions must be taken.

The Committee may recommend changes to legislation to the Minister either direct or via the joint party room. Such recommendations are usually accepted in one way or another before the Minister delivers the second reading speech. This might involve changes to the Bill itself, to the accompanying explanatory notes or to the Minister's speech.
As a commendable innovation the Prime Minister has directed that reports to the Government will have Government action taken on them within six months.

I bothered to quote Mr Giles at some length because the composition of the various committees is flexible and any member who wishes to join any committee proceedings is invariably very welcome. One can add that when a committee is discussing matters which may be of particular interest to any honourable member or honourable senator, that honourable member or honourable senator is welcome to attend the committee's hearings and express his views. One invariably finds that if a subject of relevance to any particular State is to be discussed honourable senators representing that State will attend and ensure that that State's interests are recorded. From the point of view of the Australian Labor Party, of course, the Senate may well no longer be a States House because ALP senators are unable to vote in the Senate to protect their States, even in the unlikely event that that be their wish. All their decisions are made in Caucus, which has an overwhelming number of House of Representatives members, and therefore the House of Representatives members naturally control the Caucus and the ALP senators. Of course, the great majority of the ALP House of Representatives members come from the larger States; so there is absolutely no protection by the ALP in the Senate of the less populous States such as Western Australia, in which the ALP holds three House of Representatives seats and, for the moment, four Senate positions.

The history of the Senate is littered with occasions on which the Senate has rejected or amended legislation because it has been contrary to the best interests of one or more States. For example, Odgers, in his book Australian Senate Practice, lists the 1939 Gold Tax Bill, the 1952 Land Tax Assessment Bill , the 1958 Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Power Bill, the 1968 Aerodrome ( Passenger Charges) Bill, the 1970 States receipts duties legislation and the 1973 Seas and Submerged Lands Bill, to mention but a few. Then, of course, we have the Constitution Alteration (Democratic Elections) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Local Government Bodies) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Mode of Altering the Constitution) Bill and the Interstate Commission Bill. In 1974 the Senate amended the Roads Grants Act and the National Roads Act to protect the rights of the States.

As recently as last May a number of honourable senators from Western Australia crossed the floor to vote against the Government on a matter which they believed was not in the best interests of Western Australia. The four honourable senators believed that the two-airline agreement was placing Western Australia at a disadvantage in creating artificially high air fares for Western Australian passengers. It would be a very brave Prime Minister and Cabinet that insisted on seeking to introduce into the Senate legislation that was offensive to the States. What better example do we need than the fate that befell the last Labor Prime Minister? It is not without significance to note the legislation that he had defeated in the Senate and the results that were cast upon his Government by the States of Western Australia, Queensland and Tasmania-the three smallest States that suffered most under his centralist and socialist policies.

In the 1975 double dissolution the Liberal-Country Party gained 94 per cent of all House of Representative seats in those three States. In the same election Queensland succeeded in returning six conservative senators, Western Australia returned six Liberal Party senators and Tasmania returned five Liberal Party senators-a total of 17 for the Liberal-Country Party and a miserable 12 for the Australian Labor Party. If one looks at the general Senate voting pattern, particularly in recent years, when the process of centralisation of power to Canberra has developed momentum, one sees that almost without exception these smaller States have returned conservative senators who reflect the concern of their States for a State voice in the Senate.

It has also been argued that the founding fathers did not anticipate the development of the two-party system, but of course they did. One has only to read the records of constitutional debates to realise that the founding fathers realised that the substantial party system would develop and influence decisions within the Senate. They came from States that had Upper Houses and, quite naturally, there were political groupings in the various State chambers. That perception did not discourage them from the view that the Senate would function well in the role of a States house, which it has done. Alfred Deakin stated:
From the first day that the federation is consummated-heaven hasten that day- the people will divide themselves into two parties.

The instant federation is accomplished, the two Houses will be elected on that basis. State rights and State interests, I venture to say, will never be mentioned because they will never be imperilled. Both sides in order to secure support, will make the first plank of their platform the maintenance and defence of State interests.

He correctly identified the formation of a two-party system, even if he erred in believing that both sides would safeguard the States. There have been those, certainly on the Opposition side of the Senate, who have consistently argued that the founding fathers did not realise or expect that the provision they gave the Senate to reject or to defer Supply would ever be used. Anyone who bothers or cares to read the records of the various constitutional debates will well know that they certainly did. Mr Reid, a delegate from New South Wales, at the Adelaide convention in 1897, stated:
I am prepared to give the Senate, not an antiquated power, never to be used, but a real power-the right of rejection.
The likely use of such a power was, of course, well debated. At the same convention, Deakin, in canvassing the causes and effects, made the following point:

If the Senate decides to take the important step of rejecting the financial policy of the Executive, what would happen? It would thus challenge the policy of the Government and the Government would consult the electors. This may be regarded as penalising them for introducing a measure in accordance with the views of the people. But if the Government is returned at the election, it will be clear that the policy of the Government is approved. I take it that the Council of the States--
Of course, he was referring to the Senate-
Will have fulfilled its office.
In response to an interjection asking whether he would give a second power of veto after a dissolution, he responded:
I am afraid the power of veto must remain absolute.

Here was a man from Victoria, who later became a Prime Minister of Australia, arguing for the power of the Senate to reject money Bills, realising that an election would result. The greatest single concern expressed by the founding fathers when debating the question of protection for the smaller States was that of financial discrimination. While, of course, safeguards are written into the Constitution protecting the individual States from the raising of discriminatory taxes for revenue, there is no such safeguard to prevent the Federal Government from discriminating in favour of one State against another in the expenditure of public funds.

It is absolutely inevitable that if the Senate lost its present powers economic considerations would be enormously influenced by the powerful voices of the eastern seaboard States. In other words, the very fears, concerns and apprehensions that the majority of founding fathers had when they agreed to draw up the Constitution would come to fruition. One does not have to be a cynical political observer to note that money is spent where the votes are, and the votes for either political party are in New South Wales and Victoria. Nothing has changed since Federation. In the first Parliament, New South Wales and Victoria returned almost twice as many members to the House of Representatives as all other States combined. There were 26 members elected from New South Wales , 23 from Victoria and only 26 from the rest of the Commonwealth. Today the ratio is still almost two to one, with 76 members elected from New South Wales and Victoria and 46 from the other States. Indeed, the current situation is that more members are returned from the greater metropolitan areas of Sydney and Melbourne in New South Wales and Victoria than from all the other States and Territories conbined. Metropolitan Sydney and Melbourne return 51 members and the whole of the smaller States and the two Territories return only 49 members.

Is there anyone who really seriously supports the view that the people of Tasmania, South Australia, Western Australia and Queensland are going to vote in a referendum for a constitutional alteration which frees the metropolitan members from Melbourne and Sydney from the constraints which the Senate can now exercise upon them? Now as never before, it is imperative that the States through their representatives in the Senate retain their power over money matters. There has, over a number of years, been a steady move of financial power to Canberra and the States have become, in many respects, mendicants.

There has been an increasing use of section 96 of the Constitution to make specific purpose-or tied-grants to the States, which if taken to excess could make the States agents of a government centred in Canberra. We have the introduction of the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Scheme which entitled local government bodies in the States to share in the personal income tax collections of the Commonwealth. The sum made available for distribution to local government as revenue sharing comprises a percentage-currently 2 per cent- of the total of all personal income tax collections by the Commonwealth in the preceding year. The Senate, as the States' representative, has a special interest in monitoring the fairness of the sums distributed to the States for local government purposes. We have the so-called 'spending power' of the Commonwealth, based on section 81 of the Constitution, the appropriation power, and section 61, the executive power, to enter fields of activity where Commonwealth legislative power may be limited.

I was helped in my consideration of this matter by a book edited by Senator Gareth Evans and entitled 'Labor and the Constitution 1972-1975', which was published in 1977. The chapter of particular help was chapter 2, 'Explorations and Adventures with Commonwealth Powers', written by Michael Crommelin and Gareth Evans. I am indebted to Mr Crommelin and the learned senator. I quote from pages 41 and 42 of their work:

A number of the Labor Government's programmes in the social welfare area relied upon the acceptance of a broad view of the spending power. The Australian Legal Aid Office, established upon an administrative basis without express legislative sanction other than the appropriation of the necessary funds, is a case in point . . . More significant in many respects, however, was the Australian Assistance Plan. It too was instituted upon an administrative basis, with no legislative support other than an item in the Appropriation Act (No. 1) 1974-75 which provided funds for its implementation. The essence of the AAP lay in its creation of regional councils with authority to assess the social welfare needs of people in the regions, and to apply federally-provided funds towards meeting such needs. The range of services administered by councils under the plan extended beyond the matters upon which the Commonwealth could legislate.

There is another aspect of this so-called 'spending power' of which I invite the Senate to take note. This involves the possible extension of Commonwealth powers in new areas not defined in the Constitution on the argument that such matters have become a valid and necessary discharge of the Commonwealth's national jurisdiction and which may be inappropriate to State responsibility. These are complex matters yet to be clearly resolved, but I project them because they are indicative of changing constitutional interpretation and areas in which , I believe, the Senate may ultimately be involved in the discharge of its checks and balances and the protection of the States' roles; and, to that end, the safeguarding of the Senate's amendment and veto powers is vital. If the power over money Bills were removed from the Senate, the smaller States would be totally and absolutely at the mercy of, and subject to the good graces and benevolence of, the larger States. There would, of course, be no checks and balances against the unbridled and unfettered power of the two major States in their distribution of judgment and wisdom.

I make no apology for standing here tonight vigorously defending the rights of the people of Western Australia. It is probably not generally known that the only reason Western Australia ever entered the Federation was the great influx of eastern States people into the Western Australian goldfields. In the few years immediately preceding Federation, the adult population of the colony had grown from about 24,000 to nearly 110,000, that increase being chiefly due to people coming from the eastern States to the Western Australian goldfields. Many thousands of them had never seen the capital city. They had no knowledge of Western Australia, its people or its conditions. Their relatives, friends and associates were in the eastern colonies. Theirs was a purely eastern States outlook.

The Premier of the day, Sir John Forrest, and his government took the view that the Bill for Federation should not be submitted to a vote of the people until there had been time for some sort of assimilation between the populations of the goldfields and the settled areas. The goldfields sent a delegation to London seeking separation from Western Australia in order that they might link up with the proposed Federation. The then Secretary of State for the Colonies, Mr Joseph Chamberlain, brought such great pressure to bear on the Western Australian Government that it agreed to submit the Bill to the people and to support it. In the few months preceding the taking of the vote, the number of names on the electoral roll was increased from 40,000 to more than 96,000. Notwithstanding support from Forrest and the Press, the settled portions of the State voted against it, but they were overwhelmed by the newcomers.

In 1906 the Western Australian State Government first voted to secede, and in 1933 the people of Western Australia voted by a majority of 3:1 to secede, and it was only following that call by the State of Western Australia upon the Imperial Parliament to allow it to withdraw from the Federation that the Commonwealth set up its Grants Commission to provide help for disadvantaged States. With such a record of disenchantment with the centralising of power in Canberra by Western Australia, there is no prospect of this Bill having any appeal to Western Australia or either of the other smaller States. I quote Sir John Cockburn who, in 1891, had this to say:

We know that the tendency is always to the centre, that the central authority constitutes a vortex which draws power to itself. Therefore, all the buttresses and all the ties should be the other way to enable the States to withstand the destruction of their powers by such absorption . . . Government at a central and distant point can never be government by the people.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, pursuant to Standing Order No. 364, in relation to the document from which Senator Crichton-Browne has been reading for the last half hour, I move:
—You can have it any time you like, Senator Walsh. Next time you open your mouth--

—With your vitriolic attacks, I shall do the same thing to you.

—Order! The Chair takes a lenient view of Standing Order No. 406, which says that a speech shall not be read, but I would suggest that if honourable senators want that lenient view to be taken it would not hurt them to raise their head occasionally.

—As a point of explanation, I have an inclination to concern myself with what I am saying, rather than looking around to see the amusement that it is attracting on the faces of honourable senators opposite, and that is why I conduct myself in the way that I do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we are discussing the Constitution and attempts to update or reform it, it is a pity that the debate should yet again descend into pure partisanship. I believe that the Constitution provides us with a framework in which we are able to operate politically. In that sense, that framework ought to be, and I hope can be, the subject of dispassioned, detailed critical analysis, rather than some of the types of things that we have just heard. I agree with a number of the points that Senator Crichton-Browne raised, but I think that they were raised, unfortunately, within a context which makes most people feel not willing to listen to or to take heed of the various points that he was making throughout his speech. I would hope that in the continuation of the debate involved with the Constitution, the various members of political parties, although we disagree often quite violently in relation to policy matters, may come to a less acrimonious debate about the framework in which we must all work.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill brought forward by Senator Evans on behalf of the Labor Party is an attempt to raise a number of the issues which are still here from 1975. I believe that the Labor Party has not succeeded in overcoming those problems, but that in a sense was to be expected. The events of 1975 are still very fresh in people's minds and it is unlikely that the final solution to the problems they raised will be reached within the foreseeable future. Nevertheless, it is useful to raise from time to time a debate on the Constitution under which we operate to see whether there is in the community at large some desire to alter a lot or a small part of the Constitution.

Senator Crichton-Browne referred to the debates at the time of the founding of the Constitution and the intent of the provisions of the Constitution. I do not think anybody in this chamber would quibble with the points that he made. Certainly the intent on the part of the States was to limit as much as they could the powers of the central government. I for one am still very much inclined to that view. However, I do not necessarily agree that altering the balance of power between the central Houses would as a natural consequence mean that the powers of the Federal Parliament vis-a-vis the State parliaments would be raised or lowered. That is not a necessary consequence. It could be a consequence of some changes but not necessarily of any change. Therefore, I hope that we will be able to address ourselves to the particular changes that Senator Evans has raised and see whether the consequence of those changes would have the types of effects mentioned by Senator Crichton-Browne. We should not simply assume that any change must necessarily be detrimental. In a sense Senator Crichton-Browne put his finger on the issue when he pointed time and again to a conservative viewpoint. It is a conservative viewpoint to suggest that any change must necessarily be detrimental.

There are two main sections of this Bill. The first deals with the notion of a fixed term of parliament. I take up the point raised by Senator Chipp. In terms of the informal debate that has gone on about this Bill, it was probably initiated by Senator Hamer; but he can correct me if I am wrong. That point is that in sheer political terms it makes eminent sense to disentangle any changes that we wish to make to the Constitution and to present to the people for their final deliberate vote, one item for one vote, so that they can pick and choose the items they wish to change. Unfortunately in this Bill two fairly major changes still remain, even given the amendments that Senator Evans has foreshadowed he will be moving at the Committee stage to his own Bill. Those changes are, firstly, the notion of introducing a fixed term and, secondly, the changing in some way of the powers of the Senate in relation to appropriation and taxation measures. I must say that I am inclined to the view that Senator Hamer has been putting informally that it makes sense for us to look at one item and one item only so that we can raise it for debate and talk about it in the community.

I would also like to raise a purely technical point. The Constitution, in the way in which it is brought forward, and the Referendum (Constitution Alteration) Act of 1906 stipulate quite clearly that the question that is to be proposed to the people for their vote is: 'Do you approve of the proposed law for the alteration of the Constitution entitled . . . ?' The title of the proposed law is inserted there. If Senator Evans's original Bill were to be carried, that insertion would then read: 'An Act to alter the Constitution in relation to the duration of the House of Representatives, the holding of elections for the Senate and the House of Representatives, disagreement between the Houses with respect to the proposed laws and the appointment and the termination of the appointment of Ministers of state'. I submit that that is not in the ultimate a fair proposal to put to the people. I believe it would be much fairer if all the questions were placed on a ballot paper-for example, the ballot paper in my hand which is a sample of the ballot paper that is distributed at any referndum-in such a way that there were separate questions so that one may vote Yes to a fixed term, No to alterations to section 53 and No to alterations to the provisions for the appointment of Ministers of state. That would seem to me to be a fairer and more democratic procedure in terms of permitting the widest possible intervention of the people in the operation of their own Constitution.

I believe it is unfortunate that the Bill seeks to encompass a wide range of questions that are linked. I think Senator Evans has made the point in one or other of the speeches he has made so far in relation to this Bill-that there is a link between them. That linkage, while being of some substance, is not so strong as to enable them to be considered separately to enable people to take opposing viewpoints in relation to each of the propositions.

I would also point out that what we are debating here is an Act which will seek by way of referendum to put a proposal to the people. In that sense our debates and our points are made in a hypothetical way. The Bill is not for an Act in the sense of the other Bills which we deliberate and vote upon here. It is one which says: 'Should the people have the right to have their voice made known on this matter?' I hope that honourable senators participating in this debate will take that view. We are saying: 'Should the people be allowed to have a voice on this point at this time? In a sense it would be quite open for any honourable senator to vote for this Bill and to go out into the electorate and campaign against it because it would be open to that person to say: 'I support totally the view that people ought to have the right to make a comment on this very vexed question but I do not believe in these very provisions'. That would be a perfectly reasonable proposition for an honourable senator to put. So I hope that in the ensuing debate we will be able to deal with this Bill more at the level of whether we consider these are appropriate measures to be put to the people. I have already raised one point in relation to that, and that is the way the questions are put to the people.

Let us look at the proposal as to fixed terms. I think the substance of the amendments that have been foreshadowed by Senator Evans present us with a firmer viewpoint about a fixed term. Indeed, the amendments of Senator Evans actually do provide for a fixed term, rather than the rolling triennium proposed in his original Bill. They do subscribe, I think, to the generally held view that people in the community have that a fixed term is something similar to the fixed term that we know exists in the United States or the fixed term that we know about in terms of our local government system. Therefore, I think it is better for the general community understanding of what fixed terms are about to have it couched in terms that are readily acceptable or are already operational within the governmental system in Australia. I would support the foreshadowed amendments of Senator Evans because I believe they are a better proposition and a fairer proposition to put to the people in that they accord with what the people understand to be the position concerning fixed terms.

In relation to the supporting arguments revolving around fixed terms, I think we are again in some difficulty. Basically, constitutions provide the framework in which we operate. They cannot ultimately circumscribe either for good or for bad the way in which people work. Constitutions are not able to make evil people good or good people evil. In that sense it is very difficult to frame constitutions in such a way as to prevent every possible evil that one could imagine being visited on a parliamentary system. Constitutions must be couched in as simple terms as possible and should be of fairly wide application. I believe that in this respect our Constitution is a good model. The framework involved in a fixed term parliament would mean-certainly I hope it would mean- that parliamentarians might be able to take a more dispassionate view of the material that comes before them because there is built into our system another element of continuity and stability.

I do not believe, nor I presume does Senator Crichton-Browne as he did not allude to it in his speech, there is any reference in the fixed term element to any destabilisation between the Senate and the House of Representatives. This new proposal does not in any way affect the relationship between the two Houses. The item that we are talking about here does not affect the terms of senators. The original Bill did but this does not. The Bill does not create a nexus, as the original Bill did. It leaves it entirely open for a situation such as occurred in 1975 to occur again. There would be nothing to prevent that 1975 situation from occurring again if the fixed term element were brought in by itself. The Senate could do what it did in 1975. The House of Representatives would be as impotent as it was in 1975 to respond in any way to the initiative of the Senate. The final wash-up of that situation could be anybody's guess.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not an initiative of the Senate in 1975; it was an initiative of the House of Representatives.

—I do not really want to debate that interpretation of history. The point is that the relationship is not disturbed by this Bill unless we take into consideration the additional element in the changes which concern the Governor-General. Of itself the fixed term will not do anything, but the hope is that if there is a fixed term it will create a context of stability in political terms. May I pursue that argument a little. The Senate or, according to Senator Missen, the House of Representatives, in another 1975 situation would find itself with very little time left because the provision states that if a special election were held between the normal dates then the government which came in would have only the rest of that term to serve. This provision is included in many constitutions. The operation of those constitutions seems to have the effect that governments do not wish to take people to an election if there is only a short space of time left in which the incoming government might serve. In other words, there is an added political weight to look at what one is doing.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Senate in those circumstances wanted to take it through, if the reprehensible circumstances were present-and were truly reprehensible-there would be absolutely no reason why it could not be pushed to the final situation that was reached in 1975. In this context there would be a further political reason to think about the action. I believe that is a useful added element. It does not remove any powers; it does not take away any powers of the Senate. But it would add an additional worry for the Senate because the Senate in itself would not be able to force the government to the polls under the provisions of Senator Evans's Bill because he has introduced an additional element-that is, the Governor-General's powers.

Under Senator Evans's proposals the Senate would not be able to force the government to the polls since the Governor-General would not have any powers to dismiss it unless the government lost the confidence of the House of Representatives. As one remembers, that was not the case in 1975. The House of Representatives still had confidence in the Whitlam Government. I think the additional questions that the Senate must direct its attention to are: First, does it support the notion of a fixed term and, secondly, does it support the idea of limiting the Governor-General's powers? They are distinct items and have to be dealt with in a separate fashion. Either of them can stand on its merits and we can have one without the other. I would ask that honourable senators vote quite deliberately and not simply throw out everything because they dislike some parts of the legislation.

The other major element concerns the ordinary annual services of the Government . Basically this is dealt with in sections 53 and 54 of the Constitution. On 13 May 1965 the then Treasurer, Mr Holt, issued a document which came to be known as the 1965 compact. It dealt with the way Bills are put together as they come into the Senate, particularly the Appropriation and Supply Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was an agreement with senators.

—Yes, it was an agreement with senators. There was a committee formed which comprised only government members. I believe that the practice laid down then has served the Parliament well in the time that it has operated. However, if we look at Odgers's Australian Senate Practice, we see that there were a number of occasions, particularly in 1973, on which this practice was seemingly not observed. In 1973 there was a range of problems, some of which were raised in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. I do not want to rehearse that area, but I believe we need to look now at that element and we need to go further.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans in his amendments has not been able to overcome the problem. I have suggested an amendment to section 54 which would enable the High Court of Australia to involve itself in the whole problem of tacking. I understand Senator Evans's proposition. I believe it flows from his basic philosophical proposition. I do not believe that he did disagree with Senator Crichton-Browne that ultimately the disappearance of this chamber would to him be of some political consolation, if not joy. I do not think he has made any bones about that. I think he has also said in the interim that he is seeking to raise particular points and possibly change some points. I believe he is seeking to take more than the Senate and probably the population of Australia are looking for at this point.

I am also concerned in terms of his proposed amendments to section 53 inasmuch as I believe they would enable a government to include in the ordinary annual services Bill any material which it wished to pass without the consent of the Senate. I do not believe that any of the amendments proposed by Senator Evans would provide a remedy against this. In fact, I believe that any government could pass any or all Bills into law simply by tacking them on to the ordinary annual appropriations. Provided that the government has also at least the compliance of the Governor-General-if not the support of the Governor-General-in this activity there would not be much difficulty in arranging its own affairs in such a way as to take advantage of the provisions. I suggest to Senator Evans that from his party viewpoint he consider whether, if these provisions were now in operation, the current Government would take immediate advantage of them and arrange its matters so as to avoid any problems whatsoever with a Senate in which it currently does not have a majority. I think, from his partisan viewpoint, he may even believe that the current Government would be able to take advantage of that, and would probably do so. Again, from a partisan point of view, I believe that when the Australian Labor Party came to power it would in turn make precisely the same use of those powers. The Australian Democrats do not really feel that that would in any way rescue the Senate from becoming merely an interesting but rather outmoded talking shop.

I agree with Senator Crichton-Browne that the preservation of the powers of the Senate is of vital importance. That is why I must say that I was very upset by his speech. It is possible to be a very strong supporter of decentralisation, a very strong supporter of getting powers away from a centralist government and a very strong supporter of State rights. Indeed, as the only person in this Senate who has argued constantly for additional States in this country, I say that on all of those bases it is still possible to give attention to the Bill that Senator Evans has brought down and pick and choose one's way through it to see whether or not there are within it items which would improve the operation of the constitutional framework while not attacking the powers of the Senate or disturbing the status quo in relation to the distribution of powers as between the central government and the States.

I hope that Senator Evans will take in good faith the propositions that other honourable senators are putting forward. At least from my political conviction I believe quite strongly in lesser powers at this level and more powers at the State level. I am on record as saying that and will continue to work for it, but I am looking at the question of trying to remove if at all possible-and gaining a majority within the community to support such an event if at all possible-some of the problems of our constitution. I believe that when one reads closely the debates of the constitutional conventions prior to Federation it will be seen that those who took part in the debates had a very clear view that there would be changes in the future. I suggest that honourable senators re-read the debates on the last section of the constitution in relation to referenda. There they will see clearly that everyone at those conventions knew that there would be changes. I believe that the participants would have welcomed the notion that from time to time the people of this country, operating as one people, would see that their best interests lay in modifying and changing the constitutional framework under which their democratic government operated. That seems to me to express something of the substance of a country which is alive, growing and well . We should always welcome and indeed support those who come forward with such propositions. We need not necessarily have to vote or even campaign for them, but I believe that we should give them our support in raising these matters as an item on the political agenda. That is why I believe that every honourable senator ought at least to welcome the opportunity to have this debate. I hope they will also support the notion that the people of Australia should be able to make their voices heard on these particular issues.

The more detailed elements we will obviously have to work through when we come to the Committee stage of the Bill which unfortunately probably will not be reached today. In a sense I am not disappointed with that because it enables the debate to continue not only here but also in the community and I hope, on this particular element, within the Constitutional Convention. I am sure that those honourable senators who are members of that committee will take up the ideas that have been raised in debates here and use them as a starting point from which to look again at this matter, which must continue to be on the political agenda until a satisfactory resolution is achieved. Such resolutions, as has been decreed by the Constitution, will not be attained until we have almost unanimity concerning it.

I make the plea that we not approach this matter on a party basis. Quite frankly, I could not care less who introduced the Bill. It does not stand or fall by the person who introduces it or the party to which that persons belongs. It must stand or fall upon its merits for the governance of this country. It should not stand or fall because it is attached, so to speak, to a particular person who belongs to a particular political party. I ask every honourable senator at least to vote in the way in which Senator Crichton-Browne was talking about, and that is as individuals from their States looking at their Constitution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is in some ways quite a difficult debate because it began some weeks ago, is being resumed today and will certainly not be completed tonight. Presumably it will have to be taken up at some time next week. It might be worth reminding the Senate that Senator Evans introduced this Bill a few weeks ago with what I might say was uncharacteristic mildness. The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) opposed the Bill root and branch, though he did float the idea of the desirability of having a four-year parliament, a proposition with which I entirely agree, but it is irrelevant to this debate because no such proposal is before us.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Missen incorporated a speech which pointed out the merits of a fixed term for parliament and the disadvantages of some of the other proposals in Senator Evans's Bill. I entirely agree with those remarks made at the time by the honourable senator. Senator Lewis spoke strongly against the whole concept of a fixed term for parliament. In my view, Senator Evans's Bill deals principally with two quite separate issues: A fixed term for the House of Representatives-the Senate has a fixed term already-and the separate issue as to whether the Senate's power over money Bills should be removed. These are not interlocking proposals. One could quite easily have one without the other. My party is firmly against the removal or emasculation of the Senate's power over money Bills. In any case, there is no chance of such a proposal passing this chamber. Even if, by some extraordinary chance, it was put to the people it would certainly be rejected by them in a referendum. It is a pity that it is in the Bill because it distracts attention from the question of fixed terms for both Houses of Parliament, which is not a party matter.
