TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think it would be rejected by a majority of the States or by a majority of the people?

—I think it would be rejected by a majority of the people and by almost every State. That would be my assessment of the position. I am sure that the proposal to remove the Senate's powers over money Bills has no chance of being passed in a referendum. The question of a fixed term for Parliament is not a subject on which the Liberal Party has a policy. We did have a parliamentary party committee look into it some time ago. It was divided on the issue. I understand the majority of its members were in favour. However, the committee made no formal report to the party as a whole and we have never established a policy on it, but for that reason I believe that we should be prepared to discuss it with an open mind.

SPEECH.PARA: What are the advantages of a fixed term for the House of Representatives? I am very surprised that the biggest advantage-that it solves the problem of holding simultaneous elections for the Senate and the House of Representatives-has not yet been mentioned in this debate. This problem occurs when the House of Representatives is dissolved earlier than 30 June of the year prior to the expiration of the next Senate term. The consequent separate Senate elections-and there have been four since 1949-infuriate the public and are a needless expense and irritation. Everyone, or almost everyone, accepts that this situation must be cured. Governments of both political complexions have attempted to amend the Constitution-in 1973, 1974, 1975 and 1977-by changing the term of a senator to two terms of the House of Representatives. I said then and I repeat now that I thought this was the wrong solution to a difficult problem. Instead of bringing senators' terms into line with those of the House of Representatives, we should have planned to bring the House of Representatives terms into line with ours. In any case, the first option has been twice rejected by the voters at referendums. Surely we should look very seriously at the other way of solving this problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —It got 62 per cent of the vote across Australia.

—Yes, but it was rejected. It did not receive a majority of the States. A second advantage of a fixed term for the House of Representatives is that it removes uncertainty-a point made by Senator Chipp. For at least 12 months before the due date of an election for the House of Representatives, there is speculation about the possibility of an early election. The uncertainty does very great harm to business planning and business confidence and, thus, to all of us.

SPEECH.PARA: The third advantage of the fixed term is that it removes from the Prime Minister the archaic and undesirable power of shortening the term of the House of Representatives at his whim. There is a great deal of humbug talked about this. It is represented as being a key feature of responsible government. Walter Bagehot, who flourished more than 100 years ago, is produced as evidence. But responsible government has evolved a lot since Bagehot's day. The development of party discipline has had a dramatic effect. What we should be looking at is what the situation in Australia is now and is likely to be in the future, not what it was in England in 1850.

Why would a Prime Minister want to dissolve the House of Representatives early? I am not talking about when he has lost the confidence of the House or when there is a deadlock with the Senate. These are separate issues which I will come to in a moment. But I submit that the reason a Prime Minister would want to dissolve the House early would be because he thinks he would do better in an election if it were held immediately than if the Parliament runs its full term. I know of nothing in the theory or practice of responsible government that makes this a necessary or desirable power.

It is claimed also that it may be necessary for a Prime Minister to dissolve the House so that he can seek a mandate for a controversial course of action. This is the purest humbug. A Prime Minister does not go to the people for a mandate-for the people to express an opinion-unless he is quite sure what the outcome will be. No, the only reason a Prime Minister would dissolve the Parliament saying he was seeking a mandate would be if he were confident that he had a popular issue and would gain three years more power. Again, I know of nothing in the theory or practice of responsible government that makes this a necessary power or a desirable power.

What arguments are there against fixed term parliaments? As I have said, this is not a matter on which we have a party attitude. But two Liberals, Senator Lewis and the Attorney-General, have spoken strongly against the idea. I think I have to meet these arguments although, of course, as they are colleagues, I will do it mildly and courteously. However, I am confident that if I can show-as I am sure I can-that their premises are inaccurate and their reasoning faulty, they may agree with me that their conclusions are wrong.

Senator Lewis said that the effect of the Bill would be to cripple representative government by taking away the powers of the House of Representatives and advanced a series of propositions to justify that statement. Unfortunately, all of them are wrong or irrelevant. For instance, Senator Lewis suggested that, with fixed terms, responsible government could be negated by the House of Representatives removing one government and installing another without the electorate being consulted. This is true, if the new government could gain a vote of confidence from the House. But it is exactly the same as the present situation, witness the change of Prime Minister in 1971 or the change of governments in 1916 and 1941. No one suggests that these negated responsible government.

Senator Lewis is under the impression that 'under the present Constitutional arrangements, a government from which the confidence of the House has been withdrawn may go to an election regardless of whether the House has expressed its confidence in an alternative government'. This is just not true as anyone with a knowledge of our constitutional history will be aware. Senator Lewis went on to say:

The inevitable consequences of a fixed term for the Senate and a fixed term for the House of Representatives, so far as practical politics are concerned, would be that the Executive would become totally supreme at the expense of the Parliament. We would have an elected dictatorship. There would not be the slightest doubt about that. The Government would serve its term, whether it be for three years or four years, regardless of its behaviour.
I should have thought that this was the present situation. I do not see what fixed terms would do to change that. In support, Senator Lewis advanced a curious proposition. He said:

Let us look at the United States of America where there is a fixed term government. Let me remind the Senate that the United States people had to wait four and a half years after Watergate before they had an opportunity at the ballot box to express their views about the Republican Government. Surely that was a reprehensible action but there was no way the Congress-do not worry about the people-could get rid of that Government. The Congress could not cope with the situation. The result of a fixed term would be that the executive government would reign supreme.

Almost every statement there is false. There was a presidential and congressional election six months after Watergate and Nixon later resigned rather than face impeachment by Congress. So much for the American people having no power or for Congress being unable to act! I mentioned this because it is typical of the false base on which the case against fixed term parliaments has been constructed.
Senator Lewis claimed also that a fixed election date might be awkward. As he put it:

The fixing of particular days for elections in the Constitution has the disadvantage that it is impossible to avoid holding an election during some temporary internal or external crisis or at the same time as some other event. The reasons for wishing to vary the election date may be relatively mundane, for example, to avoid the day of a State election or a celebratory event-or highly significant, for example, to avoid a period of civil disturbance or international crisis.

As a matter of fact, it is almost as difficult to avoid awkward dates if a Prime Minister has to choose a date a couple of months ahead. Although I do not want to make too much of it, I have checked what happened on the third Saturday in November every third year from 1903 onwards and on none of those dates, or in the weeks before, was there anything which would have made an election inappropriate. On the other hand, selection by the Prime Minister of the election date resulted in one remarkable fiasco. In 1914, the election campaign spanned the outbreak of World War I and we had no effective government at the critical time.
Finally, both Senator Lewis and the Attorney-General postulated a scarcely believable scenario in the House of Representatives. It went like this:

The minority faction of the majority party may decline to pass a motion of no confidence, while at the same time joining with the opposition to frustrate major elements of the government's policies. It has been said that no group of members could be so irresponsible. But such a faction may have politically respectable reasons for such a course of action, and may say, for instance: 'We do not want the present Government to be turned out of office; we wish it to carry out parts of its policy which are valuable, and we do not want the Opposition to gain office. But we will prevent the Government from carrying out those parts of its policy which we regard as not in the best interests of the country. Under the present constitutional arrangements a government in such a situation would be able to appeal to the electorate to give it a more co- operative majority in the House. In the past, considering all those jurisdictions which have responsible government, governments have often exercised this right of appeal, and successfully. Under this Bill a weak and debilitated government could be kept in office till the end of its appointed term, unable to carry out its major policies, and unable to resolve the situation.

I think that scenario is so unlikely that it is scarcely worth providing for. But if it were taken seriously it would be easy to cope with it by providing that the Government could declare any Bill a vote of confidence whose defeat would set in motion the dissolution process. It must not be thought that elections following government loss of control of the House are likely to be frequent. This happened only once in our 82 year history-in 1929. I hope I have made it clear that the intellectual foundation for the Opposition to the fixed term parliament is on very shaky ground indeed.

The Attorney-General is quite right to point out that the term of the House of Representatives will not be absolutely fixed. There are two circumstances under which it might be shortened by the Bill we are considering. The first is where no government can be formed which possesses the confidence of the House. I point out that this has happened only once in our 81-year constitutional history. Senator Evans has codified our present conventions and I have not heard any criticisms of this code. This Bill will mean that the consequence of a government not being able to command the confidence of the House will be an election of the House of Representatives only for the balance of the unexpired fixed term. I repeat that this would be a very rare occurrence, particularly as the short term would be a very strong disincentive to the representatives forcing such an election-a point I think Senator Macklin made a few minutes ago.

The second circumstance in which the fixed term may be shortened would be if there were a deadlock between the two Houses. Under the present rules both Houses would be dissolved. I understand that the proposal now is that the term for representatives and short term senators be for the balance of the unexpired fixed term. I would have preferred the new start date for the three and six-year parliamentary terms to be the date of the double dissolution election. I think the government which has control of the date could be relied on not to choose an inconvenient date. This would be a much simpler amendment to the Constitution. I do not propose to press this point in the Committee stage because even if this Bill is passed by the Senate it will certainly go through much reconsideration and revision before being put to the people. This point might well be looked at then.

The Attorney-General has pointed out that the average length of parliaments since Federation has been 2.4 years. If the Bill before us is adopted this length would be increased. But, even more important, the problem of simultaneous elections would be solved. The Attorney-General, as I said, also floated the idea of four-year parliaments. I am sure this would be better than the present arrangements, the average length of parliaments being 2.4 years, but I do not think an eight-year term for senators could possibly survive a referendum. In any case, it is a different issue which does not deal with the problems about which I am concerned-simultaneous elections for two houses, removal of the unnecessary business uncertainty in the months before the due date for a House of Representatives election and removal of the undesirable power of a Prime Minister to call elections that are timed to suit his political advantage.

I understand Senator Evans is removing one unfortunate provision from his Bill. That provision concerns the idea of a joint sitting as an alternative to a double dissolution as a means of resolving a deadlock. This was only a not too subtle way of ensuring the dominance of the House of Representatives. It is merely an irritant in this context and should be discussed separately, if at all . I hope I have made it clear that if we can clear away the partisan rubbish, the emasculation of the Senate, there is a central idea here-the idea of fixed term parliaments and how they might work-which is worth serious consideration on non-party lines.

I think in these circumstances I should make it quite clear how I intend to vote. I will not be voting in favour of the second reading of this Bill. It has too much that I disagree with for me to vote for it. I will be abstaining which will, if my calculation is correct, ensure that it will pass and go to the Committee stage. In the Committee stage I will oppose all the provisions, whatever merits it might be argued they have, which would reduce the power of the Senate. I will not be doing that necessarily on their merits but because I think they have no place in this particular Bill and will merely ensure the defeat of what I think is a good proposition. If they have all been suitably removed in the Committee stage I will be prepared to support the third reading of the Bill which, as I am sure all concerned are aware, requires 33 votes, an absolute majority of the number of senators. Those are my intentions and that I will do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been said that politics is the art of compromise. I dare say that this Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill 1981, therefore is a very political Bill. It is not designed to advantage any political party in particular and is really only a second choice of each of the political parties. It is not intended to expunge what has occurred in the past but it is planned and will provide for a far more stable political future if it is carried. In 1975 the Australian Labor Party took a very important decision after the events which occurred on 11 November and that was to continue to support the democratic option in this country. In spite of the behaviour of and, in my view, the collusion between the then Governor- General and Chief Justice, we made a decision to stay within the normal traditional political processes. There were those in the Labor Party and supporters outside the Party who believed that the Labor Party had all the odds stacked against it and that it should no longer participate in the traditional political processes. There were those who advocated a general strike. The Labor leader at the time, Mr Whitlam, and the leader of the trade union movement, Bob Hawke, opted for continuing in the traditional Australian political process.

SPEECH.PARA: If Australian democracy is to survive I think that more than just 50 per cent of the community will need to say that they want that particular system. We have already got a very shonky electoral system. It is enough to disillusion many people that we can have fair elections in this country. When the next time the events of 1975 occur, whenever they occur, we cannot guarantee that the disadvantaged group, the group that is thrown out of power, will say: 'Yes, this democratic process is all right'. I believe that the Labor Party has as much right as any other party to govern in this country. I am not sure that that view is shared by some of those honourable senators opposite. I am not going into the cliches of the born-to-rule mentality or anything else but the Labor Party has as much right as any other political party to rule in this country for the term for which it was elected.

I think it is very important that the whole of the Australian community supports the democratic process mainly on the grounds of stability as a much abused word. I noticed that in the Tasmanian elections one of the candidates, an Australian Democrat, by the name of Norman Sanders, continually advocated instability as a wonderful thing. I am not sure that the Australian Democrats here would necessarily support him all the way in that philosophy because the sort of instability he wants is some sort of political anarchy where a clown prince like himself can become the king. There is a strong case for stability and it is not necessarily a conservative argument. We on the more radical side of politics acknowledge that stability brings benefits to the citizens.

I cannot remember the name of the economist who made economic projections in the 1940s and compared Australia with Argentina but at the time that comparison was made it was thought that Australia and Argentina would follow similar economic courses. We have a stable economic system and we have developed, whilst not necessarily a perfect growth rate at the moment, a reasonable economic growth rate and a reasonable standard of employment and so on. Argentina, through an instable political system, has had a series of juntas. It has a 100 per cent inflation rate. It has terrorism and secret police-all the sorts of things that we do not want in Australian society.

This Bill is important if people in future are going to believe in the legitimacy of government in this country. This Bill aims to remove the various grounds for discord that may exist in future. I should like to look at some of the main provisions of the Bill although, because they have been covered in detail previously, I will not spend much time on them. Essentially, members of the House of Representatives and the Senate will be elected for fixed terms every three years. There is always the possibility, given some sort of bipartisan approach, that we can extend that period to four years once we resolve the problem of how long the term for senators should be. The actual date proposed in the Bill for elections to be held on the third Thursday in November I think has been given a lot of consideration. It would allow a government to get its Budget through that session. Indeed, it would act as an incentive to get the Budget through reasonably quickly every three years. If that proves difficult, I do not see any great problem in having the Budget introduced in the autumn session and presented some time in May. In fact, I think there would be some positive economic advantages in doing that.

Senator Hamer made some interesting remarks and said that he could not find any problems associated with elections being held on the third weekend in November. Certainly from Victoria's point of view the grand final is over, the Melbourne Cup is over and the cricket and tennis have not started. Indeed, we would have the advantage that we could even tell when the Morgan poll would be leaked and on what day the stock exchange was going to collapse so that everyone would have advance notice of when to sell their shares. There do not seem to be any disadvantages in the date. It is an arbitrary one to some extent, and I dare say if it proved ineffective we could discuss a better one. We have indicated that for a variety of reasons we are amending the Bill to allow not for a restoration of a three-year cycle but for a Parliament, if it is dissolved, to serve out the remaining term. The crucial thing for the Labor Party-obviously it has not received acceptance throughout the chamber-is section 53 of the Constitution. In a spirit of accord and compromise, in which Senator Evans has so dexterously approached this matter, we initially proposed that the Senate have no powers over money or Supply Bills. We have come to the situation where we want only to nominate one money Bill to be certified as the key Bill that cannot be rejected by the Senate. I think that goes a long way to solving some of the problems of 1975, as well as some possible future ones.

The problem raised by Senator Macklin of tacking on measures, I would have thought could have been dealt with by proper draftsmanship. It is unlikely that we will get Liberal support for that proposal. The reason-this is only my interpretation-is that it goes to the very core of the existence of this chamber . A variety of reasons have been put as to why the Senate exists. Some people assert that it is to represent the States. Other people assert that it is to review legislation. Recently, a more common and major reason put forward for its existence is its excellent committee system. I believe that the Senate, as it is now composed-not intended-exists to frustrate the will of a future Australian Labor government. The reality of history is that Labor does not rule in this country in long bursts. The likelihood is that every time it comes to power because of the separate terms of the two Houses, with the Senate being elected for six years, it will face a conservative majority in the Senate. I think the whole attitude of those opposite is dominated by that thought and by the belief that the Senate will be a useful tool to frustrate a government. The principle applies not only in this area; it also applies in my State of Victoria. I think that is also the main role for the Victorian Legislative Council.

The reluctance of the Australian Democrats to accept our views on section 53 of the Constitution is, I think, very much a function of their political existence. It is very unlikely that in future they will be represented in the House of Representatives, therefore this is the chamber where they can have a say. I understand their reluctance to cede any powers from this institution, which is the one institution in which they have a say. We have ceded some ground on section 57 in giving up our proposal for holding a joint sitting to resolve deadlocks between Houses. The mathematics is that if any political party had a major win in the House of Representatives it would effectively silence any expression of attitude from the Senate.

We have also codified the powers of the Governor-General, and I think this is a very important step forward. If we have reserve powers for the Governor-General but do not specify what they are and leave the discretion in the hands of the Governor-General, instead of picking a citizen to fulfil the job who has all sorts of admirable qualities, there will be no choice left for a future Labour government except to appoint a lackey, someone who will just do the bidding of the Prime Minister's at the time. He may be a person of very little talent, but if the main criterion for the appointment of a Governor-General is to be his loyalty to the existing government that will debase the office. It is essential that in some way we codify the powers of the Governor-General.

Finally, almost as an aside, in the Bill we give some recognition to the fact that there are Prime Ministers and Ministers of state mentioned in the Constitution. As I said before, this Bill is a compromise proposal. The essence of the fixed term proposal is essentially a trade-off between the Senate and the Executive. The Senate loses its undemocratic power to force the Government to the polls and in turn the Executive cedes its undemocratic power to stage elections just for electoral advantage. I think the most recent example of that in a Federal context concerned Menzies in 1963. The most recent Labor example was with Wran in 1978. He went to the election a year early just for electoral advantage. We do not believe that power should exist.

The Government will always retain certain advantages. If it cannot pick the election date it still has the advantage of being able to pork-barrel electorates. It has the advantage of staff. I think there is no way we can completely restrict the advantages governments have going into elections. I think we will go a long way if we remove the timing aspect. If this is adopted the power of the House of Representatives to form and unform governments will be enhanced.

The advantage of this proposal, as I see it, is that the House of Representatives is confirmed as the House where governments are formed. The reality is that people make their choice of government when they vote for the House of Representatives. There is no doubt about that. I think that most honourable senators on the other side of the chamber will concede that. The Senate is accepted for what it is. It is not the House where a government is formed. In my view, the Senate is intended to examine and respond to a government's legislative program, not to determine whether that government continues in office.

The Liberal-National Country Party senators were elected, I believe, to enhance the legislative work of their colleagues in the House of Representatives. That is a political reality of today. They do this partly through their ministerial representation in the Senate. We, as Labor senators, were elected to fulfil the same relationship with our colleagues in the House of Representatives. It is also clear that the Australian Democrat senators and Senator Harradine were elected to fulfil a different function. There is no question of people voting for them in terms of trying to form a government. They were elected to contribute amendments or new proposals and to scrutinise Bills, regardless of whether the government was an Australian Labor Party government or a coalition government.

There have been several speeches by Liberal Party members opposing this matter. Probably the most cogent speech was that made by Senator Lewis. I intend to examine some of those arguments. Senator Lewis, in the Australian on 26 November 1981, said of the proposal:

It gives a government three years in which to do virtually anything it chooses- legislative or otherwise-untrammelled by responsibility to the people through their elected representatives in either the House of Representatives or the Senate.

That raises the question of what is a government, what is an Executive and what is a Cabinet. In my view a government, when it comes down to it, is a committee of a majority of the House of Representatives. Given that view, one has to ask oneself whether fixed term legislation would mean that a government no longer needs a majority in the House of Representatives. The answer is no. One also has to ask oneself whether fixed term legislation would mean that the Senate could no longer subject legislation to scrutiny and, in most cases, reject it if it so wishes. Again the answer is no. Senator Lewis continued:
the Cabinet . . . should be able to seek the views of the electorate if at any time its majority is lost through party splits, or the withdrawal of minor-party support.

This did not happen in 1975. Quite clearly, this Bill is designed to avert those circumstances occurring again. In the past an existing government has lost its majority. In 1916 Billy Hughes was able to get a majority in the House. In 1941 John Curtin did the same thing. In 1931, when neither Scullin nor Lyons or anyone else could get that majority after the Beasley-Ward rats deserted the Labor Party, we had to go to an election. If we had a fixed term then the situation would have been that if there had been a no confidence motion in the Scullin government and the Governor-General had called Lyons he would not have been able to get a majority in the House and we would have had an election. The point Senator Lewis has made does not have any validity. Similar sorts of circumstances arose before 1910.

Further Liberal party myths have been raised by Senator Lewis. For example, he said that the legislation's result would be a de facto one-House parliament and that the House could be totally dominated by the Ministry and the bureaucracy. Is that any different from what occurs today? Whether that happens has nothing to do with a fixed term or anything else. If one wants to enhance the power of Parliament over the Executive, I suggest that other measures may be more attractive. It has really got nothing to do with a fixed term of parliament. One of the basic objections raised by Senator Lewis is that the sole purpose is to advantage the Executive government to the detriment of the Parliament. I wonder how one can distinguish between a government and a majority in the House of Representatives. In my view, the two should have absolute confidence in each other.

A further Liberal Party furphy raised by Senator Lewis is that the Government would also give up its right to seek, if it wished, a mandate from the people to make fundamental changes to policy. Senator Hamer's rebuttal of that point was not only amusing but also very biting. When has any government actually done that? It is in fact a euphemism for the opportunistic calling of early elections for short term advantages. Surely it is the role of the people's representatives in the House of Representatives to judge any fundamental changes in government policy as they did in 1916, 1931 and 1941. Senator Lewis continued:
Why not openly seek any desired proposals for change, instead of following a devious path . . .

I suppose it is a rather left-handed compliment to Senator Evans to imply that he has brought in a rather devious Bill that does not confront the issues head on. I think we have to understand that what we are seeking here is a consensus and agreement by the major parties for something that is vital for Australia's future. In my view the greatest and most outrageous statement issued by Senator Lewis was when he said:
The people's forum is to be attacked, to have its powers reduced, in the name of 'reform'.

In my view the Senate is not the people's forum; it never has been and it never will be. The Senate is not the House where government is formed. Because of that supreme fact, the primary reason for Parliament itself, the Senate can only ever be a secondary House subsidiary to the House of Representatives.

There are several arguments that can be brought to bear to prove that this chamber is not the people's forum. Unlike the House of Representatives, the Senate does not even pretend to have one vote one value. There is a fantastic example of malapportionment which gives a Tasmanian vote ten times the value of one cast in New South Wales. Yet in 1980, 2,717,858 formal votes were cast in New South Wales compared with 243,838 in Tasmania. Using New South Wales as the grossest case of under-representation the other States are over-represented as follows: Victoria by 33.2 per cent; Queensland by 134.8 per cent; South Australia by 269.1 per cent; Western Australia by 331.1 per cent; and Tasmania by 1,014.6 per cent. If New South Wales is fairly to have 10 senators what would be the representation in the other States? Victoria would have 7 1/2 senators, Queensland 4 1/4, South Australia 2 2/3, Western Australia 2 1/3 and Tasmania 9/ 10 of a senator. I am suggesting that the Senate should have representation according to the number of electors. I am suggesting that it is not a people's House. This is the point made by Senator Lewis. Here there is no 5 per cent or 10 per cent variation; we are talking about a 1,000 per cent variation. The reality is that we have States' misrepresentation.

The only argument that can be put up in the Senate's defence effectively destroys the myth that the Senate is a States' House. People argue that party allegiances from State to State means that in practice these disparities cancel themselves out. For example, New South Wales and Tasmania each elect four Australian Labor Party senators and four Liberal party senators as a base figure . What does it matter? All this proves is that the Senate is a party House. It also suggests the reason why the Senate is intrinsically inferior to the House of Representatives as a democratic forum. The rationalisation that party representation creates an equilibrium that overcomes a system's bias works for the first eight senators in each State, and in the Territories it gives the parties two senators apiece. As we all know well, it does not explain the 12 seats that really matter. The political reality about this institution is that only 12 seats matter in determining who controls the Senate and what happens to the Government. They are the last 12 seats; in other words, one seat in each State by two elections.

In the foreseeable future-it is hard to make predictions-I believe that 52 of the 64 seats in this House will be electorally predictable. It is unlikely that either the Australian Labor Party of the conservative coalition will ever go below 26 seats. With all due respect to the Australian Democrats that is unlikely. For the fifth seat in each State, over the 1977 and 1980 elections the voting went thus: The Government won five seats, four in 1977 and one in 1980; Brian Harradine won one seat in 1980; the Australian Democrats won five seats, two in 1977 and three in 1980; and the Australian Labor Party won one seat in 1980. This is the substance of the Senate deadlock. But is it a testament to democracy? Not in my view. If we mentally place to one side the first two quotas and concentrate on the crucial fifth position we see that the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales needed more than 300,000 primary votes to win the fifth seat and to elect Senator Sibraa. The quota all up was about 450,000. But in the 1980 election for those comparable vital seats in other States, Senator Haines required just under 100,000 votes, Senator Crichton-Browne required just over 70 ,000 votes and Senator Harradine required just over 50,000 votes. This is not to say that we have to reform the Senate and make all the seats equal to the voting population. But it does belie the fact that this is a people's House; it never will be and it never has been. The excess Labor vote in one State more than equalled the total in the other three States. So this is not a people's institution.

Senator Crichton-Browne, who read a very well rehearsed, conservative piece, made several points. First of all, he said that this is a House of States' rights. Whom is he kidding? It is not a House of States' rights; it does not act that way and it has not acted that way. Maybe there is an occasional showpiece trial every 10 years when two or three people trot over to the other side of the chamber and pretend that they are actually voting for the interests of their State when what they are really about is ensuring their own electoral base. I hate to have to impute that motive to them, but I think that is the case. People opposite, in the Government, are loyal to their party. It is not a quality I criticise them for, but they are here to represent their party and not their State. If they are ever faced with a choice between supporting their party or their State, they will pick their party every time. I might be proved wrong in the future, but nothing in my observation of history or since I have been a senator has contradicted that point.

Senator Crichton-Browne also extolled the virtues of the founding fathers. Having read the constitutional papers or summaries of the constitutional conventions, Senator Crichton-Browne tells us his perceived view of the intentions of the founding fathers and says that therefore those intentions should never be changed. Really, it is a pity that resurrection is not a little closer because we could get back these founding fathers who are the fount of all wisdom and get them to rule this country. No document drawn up 80 years ago could necessarily be as relevant today. Why should we just go by what was said 80 years ago? If one looks not just at the showpiece debates on the constitution conventions but at the wheeling and dealing that was done one would realise that the Constitution was put up as a pragmatic exercise in which power deals and trade-offs were made. The founding fathers would all get up at the convention and make these lofty, wonderful speeches about the principles of Federation and everything else. We know that the constitutional conventions of today do not operate on lofty principles and discussions. That is very much a matter of self- interest and other matters that come into it. It was the same then.

I think the only document in the last few thousand years which has stood the test of time is the Ten Commandments, although there is possible revision there. If the founding fathers had meant this Constitution to last forever, why would they have put in the referendum proposals so that the constitution may be changed? They realised that the document they were creating needed to be modified over time. They put in very conservative referendum restrictions to protect the interests of the smaller States. All we are asking is that these proposals be put to the people for some decision. We cannot make the decision here. The only decision we can make here or in the House of Representatives is the decision that the people not be allowed to vote on these particular measures .

I commend Senator Evans for his initiative in bringing this Bill forward. There is a necessity, I believe, to look to the future to try to head off further constitutional confrontation. It will lead to a situation of instability. It will lead to a situation whereby a large percentage of the voting population in this country will no longer believe in the system. The moment that particular situation occurs, questions of States rights and other matters will become irrelevant. I realise another honourable senator may wish to speak on this Bill so I will conclude my remarks at that point. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Senator MacGibbon) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution so as to vest in the electors power to propose laws and to approve or disapprove such proposed laws.
Bill presented and, by leave, read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is a rerun of the private members' Bill that I introduced in the Thirty-first Parliament. It is being introduced again in this Parliament not only because of the very considerable public support that it has attracted but also for what I believe to be its intrinsic merit as an idea of service to the Australian community. Over the last three years, I have explained the ideas behind this Bill to many thousands of people at almost 100 separate meetings. In every case those ideas have been greeted with unqualified support, which in most cases could reasonably be described as enthusiasm.

At not one of those meetings, nor in any of the conversations that I have held with people at all levels, has any person actually disagreed with the general principle, with one notable exception. I refer to some of my colleagues in this place, some politicians, whose disagreement, for those who care to look it up in Hansard, is indicated in the report of the second reading debate on the Bill introduced in the previous Parliament. But, again, over the intervening period, many members of parliament, both Federal and State, from a number of States, have been in touch with me and have indicated their agreement.

Indeed, my Australian Democrats colleague in the New South Wales Parliament will be introducing similar legislation there. I think my colleague in the Tasmanian Parliament is also considering whether the same sort of legislation could be introduced into the Tasmanian Parliament, where there is, I might say, a modernness of view about democratic methods which I think might encourage such legislation. Tasmania might well be one of those places where this sort of legislation could become law. It could act as an ideal experiment place before the admittedly much deeper and graver step of consideration of the idea for the Commonwealth were taken. The history of this sort of legislation may well be that it is introduced in one of the States and its progress is noted there. Whatever views honourable senators had of it, at least if it were in execution everybody would be looking at it with some interest.

The idea of citizens' initiative in Australia is gaining ground steadily. A number of organisations, including some political organisations, has taken it on board as policy. I am not absolutely sure whether it is universal in Australia but I know that at least some branches of the Young Liberal Movement have discussed it quite freely. Indeed, I have discussed it with them. I think that a number of people in that organisation are interested in the idea as a possibility for an expansion of Australian democracy. As the saying goes, there is nothing more powerful than an idea that has found its time. I am inclined to think that that might be the case. This Bill, if carried by this Parliament, would allow the Australian people to decide whether they should have a democratic right which is already available to people in many other parts of the free world, that is, the right to make laws independently of parliaments in certain cases. It would be a sort of overriding provision of democracy which allows the people to decide what they want to do in particular matters.

I have discussed this matter with people at all levels in the community. I was deeply impressed by the variety of views about it because that indicated to me, among other things, that there is far more interest in Australia in the democratic process and ways of improving it than I had thought. That is a hopeful sign, whatever the fate of this Bill or any other Bill of its type. I was a little disappointed, although not altogether surprised, at what I saw as the narrow and very conservative views expressed over this matter by some speakers when it was debated in the last Parliament. It was dismissed then as a sort of ill-informed populist measure which would not really work in practice.

That appears to me, with hindsight, as self-interest on the part of those people. Some politicians in fact do not want their powers shared with the community to any degree whatsoever, or, alternatively, they have that philosophy that has been described as the philosophy of the great unwashed-the view that the community generally cannot decide its own affairs with any competence or capability but has to be guided by the superior judgment and knowledge of professional politicians. I have conceded the point that there are very many matters in law which are much better decided by Parliaments-technical matters, matters of difficulty, matters of legal complication-but the point is that the history of the initiative in other countries has not been that the community tried to intervene in those matters. In all of the countries where this measure applies, most of the law is still made in the place and at the time that it should be made-in the parliaments.

It has become obvious to me, from feedback that I have got from the community at the meetings to which I have referred, and so on, that this opposition on these grounds during that short second reading debate in the Thirty-first Parliament to the idea of citizen initiative was not really welcomed by the community. I think that those words of honourable senators here, with respect to them, were noted by more people in the community than I would have thought possible, and they did not like them because they felt that this was one way in which at least politicians could consider mitigating their overall power over events-other than an election every three years-and the population of this country has a right to have that idea seriously considered. I believe, and the Australian Democrats believe, that it should be considered to the stage at which it could be put to the people in a referendum.

I wonder how many honourable senators and people here would doubt what would happen if that were put to the people of Australia. To my mind, there is no doubt whatsoever that the people of this country would wish to have that power. Basic to this debate is the responsibility upon members of this Parliament of deciding whether or not they feel that they should deny people not the opportunity of having the power but the opportunity of deciding for themselves whether they want it. That seems to me of great basic importance. I should have thought that if members of Parliament were prepared to try this out-it may be a bold step into the future-at least it would enhance the view that the public has of politicians. At least we would get the credit from the people of being shown to be trusting of the people, who, after all, elect us, and whom we are supposed to represent, who are the population of this country. I should have thought that that would have been the least of its merits.

I am convinced, on balance, from the contacts I have had with the electorate over the last few years, that this legislation is something that the Australian people want, and it is especially wanted by those people I would regard as being in highly responsible positions and very well equipped indeed to make the necessary judgements. I would suggest that in many ways that is all that is required. What is needed to make this work-this has been the experience in other countries-is sufficiently highly motivated people with an interest in democracy and in affairs to more or less lead a movement. Someone has to organise the necessary authorising petitions and things of that kind. I firmly believe that we have sufficient citizens' movements in Australia and things of that kind to make that possible.

As I have said, the Bill seeks to change the Australian Constitution to give the Australian people the inalienable right, in certain circumstances, to make law through a process completely independent of the Parliament. The fundamentals of the Bill are very simple. It seeks a referendum for a constitutional amendment, because that happens to be the only way in which our Constitution can be amended. The people themselves must change the Constitution, and that, of course, is how it should be. This Bill, if carried, would create a new chapter of the Australian Constitution-Chapter IX. This new provision in the Constitution would allow any proposition for change of the law, that is in any field of the law at all, and indeed, of the Constitution itself, to be initiated -the word 'initiated' means 'citizens' initiative'-through a petition of 250,000 signatures, that is, a quarter of million signatures. Propositions brought forward in this way would be presented to the people once a year on a set day. There would not be a separate day for each proposition to be voted on. They would be collected over a period as they are in other parts of the world, notably in California. That is how Proposition 13 got its name. It was the thirteenth proposition on the list. The propositions would be voted on at the same time.

In the case of a change to the Constitution, there would have to be a clear majority nationally and a majority in the majority of the States. But the Bill also provides that where a two-thirds majority nationally is achieved, then the provision for a majority in the majority of the States shall not apply. I think there is a good reason for that. On the side of constitutional change there is a point of some importance that is worth mentioning. I am not altogether clear on this. I do not think anybody is. I have discussed it with a number of constitutional lawyers who believe that in this vehicle of the initiative there may well be the machine for constitutional change which Australia needs so badly . It is well known by all people who have studied the mechanisms within the Constitution for its own change that it is very difficult to get results but there is a respectable legal point of view if this new chapter came into existence in the Constitution it would give the people an overriding right, because it was the right of initiative, for the reform of the Constitution itself and if that were so it could be a most exciting possibility, and I would think something of an argument for this right. I am not prepared to go further than that. It is matter which I am sure would engage a good deal of hot legal debate. I am not qualified enough to make or pretend to make any kind of pronouncement on it. I am merely indicating that as a useful possibility.

The Australian Democrats contention is that the present system, which allows only the Parliament the right to initiate laws, is an anachronism and increasingly so. It had relevance, I think, in the nineteenth century when people conceded that they wanted their representatives to make laws for them. Then the degree of education was much less in the community than it is now and the degree of involvement and interest in public affairs were also much less than they are now. I think it is no longer enough for free people in the late twentieth century to have only the right to elect one party or another to government, indeed to have no real control over the legislative process beyond that of election. I suggest that increasingly governments are beginning to recognise this because the number of referenda or proposed referenda or discussions on referenda are becoming greater as the years pass. I think it is a basic understanding on the part of the legislators that this is a good thing. If it is indeed a good thing, then why is not the initiative a good thing? I think it is not enough to say that proposals for referenda should come only from parliaments. They should also come from the people, if the people so wish.

The Bill if carried, and if the referendum were approved by the people, would remove at one stroke whole regions in which the community clearly and consistently perceives the risk of governmental corruption. As matters now stand , financial and other influences brought to bear on governments are perceived as being reflected in the making of law, and also in the absence of certain kinds of laws. The community perceives itself as powerless to control that process, as indeed it is, and perhaps for that reason gives it far greater weight than it ought to do. Nevertheless that does not induce us, I hope, to underrate the appearance and the effect of that process on the community. This new power would make it impossible for firm guarantees to be given by governments to powerful lobby groups that something would, or would not, happen because obviously if a sufficiently large number of people wanted to initiate a matter it must happen if it were approved by a majority of the people, regardless of what the Government wanted. I suggest this new power would make for a much healthier political climate. I think that the merits in that respect alone would be great. Those merits would provide a greatly needed renewed faith in the democratic process in this country.

It is of some interest historically that when the right to initiate referenda was introduced in a number of American States in the first decade of this century it was because of a widespread disenchantment of the people with the democratic process at that time. I suggest that that situation applies here. It is obvious. One has only to read a newspaper or listen to a radio to know that that is increasingly the case and that politicians, for whatever reasons, are not given much credit for their work. All of us are tarred with a certain kind of brush-whether we like it or not and whoever we are-in the public mind. That in itself is bad. It is regrettable. Having been a member of this place for four years, I believe it is altogether unjustified. Surely it devolves on us to try to find some mechanism whereby we can increase public trust in us. Again, that would make for a much healthier political climate.

As I said earlier, opposition to this issue has been expressed in this place. I do not like it. I believe it was insincere. It really comes back to the nub of the debate on whether this principle will be adopted. Does one say that this country is really a democracy and is one prepared to trust the people who make the decisions? I believe the issue is as simple as that. If one says that one is not prepared to do so then one is really bringing forward only the arguments which were historically presented much earlier against universal suffrage and later women's suffrage. They are the old arguments that things are difficult, law is complicated and there are so many matters about which people do not know enough to decide.

There is a certain truth in that. I think that most people would say that in many areas of law they do not know enough to decide, but there are other areas of law where I think the people could probably make a much more acceptable decision than we could. A community is much more likely to accept a decision which is made by the majority of its peers than one which is imposed on it by government. In fact, this has been one of the lessons of the use of the initiative and referenda in other countries. Those arguments which say that people do not know enough to decide-no matter how tortuous the attempt may be to conceal the main point-are actually, in the end, arguments for some kind of dictatorship or oligarchy. This may be subject to a check every three years but basically that is the situation. I think that must be clearly said again and again as often as these arguments are advanced against the idea of the initiative.

What are the other merits of the idea? First, it allows matters of very considerable public interest to be brought to the attention of the electorate in a far greater measure than they are now for decisions to be made. This means that the people realise they have a responsibility to understand a matter because they have to vote on it. That is not the case at present. The electorate tends to be diverted by and engaged in other matters at election time-trivia and short term measures such as whether they are going to get a tax cut in three months time. It is not good for the country that the electorate should vote only on that basis.

Matters which are brought forward for decision at the actual vote of this referendum would be unlikely to be trivial. So far as I know, in recent decades there has not been a single petition presented to this Parliament which would have been large enough to secure an initiative. I may be wrong on that, but I do not think so. The requirement of 250,000 signatures sets a very considerable goal to achieve. But if it were thought to be too small the Parliament, plainly, would have the power to suggest a higher figure. This is merely an idea. Any modification, change or discussion of it would be welcomed by me. Certainly I am not laying down what is contained in the second reading speech or indeed in the Bill as the last word on the subject. I would hope to see it amended and other wisdoms brought to bear on it. I would think that an amendment that sought a much higher number of names-for instance, half a million signatures or more- would be insincere because that would be very difficult to achieve in Australia. I believe it would place an unfair strain-an unfair financial strain among other things-on the people who were supposed to organise it. It might also lead to other abuses which I will mention later. This idea, like all ideas of this kind, is by no means a panacea or overall cure-all. The proposal represents an experiment-a bold step forward for this Parliament and certainly a bold step forward for the Australian people. There would be no harm in some caution being exercised. As I said, my purpose is merely to have the idea freely canvassed and discussed, and perhaps amended or changed.

Is the whole idea merely an idealistic exercise in impractical democracy? I do not think so. As I shall later show, it works very well in some of the world's most successful free societies-societies within friendly nations and regions with which Australia already identifies. Beyond that, it enjoys other advantages . In a future which is generally acknowledged to present difficulties and problems, to require some sacrifice on the part of the community at large, is it not best to allow that community to involve itself in some of the issues, to give it the means to study and know the facts? Is it not likely that such an opportunity would give the people a greater sense of responsibility and involvement and so, over a period, encourage them to a more far-sighted attitude ? I suggest also that it would give them a much greater understanding of the problems of legislatures and perhaps a great deal more sympathy with the problems of members of parliament. I suggest that the more people became involved in this way the more they would be inclined to understand, to sympathise and to exercise what influence they had on the political process in a more responsible way.

Is that, again, mere naivete? I suggest that it is not. I believe that there is evidence to the contrary. We know that we have a much better educated generation than we have had before. I would say that it is also a much more politically aware society than has existed in the past. The enormous increase in both media and public interest in politics and the rapid growth of citizens' movements of all kinds surely demonstrate this. The old idea that politics was something that people never discussed has disappeared. Continuously politics is a matter of active discussion and of great interest in the society. I believe that that tendency indicates a desire on the part of the community for more input, a desire to play a greater part. I believe that much of the frustration with the political process is due to the fact that intelligent, aware people who would like to play a part in fact do not play it because the machinery is not there to enable them to do so.

Another advantage would be a fuller use of political expertise and experience in government. It should be obvious that one of the regions in which initiatives are most likely to be organised would be that of the Opposition in this Parliament. Is there anything but good in that? Is it not ludicrous that all influence that is vested in one area should become virtually no influence within a matter of days, as a result of an election? Surely the nation would be better served if an avenue existed whereby the Opposition, given sufficient effort and support-by obtaining 250,000 signatures-could be able to bring forward a matter for referendum. I can see, and the Australian Democrats can see, no harm in that whatsoever-nothing but good.

Would this device of the citizens' initiative be abused? Like every other right , it could indeed be misused by power pressure groups. No freedom can be absolutely guaranteed. No device works uniformly successfully. The proper use of the initiative would then be a matter for the community to look after, and that is as it should be. Would this right usurp the authority and usefulness of the Parliament? Far from it. In other countries that have the initiative the making of the vast body of law, especially in technical or complex areas, has remained the responsibility of the Parliament-even after many decades of application. I believe that would also be the case here.

Would the device be unduly costly? We have to bear in mind the enormously important input and extra responsibilities that it would bring to the community. I do not think that it would be costly in either real or relative terms. The Bill proposes that the referendum be held in the first Saturday of each December . As a national referendum, it would cost about the same as a national election. That is probably an extreme view. It may be cheaper, but if it did cost the same it would cost about $10m-a large sum of money but only 71c per head of population each year. That is not a very large sum to expend in obtaining those kinds of rights. In addition, every three years the date of the referendum would coincide with the date of the national election-if indeed we had a fixed-term parliament as I hope we will. That would diminish the cost enormously in that year. They could be conducted simultaneously. The average cost over time would also be reduced.

The right of the citizen to initiate referendums is practised already, as I have mentioned, in several of the more enlightened countries, including Switzerland, Austria and the United States of America. The right is often found to be a long-standing one. It was granted to the Swiss in 1892, as long as 90 years ago, and it has been adopted by 24 States of the United States of America since 1890. In Switzerland, between 1892 and 1944, 47 initiatives were submitted to the confederation through petition. Of those, about one-quarter were adopted. The others were either rejected or withdrawn, which indicates a pretty high rate of rejection. Again, I think that is a healthy and reassuring sign. In the United States, the most famous recent example of a citizen-initiated referendum is probably the Californian Proposition 13 of 1977 which altered the taxation laws, justifiably, because increasing property taxes due to inflation were giving the Government of California quite an unjustified growth of revenue. A later proposition aimed at cutting a different kind of taxation, income tax-from my study it was not so justified-was, in fact, rejected by the Californian people, which indicates, I feel, that they could be trusted to judge a referendum topic on its individual merits and not just on whether it would result in personal gain for themselves.

I stress that, as with any instrument of government, this power could of course be abused. It relies for its effect on a reasonably large number of politically aware and interested people in the community. But, of course, if the initiative is working well it tends to increase the number of such people. For many years in America the initiative was misused by commercial groups who used paid operators to organise the necessary number of names and petitions. But there is, of course, beyond the actual petition the final and ultimate safeguard-the fact that the people themselves decide through their vote whether or not the matter becomes law. So even if commercial or extremist lobbyists succeeded in getting their ideas on to the annual referendum ballot paper those ideas would still be subject to the commonsense judgment of ordinary people. Granted that, I have no fears about the values of the initiative if introduced in Australia. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Durack) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Funding of Western Australian Community Development Centre

PROCTEXT.PARA: Funding of Western Australian Community Development Centre

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A news release dated 17 May 1982 from the Minister for Health (Mr Carlton) gives an account of a brief ceremony at which a cheque for $42,500 was presented to an organisation called GROW, the acronym for the Group Recovery Organisations of the World. Mr Carlton on this occasion said that GROW is Australia's largest non-governmental mental health organisation conducting, as it does, the residential drug and alcohol rehabilitative program in New South Wales. He said that this year the Government will provide $296,000 to this organisation. At the same time, the Western Australian Government has announced the closure of its Community Development Centre. The CDC, as it is known in Western Australia, is an initiative which, since its inception some 15 years ago, has worked for the promotion of sound emotional and mental health and has made Perth a leader in this field. At nominal or no cost, hundreds of men and perhaps thousands of women have gained new skills and awareness, becoming valuable community resource people who, through their immediate and extended families, neighbours and community involvements, care, inform and add a vitality to society which, without their training, might never have developed.

SPEECH.PARA: Many agencies, including, I believe, GROW, have benefited, if not actually survived, because of the committed voluntary energies and time that the Community Development Centre trained citizens have poured into them. Religions and charitable groups, those involved with young offenders, homeless and abused women and children, relatives and friends of the mentally ill, are just a few of the groups which have received assistance and training through the CDC. The country service of the CDC was expanding to include effective living and assertiveness courses, the acquisition of marriage guidance skills and courses in stress management, et cetera. Recently two women wrote from Merredin. They said:

It seems to us that the services provided by the CDC in keeping healthy people healthy is one we can in no way afford to dispense with. Certainly from a country point of view there is nowhere else we can possibly get this service.

The Western Australian Government gives as its reason for closing the centre that the service was difficult to evaluate. Humanitarian considerations apart, it is plain poor economics to put the sickness industry before preventative medicine. The social costs of not providing preventative dimensions of community services are easily quantified. We can start off with identifying the $296,000 given by the Federal Government to GROW this year for its drug and alcohol rehabilitation program. As far as I know, GROW is a highly laudable organisation . It is the incredible inconsistency of the Government's actions which appals me . I know that such decisions by State governments are largely out of the hands of the Federal Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). I do believe, however, that there is a growing public awareness of the need for a greater national emphasis on the prevention of mental and physical disease and on the need to educate and support those who seek effectively to communicate, manage their stress, assert their dignity and cope with their sexuality. If the Western Australian Government opts out of such a responsibility, as it apparently seeks to do, we will have to evolve federal schemes for specific grants and line up with GROW and the other organisations for a periodic handout.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney was advised that Senator Giles would speak on a subject within his general area of responsibility. Unfortunately he is unable to be here. I will draw his attention to the remarks which Senator Giles has made. She will recognise that probably he can do very little in regard to this matter; however, I am sure he will be interested in what she has said.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.2 p.m.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Closer Economic Relations with New Zealand

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 25 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister answer the actual questions asked by Senator Peter Rae without notice on 16 February 1982 to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources and answered on 24 March 1982, namely:

'What research work has been undertaken to assess which industries and which areas in Australia will be most adversely affected if the closer economic relations with New Zealand proposals go ahead? If such work has been undertaken, what are the results and will they be made available? If the work has not been undertaken, will the Minister put to his colleague a suggestion that the work should be undertaken before any further discussions take place with New Zealand? '
If so, when will he provide me with the requested answer; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: In accordance with guidelines contained in the joint Prime Ministerial Communique of 21 March 1980, Australian and New Zealand officials have conducted a series of detailed studies relating to possible arrangements for a closer economic relationship (CER) between the two countries. These studies have included such subjects as tariffs, import restrictions, differences in tariff treatment accorded to intermediate goods industries, export incentives, agricultural support/stabilisation schemes and government purchasing. In connection with these studies, consideration has also been given to issues affecting specific industries in the agricultural and manufacturing sectors.

In relation to agriculture, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics has conducted a series of detailed commodity-by-commodity studies and a research paper dealing with the comparative efficiency between the Australian and New Zealand dairy industries and implications for trans-Tasman trade.

Apart from the BAE dairy study, which was published in September 1981, studies have not been undertaken with a view to publication. However they have been drawn upon by the Government in formulating views as to what would constitute an appropriately structured closer economic relationship with New Zealand. The central trade objective of that relationship was described by Prime Ministers as the gradual and progressive removal of barriers to trade between the two countries.

Officials have consulted closely with industry groups in the course of their studies and views received have been taken into account by the Government in determining Australia's policy approach in negotiations with New Zealand.

Therefore, while it is not intended that the various studies undertaken by officials be published, the results of such studies will be reflected in the package of proposed measures for a new trading arrangement between Australia and New Zealand. That package will be made public before final decisions are taken by the Government. The implications of the proposed package for specific industries and areas will be considered by the Government in this context.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What helicopters are being evaluated for long term operations on the Royal Australian Navy's FFGs.
(2) Is it intended to used OH-58 type helicopters in the interim shipborne helicopter role from these ships: if so, what modifications are planned to the helicopters used in this role.
(3) What operational limitations will be placed on single-engined interim helicopters to ensure the safety of their crews.
(4) What will be the expected level of availability of interim helicopters given any restrictions on their use for safety reasons.
(5) What operational limitations will be inherent in the use of interim helicopters due to the limitations of the equipment used.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The helicopters being evaluated for long term operation from the RAN FFGs are as previously announced on March 6 1981:
(a) Sikorsky Seahawk
(b) Aerospatiale Super Puma
(c) Aerospatiale Dauphin
(d) Westland Lynx
(e) Sikorsky S76

(2) Yes; as a training helicopter. Minor modifications will be undertaken, to improve the safety of small ship operation, and will include fitment of a rotor brake and a more suitable skid landing gear. It is possible that the OH-58 type, the Bell Kiowa, may be replaced later by the light utility helicopter proposed for RAN and RAAF acquisition in the near future.
(3) The helicopters will operate in conditions to be established by first of class flying trials, which will ensure the maximum safety to personnel, ship and aircraft.

(5) Alternatively I refer the honourable senator to the answer to Question No. 2158.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What proportion of the Royal Australian Navy's requirements for helicopters operated from FFGs will the interim helicopters be unable to meet.
(2) Can Sea King type helicopters be operated from FFGs, and are they intended to do so.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is not intended that the FFG interim helicopter be utilised in other than a training role to develop helicopter/ship procedural skills.
(2) Yes; in an emergency a Sea King could be landed on deck, although not hangared, but there is no intention to operate them from FFGs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is recycled paper used in the Minister's Department; if so, in what capacity is it used; if not, will the Minister consider using recycled paper in preference to new paper wherever possible.
(2) Is paper from the Minister's Department recycled; if not, will the Minister consider having this done.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Paper used in the Department of Defence is obtained under contract arranged by the Department of Administrative Services. It is possible that some of the paper supplied could fall into the category of recycled paper, but no details are available as all paper appears in the new condition when delivered.

(2) The Department of Defence uses paper recycling services for unclassified waste where these are arranged by the Department of Administrative Services. Unclassified waste paper not covered by this process is disposed of by cleaners contracted through the Department of Administrative Services. Under no circumstances will classified waste paper be made available for recycling.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Australian Embassy in Washington: Security Checks

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 February 1982 (Hansard, page 481) Senator Sibraa asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, refers also to the arrest of a former employee of the Australian Embassy in Washington on charges of stealing. What security checks are applied to prospective employees before they are granted employment with our Washington Embassy? Have the staff cutbacks resulting from the razor gang's decision led to a breakdown in security arrangements?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The employment of all locally-engaged staff at the Australian Embassy in Washington is subject to a police records check in the United States, as well as in their country of nationality and in any other country of prior residence. In making these checks, the Embassy must rely on the accuracy of information provided by agencies of other governments.

Generally it is not possible to fully complete police record checks prior to the engagement of an employee. If checks cannot be completed prior to an engagement the employee is placed on probation, which is not confirmed until the checking process has been completed. In the case of the former employee mentioned, checking was completed in accordance with established procedures.
The imposition of staffing restrictions has not resulted in a breakdown of security arrangements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1442) Senator Mason asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence . Is the Government aware that when the Government of Argentina understood that British nuclear submarines were in the vicinity of the Falkland Islands the Argentinian Navy's aircraft carrier was withdrawn to port, where it appears it has remained ever since? It is known that there is a world-wide disposition of nuclear submarines and that they could be expected to be present everywhere in the world in a normal war situation. In that case, in a war in which Australia was involved what would the Government propose to do regarding our new aircraft carrier, Australia? Would the ship be kept in port or sent to sea? What would be her usefulness in either of those circumstances?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following information which is additional to that provided by me on 22 April 1982:
My Department has received no information to suggest that the Argentinian Navy 's carrier was withdrawn to port because British nuclear submarines were in the vicinity of the Falkland Islands.

HMS Invincible is a modern warship which has been designed specifically for Anti Submarine Warfare (ASW) operations in the NATO strategic environment where there is a considerable threat from nuclear submarines.

As the central element of a task group, whose major role is to detect and destroy submarines (whether they be nuclear or diesel electric powered), she has proven to be a very effective ASW vessel in NATO exercises.

In war the new carrier would be at sea, operating in conjunction with other elements of the Australian Defence Force, pursuing the strategy adopted by the Government of the time. One of her primary roles could be the protection of shipping in which she has a demonstrated capability to perform effectively.
